If you enjoy babysitting 18-20 year olds, then this is the place for you. Otherwise, when someone approaches you and you hear the words, "hello, i'm a manager for abercrombie and fitch I was wondering you had a moment..." RUN.
review_advice_mgmt: Listen to the management staff below you. If you realized that the company has changed dramatically over the last few years and that it is not as easy-breezy as it used to be when you were running stores, maybe you would understand our frustrations better.

review_title: Buy the clothes, waste your check
review_pros: Clothes discount. You have to work early to please Mr Jefferies just incase he comes to your storel.  The managers work insane hours.
review_cons: You have to buy the ridiculous clothes with a low discount.  The hours are awful.  Closing down and folding the store will often keep you longer than necessary.
review_advice_mgmt: Higher discount.  Better pay for the managers.  They work insane hours for very little benefit. This is a job I didnt mind leaving.

review_title: sales rep, costumer service, & lots of folding clothes
review_pros: The managers are usually young so they are easy going and fun to talk to. They work around your schedule and if you want time off you just request it. The people you work with are usually the same age so it basically like working with your friends.
review_cons: Its a pain closing the rooms down, the mangers expect the rooms to be perfect, as if no one touched the clothes. And there gets a point where you get sick of folding. Costumers are rude and always complain about the music.
review_advice_mgmt: Be alittle easy on the models, they are getting paid minimum wage for a job where they expect alot .

review_pros:
Benefits
Resume Builder
Working with fun people
review_cons:
Unresonable upper management
No creativity
Strict dress code/look policy
Moraly unreasonable
Low pay for college grad
review_advice_mgmt: Out of touch with realty - higher management truely believes that hiring great looking people = higher sales.

review_pros: Benefits and working alongside attractive co workers are about the only two things that are worth working for this company
review_cons:
Awful trickle down management style, poor performance reviews, incredibly biased hiring practices, most senior managers have terrible tact when attempting to redirect someones struggling performance issues, inept when it comes to business strategies and selling practices are most district managers, micro managed by at least three different bosses on any given day

the people who are complacent with this job have the following to say in defense "well you have to get up and get dressed for work everyday, i get to wear flip flops and jeans to work and hang out with hot people."
review_advice_mgmt: Promote managers based on associate feedback as well as retention and turnover percentages.  If a DM has held a 200% manager turnover rate then that person is probably unpleasant to work with and for.  Promoting people with reputations like this sets a bad example for managers looking for long term employment with the company.  It would behoove the company to take a more active role in caring about a work/personal life balance in it's full time associates to ensure employee satisfaction.  Most associates are under paid and over worked at this company and all that shows for it is constant weight loss due to overnight shifts during holidays, inept assistants that other managers have to pull the weight for and district managers that can barely make a conference call on time much less manage three high volume cross branded malls.

review_pros: Discount on clothes, great music, smells good, easy work, very good looking co-workers, laid back, little cleaning, and short shifts
review_cons: the cons of working at abercrombie are somewhat tied to the pros. the music is on a loop every 45 minutes for 2-3 months so you will have all the songs memorized, the cologne can get alittle out of hand because they spray it every 2 hrs. the good looking co-workers are usuallly a--holes, the little cleaning is usually done by the least favorite person of managment.
review_advice_mgmt: realize that the people working for you are none the less people and minimum wage and a discount on clothes u can still not barely afford is not a good deal for the cons you have to accept at the job

review_pros: nice work environment, friendly staff
review_cons: no training, very few hours
review_advice_mgmt: Give more feedback and evaluations of employees

review_pros: It was a fun work environment.
review_cons: Rude store management.  The room spray made me sick.
review_advice_mgmt: Be nice, but fair.  It's that simple.

review_pros: excellent social crowd; very successful people working there
review_cons: limited responsibilities; scheduling issues with managers
review_advice_mgmt: I think the managers could be more willing to learn the schedules of each individual employee. Otherwise, the leadership role is amazing.

review_pros: It was a great job while in college because of the flexible schedule and fun atmosphere.  All employees were college students
review_cons: Frequent turnover, lack of quality management, many people played favorites, difficult to get enough hours because of company policy and outlook.
review_advice_mgmt: Promote equality within the workplace.

review_title: A job with a fair share of responsibility, but little in the way of preparation for a long-term career.
review_pros: Dress code is very casual, as is the atmosphere.  The campus is new and beautiful, but the "cool" image portrayed through the constant techno music and razor scooters masks the exploitation of entry-level workers and their demanding hours.  The cafeteria has a wide selection of good food, and there is a nice-sized gym on campus.
review_cons:
The career development is "Abercrombie-centric".  There is little in the way of preparation for a career outside of the company.  Skills developed are narrowly focused on the job an employee is currently in.  Mentors can be found but are informal.  Many decisions are made sporadically and with little consideration of long-term impacts, leading to a pattern of rapid back-and-forth strategic decisions.

The CEO is extremely eccentric and some of the most basic decisions (apparel patterns, markdown timing, etc.) must pass through him.  The decision making and control within the company is heavily contained within the CEO role.  If the CEO were to leave, the company will be in dire straits as Mike Jeffries (or just "Mike" as he's known on campus), is involved in nearly every function and leaves little decision making ability or control to his subordinates.
review_advice_mgmt: Let the real you shine through the Abercrombie facade that you have to put on every day.  The clothes and the image and the brand that you have to pretend to love everyday make most people here feel as if they have to fit into a mold and there are few interesting or engaging people.  It is more like a bootcamp than an office in many ways.

review_pros:
i took long breaks without the mangers knowing
time and a half on holidays
review_cons: no hours no hours and no hours
review_advice_mgmt: stop hiring people

review_pros: It was an easy and very laid back job. I was told to just "look like I was working" while standing around talking to co-workers. Basically, most of the employees are paid to stand around and look pretty while folding and refolding clothes.
review_cons: The pay is actually awful and they are extremely critical of appearance, especially when management was expecting a visit from upper management.
review_advice_mgmt: A pay increase would make a lot of sense considering the fact that the company is so picky and choosy when it comes to who they hire. If a position is going to be called a "model" position, compensate accordingly.

review_title: Fun place to work if you're only looking for pocket change.
review_pros: 30% discount, which is great because they pretty much require you to wear their clothes. Also, 50% on new collection items.
review_cons: You can't really grow with abercrombie and fitch. Not unless you havr graduated from college. Other than that, you're stuck as a Model, or Impact.
review_advice_mgmt: Change up the play list.. a lot of customers stray away from the store because of it's ridiculous play list.

review_pros:
The people  you meet
Good for high school students with no real need for money
review_cons:
the rules
no hours
they hire to many employess
review_advice_mgmt: its a fun place to work if you have hours to work

review_pros:
Fun environment to work in.
Discounts on clothing.
review_cons:
Low pay and it's hard to get an increase even when you are one of their "best" salespeople.
There is a lot of favoritism within the actual stores.
Not the most understanding when your personal life conflicts with your working.
Required "image" (looks are definitely taken into consideration when it comes to working in the store; if you are overweight and unattractive you will be working in back of the store...)
review_advice_mgmt:
Reward employees when they work hard with promotions or increases in wage.
Don't overlook the people who work in your stores because they represent you and if they don't like working there its not good.

review_title: Pros and Cons, just like any job
review_pros: As soon as you join the company, you are given an amount of ownership over your business. It is exciting to have a lot responsibility.
review_cons: The hours are long, which isn't uncommon in the apparel retail industry.  What is most dissatisfying about the job is that occasionally you feel forced to follow direction from the top even with you know the direction are going in isn't the right direction.  It isn't satisfying to feel as if your time and hard work is being wasted.
review_advice_mgmt: Listen to your employees and try to make the correct business decisions despite the recommendation from the top.  Don't take your business in a direction that will waste your employees time and burn them out when you know you're going in the wrong direction, but are going there just to appease the top management.

review_pros: The atmosphere of the workplace is comfortable and its a very relaxed job expectation.  The discount helps also because their clothes can be expensive.
review_cons: The work shifts are unpredictable and because they hire new employees often, you do not get many work shifts either.
review_advice_mgmt: I would recommend they learn how to prioritize and get their employees motivated to work harder and at a faster pace.

review_pros: Great benefits.  Good job out of college. Fun place to work.  Flexible with vacation and personal time.  A great opportunity to meet people.
review_cons: Be ready to wait years before a promotion.  Terrible pay for the a position that requires a degree.  Terrible pay increases.  Six percent after one year?  80 bucks more a month?  Thanks you just paid my gas for two weeks...retail hours can be rough.
review_advice_mgmt: Provide feedback.  Good or bad.  Offer incentives for performance!  Pay us what we deserve.  Better pay would keep the best managers where you need them.

review_pros: 1. workiing with great looking and outgoing people 2. the environment is very chill and lay back 3. move up easily within the company
review_cons: 1. you have to be able to stand 9hrs / day. 2. Salary is not high (hr wages) no commission.
review_advice_mgmt: It is  much easier if you have a group of good workers when you work there. training associates is critical

review_pros:
- Above average compensation
- Fun people to work with
- Interesting atmosphere to work in
- Decent discounts from time to time
review_cons:
- Drama filled environment
- Employer doesn't care too much about employees
- Long hours 
- Hard to balance work and personal life
review_advice_mgmt: Take some initiative to care about employees, offer better benefits packages and discounts, don't fire employees left, right and center

review_pros: You get to work in a very fun place everyday with people that are fun and around your age.  It is very laid back and can be fun at times.
review_cons: I thought that I would just take this job while i looked for another job- that didn't happen.  Hence I'm still there.  I am currently looking for a new job because I am sick of the empty promises of promotions and the promotions benefit the company not the manager.
review_advice_mgmt: Do not call them promotions if you are simply just filling a void at another store.  Telling us, the managers, that this is a great opportunity is over played.

review_pros: Co-workers are awesome, culture is fun, gym is great. The people are really nice. The interview process was pretty low key as well.
review_cons: Not a lot of preparation for other careers, business school discouraged, the hours are as long as consulting hours, but the pay is not as good.
review_advice_mgmt: I think overall the company is doing a good job. I think some people have pointed out that they are doing the same thing they were ten years ago. That is true. The styles that are popular now are a bit cleaner. See Lacoste/Ralph Lauren.

review_pros: You get to make your own schedule. Finding someone to cover your shift is very easy. The job overall is very flexible.
review_cons: You only make minimum wage. Due to the large number of hourly employees you usually only get one or two shifts a week.
review_advice_mgmt: I think the leadership at Abercrombie & Fitch is average. The managers are young so they usually don't have that much experience but I think they are good managers.

review_pros: flexibilty in creating your own schedule...can create your own schedule at home online, 15 minutes grace period.
review_cons: no benefits,  only 6 hours shifts, 45 minutes lunch break..no break room
review_advice_mgmt: no comment

review_title: A decent place to work for gas money when you get your first car.
review_pros: Uniform way of doing things throughout the company; transferring from one store to another is a pretty smooth transition.  Tried & true methods of doing things.  Easy work and flexible hours because there are so many employees.  Most employees (and people in higher positions) are relatively young, which makes for a good social environment and a relaxed relationship with your boss.
review_cons: Minimum wage.  The uniformity of the company eventually begins to feel robotic.  The discounts aren't as high as you would think, and they only apply to a few items in the store, and only certain colors of those items.  Managers tend to move in and out in a revolving door kind of way, and the fact that they're so young can be a plus, but in some cases, you end up with a really immature, passive-aggressive, or arrogant-in-an-adolescent-way boss.  You're supposed to do things that make you feel uncomfortable around the customers (use cheesy taglines like "Hey, we've got the coolest jeans!  Check them out!" or explain to them that most of the items on display aren't actually carried by the store).  The music is really annoying and loud and plays in a 10-15 song loop, which sounds insignificant, but listening to it for 6 hours on end at the absurd volume it plays genuinely sours your work experience.
review_advice_mgmt: I just wish we weren't always responsible for calling people to cover our shifts because it's much easier for other employees to turn us down than to turn down a request from the manager, so the process takes much longer.  Other than that, you guys did pretty well.

review_pros: Casual work enviorment, fun place to be motivting
review_cons: Low pay hard work promotions based on looks
review_advice_mgmt: Give good managers and better incentive to keep doing a good job

review_pros: the discount. you can have any days off that you want, really. the managers are usually very young. You also get to work with attractive people.
review_cons: They are extremely superficial and do not recognize the abilities of their staff. I have worked for the company for nearly six years, and now that I have a college degree they will not promote me to assistant manager position because i do not apparently fit their "look policy". Bad company reputation.
review_advice_mgmt: You throw away many good employees. Too much recruiting efforts. The most valuable people in your company are the ones who have dedicated all of their time.  Train your staff better and focus on customer service or you will surely see a freeze in growth eventually.

review_pros: Generally speaking, coworkers are pretty fun. Discount on clothes is "OK", things like music are always changing... Nothing too great
review_cons: Discount is only on full price items, at their store. Free clothes for modelling position are ridiculous and always way too small. Customers are usually rude... Basically there for looks. You could do a good job with any task and usually no one will even notice. But if you do something wrong, etc, they cut your hours.
review_advice_mgmt: Treat employees as people, not as numbers. Reward good behavior if you're going to punish for bad behavior. Understand sometimes people get sick and cannot find someone to cover.

review_pros: discount on clothes, you represent a certain image for the company, other young people to work with can make it fun.
review_cons: the perfume smell gives a definite headache, job is boring, lots of folding clothes for endless hours, have to spend a lot of money to buy the clothes
review_advice_mgmt: don't make minimum wage employees spend so much to buy "in trend" and matching clothes. Theyre spending practically their whole meager paycheck.

review_title: Reputable, but oblivious to the big-picture.
review_pros:
Very reputable company in the corporate retail world.
High level of responsibility early on in your career.
Keeps you young!
review_cons:
No work/llfe balance encouraged.
Senior management is too social with lower-level employees, leading many employees to cry "favortism" when promo-time comes around.
Likely to burn out quickly.
review_advice_mgmt: Respect your employees and encourage them to balance their work with their personal life - too many people burn out too quickly at this company.

review_pros: The best thing about this company is that you don't have to come to work professionally dressed everyday. You work with great looking people everyday and the benefits are pretty decent. I can say you do learn a lot of business skills and other survival tactics in terms of running a business. After a year or two, you'll prob be efficient in retail work and lingo.
review_cons: Promotions are a joke, you would think they happened based on your work but it's pretty much the same way we hire our models, by looks or how close you are to the DM. It's almost like a trap, they try to suck you in to stay almost making you feels it's a privelage to stay but it's not at all lol. You get paid ish for the amount of responsibilities you have to carry and they require a degree? You have to be kidding me. It's a good job to start paying your school loans back but not a smart career choice.
review_advice_mgmt: Hmmm, where do I start? Well first off the home office department has no clue what's really going on in stores so they base the business off a fake replica store to determine the number of hours given to run the business. Step into the store for a whole day and observe what is really going on. They expect the standard of the store to stay damn near perfect with just three people hahaha. Also, please be specific on what your look policy is cause this causes a problem between models and managers. Oh and promote on actual performance not who knows who and who looks like what. That's how your business will run properly.

review_pros: There were hardly any pros to working at hollister. I met some nice people but other than that nothing.  The discount is awful.
review_cons:
There were a lot of downsides. The management was a joke. My store manager had a four year degree in physical therapy and some how they figured he would be able to run a retail store.
Lots of dumb jobs, always getting yelled at.
review_advice_mgmt: Don't run a retail store just because you can't find a job in your field of study. Only do it because you like it.

review_title: Laid back job...but if you want competitive pay, look somewhere else!
review_pros: Flexible Scheduling, Fast advancement with a four year degree, relaxed environment, relatively easy job
review_cons: Pay is not competitive, raises are rarely offered, the company is doing a lot of cutbacks, profits are down, not the most professional environment, CEO seems greedy, high turnover rate
review_advice_mgmt: Offer more competitive pay

review_pros: The atmosphere is great and there were tons of people that made the job fun. The managers I worked with were some of the funnest and most engaging Ive worked with in retail yet. Very fun.
review_cons: The recruiting was not a fun aspect of the job at all. The tag lines got old very fast and they didnt do a good job of training us.
review_advice_mgmt: I understand what the company is going for and the type of crowd they are aiming for but more needs to be done to drive people into the stores.

review_title: its fun at first, but then things start to change
review_pros: the people you work with are always fun and friendly....i guess the discount
review_cons: way too much work to be done in allotted shift time. if you work full time you have no social life. always get stuck working over 40hrs/week. no set schedule...constantly changes. pay is higher at other retail management postions.
review_advice_mgmt: Pay us more....give us more hours....

review_pros:
Discount
Good job for college students
Friendship with other workers
Fun atmoshpere
Opportunity to transfer
Experience for future positions inside and outside of retail
review_cons:
Uncomfortable communication between management and associates
Strict rules such as no color nail polish
Bad management at all levels of the organization
review_advice_mgmt: CHANGE

review_title: Frustrating from a financial point of view
review_pros:
Good benefits and decent compensation compared to other companies in area
Young and energetic company, fast paced and high intensity
Good place to launch career
review_cons:
Terrible work / life balance
Too much priority towards product 
No standard way of evaluating employees and little room for growth in finanial depts.
review_advice_mgmt: During tough economic times, more importance needs to be placed on financial decisions, rather than basing everything on the product.

review_pros: It would seem to be a cool place to work directly out of college, due to the young average age of the employees there.
review_cons: it is like a boot camp - techno music playing on a loop, old outdated systems that you use at work, loooooooong hours and no work//life balance.
review_advice_mgmt: stop being such a cult that only does what the almighty mike jefferies tells it to do. work on balance for employees

review_pros:
The scheduling is very flexible (during the summer months), they were always open to rescheduling if you had something important or just needed a day off.
30% discount on clothes and 50% off your first pair of jeans, shirts, etc.
Socializing seemed to be a popular theme so it helps if you like to talk.
review_cons:
Summer job, once fall started I was stuck working all the shifts and my part time job turned into a full time job. 
Some managers were rude and impatient and most of them just stood around talking to each other and not the rest of the employees.
Often asked to (in my opinion) pester the customers, always walking up to them and making sure "they're finding everything okay" even if I just asked them if I could help them find anything.
review_advice_mgmt:
A majority of customers don't want to be followed around, they just want to shop.
Managers need to pay more attention to the sales associates.

review_pros: The benefits are pretty decent. The discount on clothes was ok. You got to wear shorts and flip-flops to work.
review_cons: The pay is awful. If you work over 40 hours, you get "half-pay" which basically cuts your hourly rate in half. You work for less than what the cashiers make. However, it's impossible not to work under 50 hours, since most of the stores are very under-staffed and you have to do the tasks of several other people. Working the holidays was horrible. I would get there at 4 pm and not leave until 8 am the following morning, because the store was a mess, which was because the store was so understaffed that there were not enough employees to maintain it during the day! Oh, and the "raises" were terrible. After working there for 8 months, I got a 24-cent raise.
review_advice_mgmt: Increase the starting pay for managers. Increase raises to an acceptable level. Realize that the managers are people, not robots.

review_pros:
Good Benefits including health care
two weeks paid vacation
easy job with not much thinking involved
work with people your own age
review_cons:
no praise given when a good job is done
all they care about is how good looking people are
dramafest
nothing is ever good enough
upper management gives false hope to managers when it comes to advancement
terrible pay
review_advice_mgmt: if you want only good looking people to work there you may want to offer some incentive. minimum wage is not going to get you hot, older looking males and females.

review_title: Only for those who look good . . .
review_pros:
The music is good.
The discount on clothing is decent.
Easy to get time off if management likes you.
Overall, the job is easy.
review_cons:
The starting pay is very low and does not increase much.
Hiring is solely based upon looks, not ability.
There is not much room for growth.
review_advice_mgmt: Although A&F has an image to maintain, the idealistic looks of people you search for is unfair. People should be rewarded for their accomplishments, not how good they look in the merchandise.

review_title: It's not worth it in the long run
review_pros: Depending on the store you work at, Abercrombie can be a really fun place to work. Especially if you are young.  A good staff is key.  If you enjoy your team you will enjoy your job
review_cons: There is very little advancement opportunities.  Senior management shows very little respect for store employees.  The company is micromanaged and shows little concern for you. Everyone is replaceable.
review_advice_mgmt: There needs to be more respect for the front-line workers.  Good looks and dress code do not make people want to shop at A&F.  I loved working there when there was more freedom to be an individual.

review_pros: The atmosphere is fun and I meet some of my closest friends here, it's a good starting point to learn about managing employees.
review_cons: I basically had no life working here, over time was a given and I wasn't even paid time and a half for extra hours...I was paid half-pay instead!
review_advice_mgmt: Value your employee's balance between life and work, and understand that hiring quality employees will take you further in the long run than hiring hot ones.

review_pros: a way to get away from nightlife  and keep you from being bored at home.
review_cons: employee hours aren't given out equally.
review_advice_mgmt: I would like to advise the management to pursue employees whether they would be interested in having a career in the company.  If its really equal opportunity then they should have a program where part-time employees have the options for advancement or not. Promotion perhaps?

review_title: If you need a job badly, don't come here
review_pros: Easy going job as long as you consistently work. Represent the brand, present the clothes, and assist all customers. Pretty simple since hours are based on appearance, work capability, and how liked you are by the management team.
review_cons: Bias of hours toward employees based on appearance. Whoever is chosen as the few to represent the appearance of the store receive a majority of the hours.
review_advice_mgmt: Learn to work with the associates, not stress them out

review_pros:
Wonderful place to work while in HS. If you don't have bills to pay and just need some extra weekend spending money or want to use the clothing discount, it's a great opportunity.

Once you apply, if you get asked for an interview you basically have the job. Interviews are a joke - They already know who they want to hire or not, usually based on first impression of your appearance. You have to really be an idiot not to pass the interview. They even asked me what kind of vegetable I would be. If you've got the looks and you purposely dress in head-to-toe HCO style, you've got the job.

Depending on your store, work can be really, really fun. Many managers treat associates more like friends due to closeness in age. If you're a favorite, you can get away with a lot. Personally, I loved the music, didn't mind the volume, love the scents and the clothes, so I didn't totally hate the time I had to spend there everyday.

My store actually was run well by the managers. It was important to get things done and not slack around too much (or at least multi-task and only talk to friends if you could work at the same time), which led to not too much drama or gossip, which I've heard about at some stores. I think that ultimately, your experience depends on your management.

There is a small discount (I think 15%), not for use on clearance items. You also have AAA's, which are specific discounted clothes chosen by corporate that are new. They want you to buy them in order to display "the right image" and to promote customers to buy the items. AAA's are usually more expensive items, so it's nice to get the discount once every few months. My store was not at all pushy about buying AAA's.

This is the perfect job if you aren't concerned about making a lot of money, don't need a lot of hours, and want a very easy, laid-back job where you can make friends.
review_cons:
If you are someone who doesn't like loud, LOUD music, don't even bother. Also, if you can't deal with listening to the same 20-30 songs on rotation for a month or two.

There is A LOT of favoritism, which can work out great or terribly for you. If you aren't someone with a very outgoing personality, don't go for model position (choose Impact) - You will feel ignored and will most likely spend all of your shifts standing at a table in a room alone.

Pushy taglines get old and usually are really awkward phrases. "Cashwrap" (cash register) can get irritating when the managers hound you about tags. The stores get secret shopped often, so you have to awkwardly harass shoppers in case they may be a secret shopper (for example, using the tagline "Have you checked out our fragrances?" when the customer is currently purchasing five fragrances. You will get yelled at for not using the tag, so just get used to customers looking at you like you're an idiot).

Speaking of idiots, the employees are not always the most competent, including managers. The store is very, very looks-based and almost all employees are in high school. Again, if you're young and just want to have fun, that can actually be a pro to have a not-so-serious job.

If you need a fast-paced job that keeps you busy, this isn't for you. Many days you will find yourself in a room for five hours, re-folding the same jeans over and over. I often had to LITERALLY refold the same shirts countless times just for something to do. Some days I would actually be excited to see a customer carelessly screw up the wall of jeans, 'cause I would finally have something to do after 2 hours of faking it.

Do NOT expect to move up professionally here. Pay is minimum wage, as far as I know there are no raises for associates. Hours are terrible, I had great availability and was one of the few lucky employees to get about 16 - 20 hours a week!

All associates are part time. Only managers can work full time, and you must have a college degree to be a manager (actual degree does not specifically matter - I had managers with business, political science, etc). However, managers work their butts off and tend to have no lives.
review_advice_mgmt: Given that this is a high school oriented store with high school employees, it's basically run the way it should be. I would however highly suggest raise opportunities for associates who are devoted and work many hours (myself being an example, I worked usually every day of the week and covered many shifts with no complaint). I quit this job for a better paying one, but wished I could have stayed. I was one of few truly hard workers there at the time. Employees like these should have incentive to continue working hard for the benefit of the company. I also would suggest programs and encouragement for employees approaching college or college graduation to be prepared and trained for management. Using motivation and the right incentives, I could see HCO easily convincing employees entering college to go for a business/management degree, and move up upon graduation. However this would probably have to come with a nice raise too for sticking with the company for four years as well as being promoted. I don't know specifically what managers made, but I recall mine making comments about barely paying their bills. I think that if HCO developed programs and opportunities for growth, they could get rid of the negative reputation caused by their high turn over rates.

review_pros: Great Benefits, great way to increase self sufficiency and independence, 30 - 40% discount on clothing, significant management training program.
review_cons: Overtime pay is half time not time and a half, upper management beyond store level is insignificant, pay increases are far and few, no commission or bonuses, mandatory management schedule with minimal flexibility, hiring standards based solely on appearance.
review_advice_mgmt: Great opportunity to enhance personal management skills and philosophy. Amazing MIT program that signficantly strengthens administrative skills. However, do not get sucked into the hype and appearance policy.

review_pros: Music, great people to work with, flexible scheduling
review_cons: Bad pay, the average time span of an employee is 6 months and either you quit or in it for the long haul.
review_advice_mgmt: The company needs to care more for its associates. Times have changed and working for the store is no longer fun and exciting.

review_pros: Abercrombie & Fitch is a good place to work if you like a competitive, energetic enviroment.  Not a lot of time is spent sitting down or doing paperwork, it is mostly interractions with co-workers, subbordinates and cutstomers.
review_cons: The biggest downside is the amount of work managers are expected to do but given a salary that is less than most retailers will offer for managers.
review_advice_mgmt: If you are looking to apply for A&F, show yourself as a fun, energetic individual who is hard working and will go to any lengths to get the job done.  Since most of your job will be interracting with others, be ready to provide examples of how you have shown yourself as both a leader and a team player in the past.

review_title: Decent job if you know what it entails
review_pros: Easy to work here, it is just folding clothes, putting clothes back, arranging displays and other things of the like.
review_cons: it's pretty boring, has loud music that gets annoying, taglines are cheesy, and it's generally just a bit cheesy overall.
review_advice_mgmt: Ease off on the taglines, allow people to work different areas at all times in order to keep you on your toes and interested.

review_pros:
The pay for a recently graduated college student with little or no experience is "okay"
There is a high turnover rate, so opportunity to get promoted is high (Mainly if willing to relocate)
review_cons:
Not all Hollister's will have the same experience. As with any employer, it depends largely on your supervisors/ co-workers. My experience consisted largely off a Store Manager, with decent skills in running the business herself (with the exception of scheduling!) giving little, if any, coaching to its MIT's. Also, feedback was non-existent, except for the petty complaints to the high-school associates--only rarely hearing of myself, but hearing about rants talking of how all of the other MIT's were completely incompetent, greatly undermining their authority.

HOURS ARE RIDICULOUS!!!! 
You have to come in far beyond hours (especially if you are a visual manager- 6AM) and your closing will be there until at least 11PM, minimum, later if your a high volume store.
review_advice_mgmt:
It depends largely on the person. 
Please!.. If you hate your job, don't take it out on your subordinates.

review_title: Abercrombie just was a dissatisfying summer job, overall
review_pros: Your coworkers are fun and nice and its super easy to take time off
review_cons: they overhire, which results in a contest of whoever is the prettiest/outgoing is the one who will get the most hours. The manager who hires you will probably rush through the orientation..when you ask for help they seem sort of irritated. But, they were mostly nice, i would say that you should take it if you just want something to do over the summer, but you shouldn't depend on it being your main job, since they only usually ask for like 2 shifts a week.
review_advice_mgmt: be more patient with newcomers

review_title: great first job out of college
review_pros: good energy and enthusiasm from the people you work with as well as upper management; outgoing people to work with
review_cons: do the same basic tasks every single day; do a lot of work that the associates are hired to do
review_advice_mgmt: should make sure that each manager gets more performance evaluations; give more credit for the work that the managers do

review_pros: when working at abercrombie and fitch, i made some life long friends. still talk to all of them today. the clothes used to be amazing, but now there is nothing that makes them special.
review_cons: there were weeks where we would all work up to 100 hours in one week. the expectation was very high
review_advice_mgmt: you can make a lot more money working somewhere esle, often double. although you will learn a lot about visual merchandising.

review_pros: higher pay rate than pti, full time benefits, very consistent hours, friendly co-workers, can teach you very good time management (you need to be efficient)
review_cons: a lot of responsibility to maintain the stockroom, stressful during holidays, limited positions open (one per store, and not in every store)
review_advice_mgmt: you do not always need to go "directly" by the book, what the guidelines say might not work best for everyone...hear out your full time stocks, they might have a well laid plan.

review_title: This is, at best, a temporary and severely under-paid job that rapidly has one yearning for a real one.
review_pros:
[I actually worked for Hollister, not A&F, but they are under the same umbrella. Glassdoor.com staff, please change the company name to "Hollister, Co." instead of "Abercrombie & Fitch"]

Entry level management position with low requirements (any bachelor's degree will suffice).
Management experience (although of limited scope) and management training (although of poor quality).
Fun coworkers in your own age group (20-30 years of age).
Flexibility in terms of location with great re-location opportunities.
International opportunities (although few and hard to come by).
Acceptable first job right out of college.
review_cons:
**Don't expect to learn anything of actual value while working here. The job requires a bachelor's degree but don't let that fool you. A monkey could do this job. If you can read a recipe to bake a cake then you can also be a manager here -  all you have to do is be able to follow instructions. Independent/critical/innovative/creative thinking is neither required nor encouraged.
**Obnoxious work environment plagued by the following: loud music just barely within OSHA standards, dusty and heavily scented air, and a dark and insufficiently lit work environment.
**Exploitation of workers. The company actively endorses high turnover since the CEO Mike Jeffries consistently wants "fresh faces" in the stores. This policy quite likely stems from the corporate realization that it is the only way to maintain morale (somewhat) as disillusioned workers soon realize that this job is a joke. The high turn-over is a pain in the ass for managers who constantly have to train new people while trying to maintain the operational integrity/efficiency of the store. Not to mention how detrimental the turn-over rate is to creating a positive corporate culture including moral values and loyalty to the company.
**Unethical practices. Cowardly and non-confrontational managers frequently simply omit company pariahs ("undesirables")  from the weekly schedule in the hope that they will quit the job due to not getting any hours (when there is no legal basis upon which to fire the unwanted associate).
**Systematic violation of work rules (break times, hiring practices, and vacation). This is of course not endorsed at the corporate level but nonetheless employed at the local (store) level through an implicit don't-ask/don't-tell understanding.
**Company policies that, although not illegal, certainly are unethical.
**This is a superficial company that only seems to value easily brainwashed employees that happen to have a favorable genetic composition (good looks). This is further emphasized by the complete lack of faith in the hired managers' actual managerial skills. Everyday, a company program prints across that needs to be followed to the tee and every task or assignment needs to be signed-off on. This is to effectively rid managers of any urge to use their own brains. The company attempts to conceal this obvious disempowerment and dumbing down of managers by ascribing an exaggerated importance of meticulous attention to detail (especially visual detail). By keeping people focused on details, they don't see the big picture, I suppose.
**Poor training with a high degree of on-the-fly learning and occasionally unclear job expectations. If you, like myself, were placed in an under-staffed store, you can expect to be required to complete the manager training program at the same time as you are learning to run the business. Needless to say, not much thorough training is ever done. This is later often thrown in your face though phrases such as "lack of dedication" and "laziness" when specific details are accidentally over-looked (due to improper training).
**Corporate atmosphere of threat-over-incentive application of leadership.
**Extremely poor ROI on investment of time, loyalty, and effort into the company - you are either promoted or weeded out over time (and promotions don't grow on trees).
**Non-existent expression (implicit or explicit) of appreciation for employees.
**Extremely high turnover - mostly caused by low job satisfaction.
**Pathetically, customers often get better discounts than the associates working for the company. Yes, you heard right! In addition, associates are restricted from taking advantage of customer discounts. Yet the company stands dumbfounded as to why internal theft is so high.
**External theft (regular shoplifting) is ridiculously high due to farcical loss prevention tactics. Meanwhile, significant time, money, and effort is spent suspecting/vilifying employees for theft and associate discount abuse. This is absolutely ridiculous considering that all an associate has to do to steal is to instruct a friend how to get away with it (since stealing as an employee is considerably more risky/difficult than stealing as a customer).
**I felt sorry for a lot of the employees that had been with the company for a long time without anything to show for it (no raises or added rewards/bonuses/benefits/tokens of appreciation).
**The level of incompetence in management is sometimes mindboggling. Semi-intelligent mangers get out before fully corrupted and turned to the dark side. The remaining mangers (needless to say, NOT the best and the brightest) are the ones competing for advancement.  Exceptions obviously exist, though rare.
**Due to a previous class-action racism law suit in 2004, the company is mandated by court to strive for more ethnic diversity in its hiring practices. While this may be intended as a good thing, it sometimes leads to reverse racism. In addition, the company still hires people with a very narrow and specific physical appearance in mind. In practice, I can't describe it in any other way but to say that the company wants essentially white people with a very slight tough of ethnicity (read: color) - or, described differently, people with diverse ethnic backgrounds but with STRONG caucasian physical characteristics. A few exceptions (read: dark-skinned individuals) are of course thrown in for good measure and to keep up appearances. I am, for example, YET to see any marketing (advertising, primarily found in the store itself) with a dark-skinned model. 
**The main criteria for advancing in the company is... recruiting. That's right. Not people management. Not operational management. Recruiting! Clearly, it is considered so difficult to consistently find enough unsuspecting souls (enough to make up for the high turn-over) to work for this unscrupulous company that they have made this the single most important factor when being considered for a promotion. In other words, in order to achieve long-term success with this company one also need to be adept at selling and deceiving.

In summary, almost all intelligent and conscientious individuals that I have come into contact with through this company thinks that this company is a perverted joke! Most put on a content face solely for the sake of keeping their job. For the great majority, this job is a temporary one in a tough job market. The remaining  people I have come into contact with are frightening examples of what the US work force has to offer: easily brainwashed and manipulated, non-critical, take-orders-like-in-the-military drones with an unsatisfyingly low capacity for critical thinking. 

In order to genuinely appreciate this job one has to be either stupid, desperate, or willing to be misled/deceived.
review_advice_mgmt:
OMG! Where should I begin?
For once, show some appreciation for the employees  - they make up the store, including the store experience. Disgruntled employees make terrible promoters of the brand.
Listen to the employees. They are extensions of customer sentiment and hear more direct customer feedback than HQ ever do.
Employ some REAL management education so that poor management tactics (such as threats, punishment and implicit unethical expectations are replaced by real incentives and rewards).
While internal theft is considered to be high, you wouldn't have to worry about this nearly as much if you gave your associates reasonable discounts (i.e. better-than-the-average-customer discounts).

review_pros: great people, great managers, awesome smell. you walk out smelling good everyday. my manager was great. he let me take time off when i wanted to and let me pick between 15 or 30 min breaks. 30 min break includes punching out but when we're behind hours, we get paid for our 30 min break. love this place
review_cons: horrible pay. minimum wage for every state whether you have experience for not. short hours and they hire a lot of people because it is a diverse store, or so they say. you stand all day in flipflops. theres also a dress code. wear their clothes or something like their brand. if you wear american eagle or hollister, the symbol cannot be seen. natural makeup, no eyeliner. only mascara. hair has to be nice and you have to be pretty and thin to work here.your break goes by really fast. when you're in front and your shift is over at 4, you're force to stay if the person that takes the next shift shows up late.
review_advice_mgmt: i love my managers

review_title: Not a place to work, if you are looking to make real money.
review_pros: social, discount, meet alot of people, flexible
review_cons: exciting at first but then quickly becomes boring and mundane, hours based on looks, they are constantly looking to hire because the turnover rate for managers, models and impacts are extraordinarily high. The pay is less than that of comparable mall retaliers. generally not a good place to take seriously for an occupation.
review_advice_mgmt: Take an unbiased look at the whole company from top down and seriously try to figure out why people don't last with this company.  It won't take long to come to a conclusion!

review_pros: Discount, fun/young atmosphere for young people. Promotions can be expected if you work very hard.  Retail hours, in general, are terrible.
review_cons: It was great to be in management before the company went downhill around 08/09 when the economy got really bad.  They did away with overnight teams to fix the store so management was there late..into the AM hours. The pay is poor for the time/work but you can expect promotions if you do well & work hard within your first year or two.  The values of the company are unfair and discriminatory in hiring practices as far as who gets hired to work within the store as a "model"
review_advice_mgmt: Use fair employment practices!

review_title: The Mother Store Is Better Chose To Work For.
review_pros:
5 hour shifts...but will ask you to stay later if need be.
Co-workers are sympathetic, will give or trade shifts.
review_cons:
Lack of hours, you have to be the favorite with managers to considered given a shift.
Have to buy the clothes within each season and follow the trend. Hard to do if you not there alot to know what clothing you have to wear and if you had a paycheck for it.
If you get sick on the job, can't go home and if you call in kind of hard trying to find ppl to cover for you.
Having to remember where to prep and place close all the time because the salesfloor and folding styles changes every other day.
Best work for Abercombie.
review_advice_mgmt: Need to give everybody a fair share of hours.

review_title: Boring, Repetitive, & The music and smell drive you NUTS
review_pros: Cool and attractive co-workers. Assistant managers that kiss-ass and do an OK job may get promoted to store manager pretty quick. From store manager you can become a district manager within a few years and then a regional manager. All hiring and promoting is from within the company ONLY! Everyone starts as an MIT (manager in training). Awesome benefits package. Pretty Relax environment for the most part. Good Discount (40%)
review_cons: Low hourly pay for a 45hr work week minimum. The tasks are so stupid and repetitive like constanty folding, making sure the manequins look perfect, making sure all the tables/fixtures/trees and props through out the store are perfectly placed as shown on the floor plan map (this requires hours of measuring YES MEASURING WITH A MEASURING TAPE, all of the fixtures to the walls to make sure they match the map measurements). RECRUITING is so awful! You feel bad recruiting young and cool kids because they are going to get paid minimum wage to stand around bored out of their minds and do opening labor such as sweeping/mopping/windexing/vacuuming/and cleaning the bathroom.
review_advice_mgmt: Pay your models more money! Specially your managers that work so damn hard on maintaining an attractive staff of 30+ and maintaining a perfect store.

review_pros: Great as a second job. Really flexible hours. Fun environment when you have diverse, easy-going associates. Very easy work, low demanding. Usually, very laid back management.
review_cons: Extreme favoritism in management, if the manager that does the schedule dislikes you=no hours. Limit of 25 hours per week. 4 hour shifts, sometimes 3 hours. Sometimes we get horrible playlists. Slow days make 4 hour shifts seem like an eternity, because of lack of things to do. No possibility of moving up, unless you have a Bachelor's.
review_advice_mgmt: Hire more competent employees rather than just attractive ones. Lower your intensity, most employees are high school kids and have never had a job. Humble the superiority complex alot of HCo./A&F managers have.

review_title: Good first job for younger crowd
review_pros: Discounts on clothing, interactions with different people daily
review_cons: Rude management, gossipy employees, customers were typically angry at employees, had to buy the clothing, could not wear make up or nail polish, had to wear the brand and certain colors to work so much of the paycheck went back to the store
review_advice_mgmt: Be nicer to employees, don't act as though it is a revolving door (even though it may be)

review_pros:
- incredibly flexible schedule; choose what days and what time you want to work and if you're going on vacation or just want to take a week off, you can do so. Some people work once a week or even once a month
- paid more than minimum wage
- easy tasks (come on, you fold clothes)
- almost everyone is a college student
- they play rap & hip hop music in the stockroom and it doesnt smell heavily of cologne
- rarely or never have to deal with customers
review_cons:
- too lenient. This may be a pro to some people but there are people that come an hour late or some that dont show up at all and never get reprimanded
- it's like going back to high school. People, managers and leads included, gossip about other people in the workplace
- managers & leads play favorites. If they know and like you, they'll give you easy tasks while the other people get told to pull hundreds of clothes at a time.
- can get incredibly boring and repetitive
review_advice_mgmt: This is work not high school

review_title: become friends with the managers to get more hours
review_pros: The main reason I worked here was for the 30% discount. It's easy work: greeting, folding, go backs, register, etc. They rotate you during your shift so you're not doing the same thing the entire time.
review_cons: Pay is minimum wage, but that's typical for part time retail anyways. I barely got any hours, but if you become friends with the managers you'll get more. I HATED that they did call in shifts..you have to avoid making plans for that time because you call in an hour ahead to see whether they need you to come in. Even though it doesn't matter much if you won't be able to make it since they have a huge list of employees to call, it's just annoying. Either give me a shift or don't.
review_advice_mgmt: Stop with the call in shifts. They're pointless.

review_pros: cafeteria was the highlight of the work experience, good indian food once a week, occasional salmon was good too, good salad bar
review_cons: managers, boring work, some parts of the year they have you come to work by 7 even tho you dont have any more work than normal
review_advice_mgmt: congratulations on being there for 3 years, you are in the minority for a reason, the smart ones all got out of there.

review_pros: Discounts on close are 20%
review_cons: Treats  impact employees with no respect. The models get all the respect.
review_advice_mgmt: Learn to teach your managers to treat everyone with equal respect.

review_pros:
You'll meet some pretty chill people.
Good music sometimes
review_cons:
The company doesn't care at ALL about their employees! They really couldn't care less that you are quitting bc they'll just recruit a replacement the next day. I honestly havent the slightest clue as to how this company is still existent  based on the fact that they have a ridiculously high turnover rate and no employee stays long enough to actually learn something. thats why the "models" seem so incompetent when you ask them a question about their merchandise, bc in most cases they havent even been there long enough to know everything they need to about the store and they will quit/be fired before they know half the amount they need to. Management doesn't care about this bc they themselves wont be there for very long. 

and training... its a joke. honestly, 3 hrs long?  how could you possibly learn about a retail store in only 3 hrs?

I gained absolutely nothing from this experience and i wish i had spent my time at another job where i wouldnt be dealing with incompetent, careless, immature people all day.
review_advice_mgmt: I dont even know where to start. maybe... grow up?

review_pros: Employees benefit from discounts on clothing of 30%. There are greater discounts on new season items when they first come in which is around 40% with limitations to buying one item of each type such a one pair of jeans. You know when sales are. Laid back environment in which to work in.
review_cons: Not a job in which you would learn much from besides customer relations.  Few hours.  Get repetitive and you dont learn anything from it.
review_advice_mgmt: The leadership at abercrombie and fitch is not bad to begin with.  Management should however try and be more open to letting employees learn something from their job.

review_pros: You receive percentages off any one of the chain stores ( Hollister, Gilly, Rhuel ect.) . People are really nice to work with. You get to model all of their crap ( If given that position ...)
review_cons: They play favorties alot, Male managers typically hit on female employees, Music is super loud, Prices are out of this world for one scarf or a pair of simple flip flops. Not alot of pay, typically because A&F has so many employees, Therfore giving people less hours. No tips for being cute or helpful ..
review_advice_mgmt: Stop being so self centerted, Make the interviews not full of nothing. Managers in my area were pretty good overall though, If your nice to them, They'll be super to you.

review_title: Loved working there but after four years company abandoned me after asking me to apply for MIT, wow.
review_pros: This is an opportunity to meet new people with similar interests. It also opens the door to experience in retail and perhaps even a taste for fashion. You get a 30% discount on the clothes, and the environment is mostly cheerful. It does depend on the manager that you have.
review_cons: The tag-lines have become a tad ridiculous. People will often glare at you after you say it to them. If you are helping a customer and the "secret shopper" comes in to make sure you are saying the tag lines and doing your job correctly, and you happen to not say the tag-line to this person, you get in trouble. As well, I have worked there for three to four years part-time and recently applied for the MIT position. I interviewed with the DM 3 weeks ago and I have heard nothing. I graduated from College with a major in Business management. I have called the store numerous times and still nothing. I think the DM forgot that they interviewed me.
review_advice_mgmt: Get more organized and be more professional. Hiring based on appearance will sink your company. You need management that can manage not just look good.

review_title: Good Place to Work If You actually Like Buying The Clothes and Chillin at Work
review_pros: Good Discount on Clothes, Nice Managers (If they think you're hot/suck up to them) and never a dull moment at work cause you can hang with your friends instead of having to stalk customers like other stores.
review_cons: Having to maintain a body that "brand positive" , really expensive clothes, constantly making sure everythings folded perfect, really crappy pay (minimum wage) . Work can get lonely if your a greeter.
review_advice_mgmt: For the love of god stop over updating the outlets, and allow some stores to get clean. And raise the damn wages for hotter employees or use system like that

review_pros: Well, the pros were that you get to work with people and make friends.  It is a pretty easy job if you ask me.. folding clothes and putting them back.
review_cons: This job is boring, and it gets tedious folding clothes all the time.  Also, the pay is not very good.
review_advice_mgmt: The leadership is good. THey train you and make sure that you are doing your job unless you get a lazy manager,

review_pros: not much expected, easy way to make some extra money, fun place to work. people are fun, very social environment
review_cons: no real chance to advance if you are in school. fierce stinks, ridiculous standards. some people are stuck up and very rude
review_advice_mgmt: give great associates a fair chance to advance. recognize good work with appropiate pay. take time to train employees properly

review_title: it's okay for a first time job
review_pros:
-good environment
-coworkers were friendly, great first job or job to meet people in
-discount is ok
-willing to work with your schedule
review_cons:
-pay is terrible compared to other part time jobs
-hours are difficult to get when you want them
-modeling portion is over glamorized and harder than many think
-the smell and music drive you insane over time
review_advice_mgmt: have better system in place for finding people to cover shifts instead of calling in.  Also, provide more benefits to workers that actually do work.

review_pros:
- Lots of exposure to C-Level management early.
- Loads of responsibility from the onset.
- Great discounts on clothing.
- Given the opportunity to make a material impact.
- Home Office offers many amazing perks.
review_cons:
- Company is run by one person more or less.
- Politics is the name of the game.
- Very restrictive on promotions, no matter your responsibilities.
review_advice_mgmt: Less gossiping, more listening.  You have a company filled with tons of intelligent people; please consider their suggestions for a change.

review_pros: The people are energetic, fun, personable, and very diverse. You can invite/recruit your friends to work with you. It's a cool, casual and fun environment to work in.
review_cons: Compensation could be better, long hours, the politics played in promotion decisions.,
review_advice_mgmt: Strong case of marketing myopia--A&F struggles to take a step back and look at the big picture in almost every aspect from hiring decisions, to product, to business opportunities, etc.

review_pros: Great co-workers, lots of fun, laid back, flrxible hours.
review_cons: low wages, not too much room top grow.
review_advice_mgmt: reward good work ethics and hard workers.

review_pros: discount, fun environment, smells good, friendly people
review_cons: too much turn over, not enough pay
review_advice_mgmt: abercrombie kids should change how they give out employees weekly schedules it's a hassle to go into the store every week to pick up your schedule when sometimes you're not even on the schedule

review_title: Good easy job to make extra money
review_pros:
fun and upbeat atmosphere 
laid back job with lots of chances to socialize with employees your own age
flexible hours
pretty easy work
review_cons:
discriminatory recruiting process
minimum wage pay
few hours given (especially to those deemed unattractive by the manager who makes the schedules)
managers often play favorites
job gets boring and tedious after a while
review_advice_mgmt:
hire based on the merits and skills of an employee -- not merely based on their looks
rewards the employees who actually work and treat it like a job instead of a modeling agency

review_title: fair place to start, not to be in mid career
review_pros: fast paced environment to work, given a lot of responsibility, lot of young people work there, casual dress which is nice
review_cons: long hours, unless you are a merchant you don't get paid like you should, have to wear abercrombie clothes to work
review_advice_mgmt: cuts costs, we waste so much money in so many areas such as salary for upper management, and are merchandise has not changed much is the past years, we need something fresh

review_pros: discount, people are fun to work with
review_cons: bad hours, promotions are not based on performance
review_advice_mgmt: your management team should be based on something other than looks

review_pros: Great Benefits, not much else. Attire is casual. Great if you want to live in Ohio and/or value superficial appearances over comprehensive business knowledge.
review_cons: No accountability of DM's. favoritism runs rampant. Increasing demands are met with decreasing resources. Upper management is out of touch with store level realities. Upper management does not promote critical thinking. Culture is fake. Promotions have little to do with the empirical business successes and directives.
review_advice_mgmt: Don't get sucked in, a successful career path with A&F forces a compromise of character. Don't trust your supervisors to have your best interests in mind.

review_title: Pay is good, company is alright.
review_pros: You don't have to wear Hollister clothes, no annoying loud music and the team I worked with was a lot of fun so it never got boring.
review_cons: The hours are sometimes unpredictable.
review_advice_mgmt: Communication is important, and be clear on scheduling

review_pros: A good job to start and gain experience in the retail business.
review_cons: Low Pay and very tedious and boring
review_advice_mgmt: Management was strong

review_pros: The people were nice. My managers were really cool.
review_cons: Very menial tasks. Music too loud. Dark environment.
review_advice_mgmt: Turn the freaking music down and turn some damn lights on.

review_pros: nice clothes and fun smelled good
review_cons: not good hrs so i leftt
review_advice_mgmt: shouldnt hire on looks like they did with others

review_pros: Great looking people (No fraternization is allowed). The pay is pretty competitive. Benefits are decent. (PPO. 2 weeks of paid vacation. 5 personal days. 3 sick days.)
review_cons: The company is extremely petty. I have personally seen managers succeed not for what they have done, but for how they look physically. They will also tell you that it is not a requirement to wear their clothing; however, this is only so they don't have to pay for you to wear it as a "uniform." Management will often "phase out" managers that no longer physically look like they could grace the precious marketing by labeling them as a "poor performer." Every manager hired has a picture of them taken and it is sent to corporate where the Regional Managers "judge" them on how beautiful they are. Everything is micromanaged by use of a daily checklist that is printed out from corporate every day. The checklist is rarely accurate with how much time it actually gives you vs. hours in the day to complete the daily tasks. This Often results in making you work well beyond the 40 hours a week you are scheduled and usually off the clock. The music is pretty loud, which you do get used to; however, the customer complaints everyday can drive a person crazy. I am also wondering how long it will take for me to develop some sort of lung cancer for all of the cologne I was required to spray in the air.
review_advice_mgmt: Stop the pettiness. The consumer isn't worried about how beautiful the managers are, but the price and quality of the merchandise.

review_pros:
*quick advancemnt (if they like you)
*good work atmosphere
*the people keep work exciting
*Its not rocket science to work there
review_cons:
*pay is horrible for the amount of work and time that is required
*promotions and hiring is based off of looks and not work ethic
review_advice_mgmt: Stop basing everything off of looks. Some people work there for years and never get promoted vs others who are there a few months and you hold on a pedestal

review_title: It had its pro's and con's
review_pros:
Discount on clothes
Smelled good
Good music (although kind of loud)
Informal relationship with managers
review_cons:
People formed cliques and caused drama
Had to work past my shift a lot of times- couldn't leave until everything was done.
They were pretty judgemental on appearance- especially your outfit choices (only certain types of shoes, certain types of jewelry, ONLY Abercrombie clothes- the newest styles, etc)- they werent modest about telling you either.
Really picky about how the displays looked- clothes had to be PERFECTLY folded, and you had to keep redoing them until they were satisfied,
review_advice_mgmt: Its good to be close and have an informal relationship with the workers, but still keep it professional/don't be clicky, etc.

review_pros: Abercrombie provides a fun, relaxed environment for its workers. Because of the large number of employees, it's easy to get time off. Great place to work for students.
review_cons: Not always easy to get hours if managers have their favorites. No room for growth unless you're a college grad. Can feel like a very immature environment if you're not still a teenager.
review_advice_mgmt: Make sure you work to keep the good employees that you have. Though every store has a ton of employees, you really only have a few great ones. Value them. Give them hours. Give them the days off that they request. Don't treat them like they don't know what they're doing.

review_pros: They shcedule many empoyees so that you are never understaffed. There is always a fun atmosphere because the staff is so young.
review_cons: The pay for the position is salaries with overtime. The catch is that you actually get half pay for the overtime. I dont know how this is legal but they do it. On top of that you are scheduled for an automatic 10 hours of overtime every week not even including the time that you end up staying late.
review_advice_mgmt: Figure out the pay. the fall out raqte is unbelieveable because of the pay. Initiate a comission for employees so they can be engaged to sell.

review_pros: They offer good discounts and a lot of times its a fun work environment.
review_cons: In my experience there were issues with poor management.
review_advice_mgmt: Try to stay consistent with policies and procedures. Don't favor employees because you simply like them. Try cross training more employees.

review_pros: I know a lot of people hate the music and the scent, but I love the whole mood that it creates. At my store, at least, everyone is pretty laid back and while it does get busy and hectic in the back sometimes as well as at the register, the general atmosphere is chill and probably my favorite thing about working at A&F.
review_cons: The employee discount is pretty pointless. Other than the 50's, for everything else you would be better off just waiting for the items to go on sale (or even clearance sale)
review_advice_mgmt: In my area, the area manager could really be much more approachable. I enjoy working at my store, but I don't know how advancement would look in the future.

review_title: encrourages personal growth within the company.
review_pros:
*fast paced
*only promote from within
*requires bachelors degree
*full benefits
*fast promotions
*yearly reviews
*store specific goals
*incentives
*discount
*5 day work week
*monthly discussions with upper management about career plans
*relocation package
*stores overseas
*new stores opening each week
*DM company car
*DM company phone
*gas reimbursement
review_cons:
relocation due to promotion
work weekends
non comission
not many extra ways to make extra money
review_advice_mgmt: opportunities to win extra money or trips. better incentives. higher pay=less turnover.

review_title: Good experience for a recent graduate
review_pros: comfortable work outfits, typically fun staff
review_cons: no feedback from senior management on potential growth or promotion opportunities. communication skills between senior management and assistants is slim to none, they say jump, they expect you to answer with "how high?"
review_advice_mgmt: if you really value your managers let them know, dont keep them in the dark when it comes to professional growth

review_title: There are a lot of better companies compared to AF
review_pros: It's a fun environment to work in.  You listen to great music and everyone you work with has personality, so it makes in fun (almost like you're not working)
review_cons:
The pay rate for what you do as a manager is not worth it.  Depending on how much staff you have, you may be screwed, since they are under staffed often at some stores, you will be putting in a lot of time for the same salary.

Any manager above your district manager doesn't really care about what you do or think, just follow the company procedures.  

Rules and laws are not as clearly communicated until there is a lawsuit against the company.

Company is all about looks and not customer service or customer satisfaction.
review_advice_mgmt:
They make a lot of rules without thinking of how that will affect the store.  There's a limit of how many hours your store gets a day and it's flexible depending on sales, so sometimes you have a crapload of people because you have to have them, but other times when you need people to "maintain" the store, there's nobody because it's slow.  

The CEO or RM is always going to visit you and after you clean up the whole store to visual standard, they change their mind and do not show up.  They probably just say that so that you clean up your store to the "A" standard.

review_pros: Some of the best reasons to work for the company would be the opportunity to develop leadership skills while working in a fun, laid-back environment.  Also, most all promotions are done from within, so the opportunity for career advancement is huge.  The benefit package is also pretty good.
review_cons: Some cons would be the turnover rate of part time employees.  This tends to be high and can make running a successful store difficult, especially when you have to consistently train new associates.
review_advice_mgmt: I would like to see more training conferences for managers which are fun, informative, and a great way to meet other store leaders in the region.

review_title: Good for a High School Job
review_pros:
Discount on clothes is pretty good
Decent music (if you are into techno)
Cute co-workers
Smells good throughout the store
review_cons:
Better discount at other places
Hard to get people to cover your shifts if necessary
Can become boring and tedious, especially if you're on clearance
review_advice_mgmt: My experience was okay but I found myself being asked to do tasks that seemed ridiculous (replacing the lights that are 400 degrees while standing on a ladder 15 feet in the air - I should have gotten hazard pay). Don't most malls have maintenance to handle this stuff?

review_pros: It's a relaxed atmosphere, it's not hard work, and generally we get good employee deals on the clothes. It's not overwhelming. Fellow employees are easy to work with and it's easy to switch shifts or get someone to cover for you.
review_cons: Hours are typically unreliable, and hard to come by unless you're favored or if people are willing to give up their shifts. The look policy is strict. Getting scheduled for call-ins is never fun.
review_advice_mgmt: It would be nice if workers were given credit for a job well done, or at least given the better jobs based on past performance.

review_pros: good place to start career.  good place to get experience.  if you can survive as a merchant you can make it anywhere
review_cons: if you are not a favorite you will get put in a holding state and not move up.  hard to get new ideas through all the red tape.  work life balance is not good.
review_advice_mgmt: better training would help everyone.  people there need to respect everyones opinion equally instead of only people that are managers or higher levels

review_pros: Get to work with some awesome fun people who will be great friends.  There is usually one awesome manager at each store who all the part timers adore.  Unfortunately they usually don't stay with the company.
review_cons: Get to witness the fake side of managers who are dying for a promotion at any cost.  There are people in this company who like to point the finger and love to take credit for other people's good work.
review_advice_mgmt: Managers, especially upper level, try to recall what it's like to be a normal human being, before you relied on the program to tell you what to do with every 30 mins of your work day.  Stop being a damn robot.  Ask your part timers who their favorite manager is and why they like working for that person.  Learn something.

review_pros: The discount across all brands, amazing work parties and some of the greatest people you will ever meet by which I mean gorgeous girls if you're a guy and fit guys if you're a girl.
review_cons: Poor management, lack of career progression unless you have a degree, no pay rise for most people and tasteless rivalry between different positions i.e. model and impact specifically. Favouritism among managers.
review_advice_mgmt: Listen to criticism from all associates, lose the favouritism and respect associates as they are the ones that meet targets set by DM's and RM's on your behalf.

review_pros: Fun atmosphere. I'm one of those people that actually enjoy the music and smell. Cute and super chill employees.
review_cons:
Not good pay.
Always asking me to go to work when I'm already scheduled to work a certain amount of hours.
review_advice_mgmt: Don't discriminate on looks.

review_pros: The music is great, the store smells amazing, the clothes are high quality and the styles are great, the forms are perfect and everything is neat! Of course, you make that happen by working there. The people there are so chill and fun to be with, it doesn't feel like work at all. The managers are too busy chatting or ringining up customers on the salesfloor to go into the stockroom to check on you, so you're not micromanaged by the hour and you can pick whenever to go on your break. As impact you get to be on the salesfloor talking to customers as well as doing EUSR and floorsets, which completes your retail experience.
review_cons: The pay sucks but you could be doing a lot worse things with that same pay flipping burgers and trying to get credit cards at other retail hellholes.  As impact you don't have to try as hard to look "abercrombie" as the models, but you still have to be careful as in not wearing the wrong things (no black/purple, no eyeliner, wear only white/navy/gray). However if you as an impact make an effort to dress like models (AAA looks) and you look decent you will be asked to cover the salesfloor when a model bails last minute. In the same store there will be managers who are pretty catty and cold, and tend to have a group of models kissing their ass, but there are always that one or two nice ones that you look up to and you secretly cheer them on and hope they get promoted. You work and go home dog tired, but as long as the managers didn't treat you like crap then you would consider that a good day at work.
review_advice_mgmt: Its okay to hire good looking people but that doesn't mean you should let them act like total douchebags and get away with it. Some models stand around yawning and I have to go ask them to go open up fitting room doors, and all I get is this "whatever fine" look. They need to know that some of us impacts are just as good looking as they are so just because we chose to be more useful as an impact doesn't make us any inferior than they are. Without the impact team and our lead stock the store would just flat out fall apart. Also, to the RMs and DMs, stop promoting the best looking managers just because they are the best looking, promote your second-best-looking manager who actually gets along with all his/her associates and you get a win-win situation.

review_pros: Easy hours, nice coworkers, and discounts.
