review_pros: The job itself is relatively easy and most of the time, managers don't really care what you're doing as long as you are greeting most customers at the door. The pay is OK, but don't expect a raise [I've been there for a while and have gotten nothing].
review_cons: Most of the people that work here [models, PTI & managers] are so dumb that its ridiculous. There is a lot of employee competition to see who can look the best, hookup with the most people, get the most drunk etc. A lot of dumb wannabee stuff happens. Plus, everything needs to be folded with a board and most employees are too incompetent to do it right.
review_advice_mgmt: Stop judging people on their external appearance and then maybe, you'll actually get some qualified employees who can make your company some money...

review_title: Positive experience if you 'drink the kool-aid'
review_pros:
One of the best descriptions I've heard is that if you 'drink the kool-aid' there is tremendous room for growth. Management looks for candidates that are passionate about the A&F brand and believes in the store experience of Fierce cologne, unique music and trendy lighting. Within a year there is the potential to move from MIT to Store Manager. Within another year there is the possibility to move from Store Manager to International SM, Store-Openings Teams, or District Manager. 
Other:
- Benefits package is amongst the best of any company
- Seasonal cash bonuses for sales goals
- Up to 18 days of PTO
review_cons: A&F prides itself as an aspirational lifestyle brand. Consequently there is often an 'exclusive' atmosphere among part-time employees and even among the management team. There is an extremely high turnover rate among all employees seemingly on account of poor hiring decisions within stores, uncommon and often undesirable hours for managers, strenuous operational demands for managers, and often a juvenile 'high-school' attitude that emanates from the majority of 17-24 year old part-time employees. Those most likely to succeed are young-at-heart with the ability to motivate adolescents who are sometimes unreliable and independently willed.

review_title: The best retail company to work for if you have a college degree, but be prepared to move on the dime
review_pros: College degree required. Work with "chill" employees. Easy to work hard
review_cons: Promotions are rare. You must move to make this a career
review_advice_mgmt: Some DM's are amazing, some need to realize they aren't the greatest people whoever walked the planet

review_pros:
Somewhat good employee discount
Flexible hours
Comfortable atmosphere
review_cons:
Managers were arrogant and plain mean
Chose favorites
Looks are everything
review_advice_mgmt: Get off your pedestal. Stop degrading your employees and treat them with a little more respect.

review_title: If you are looking for an easy income, & dont mind an unprofessional atmosphere..
review_pros: Good benefits, easy responsibilities, laid back if you work with good people, casual dress on a daily basis
review_cons: unfair treatment based on relationships & LOOKS, working weekends & nights, shallow hiring process also based on appearance, management plays favorites, high turnover, working holidays
review_advice_mgmt: promote the people who need it, not the people who you think look good in the product.  those people are not the best leaders or management material.

review_title: Put the work in and you'll do great!
review_pros:
-Work for a company that has a very detailed brand image and distinguishable target market
-Learn multiple role and the ins and outs of retail
review_cons:
-Low pay
-Fast pace
-Takes a long time to move up

review_title: It was a good job to have during college with little responsibility.
review_pros: The people and atmosphere is fun and everyone is really outgoing and likes to hang out outside of work.
review_cons: You get few hours and make minimum wadge. Your treated poorly by customers and they are usually uptight and stuck-up.
review_advice_mgmt: To be more professional. The management would tend to act immature and then turn around and aspect you to respect them.

review_pros: Very very flexible schedules, people are generally really nice.
review_cons: Pay is minimum wage; They expect you to go above and beyond with basically no incentive.
review_advice_mgmt: This company makes so much money, pay the part-timers a little bit more and you wouldn't have so much turnaround. Also, on an unrelated note, it's pretty dumb that the Management Training Program requires a bachelor degree.

review_title: loved it there so much fun
review_pros: all employees are so friendly and nice to each other besides some girl drama.
review_cons: not much room for promotion and no raises based on performance
review_advice_mgmt: i understand that you higher a lot of college kids but managers can really pick some lazy and not so smart people. please do better.

review_pros: Discount if you wear the clothes and being able to say that you work/ed at Abercrombie and Fitch.
review_cons: The pay is low, there is no respect from management, hours are only given to favorites, impacters have to do the job of model as well, little to no room to be promoted, very superficial ( hire based on look)
review_advice_mgmt: Increase hourly wage because impacters and model at the end of the day are the ones that keep the store going...not managers, have actual training and not 2 useless videos that you watch during "orientation" and hire for more than a pretty face because no one likes an airhead! And train managers better!

review_pros: You don't have to do anything in the Orlando store in the millennia mall, but greet people.
review_cons: You have to buy their clothes which is worth a pet check.

review_title: No matter where you start, you're in the door so make the best of the opportunity
review_pros: You work at ANF for the reputation and prestige the name brings with it in the retail industry. Make the most of your opportunity through networking and you should be rewarded. Especially after college, it is a great place to start a career in the corporate retail world and serves as amazing training for your next company. Ongoing worldwide expansion over the next 5 years makes this the place to be.
review_cons: Jobs are specialized and most employees are relegated to unique, repetitive, time-intensive tasks, but that's how you learn. To me, it always seems like families and people with babies get promoted faster. I doubt that that is true, though.
review_advice_mgmt: Everyone is so super busy I feel that it is easy to get lost in trying to find that mentor. While managers have a duty to the business, they can't forget their duty to their internal employees.

review_title: Super fun fast paced working environment
review_pros: The atmosphere of the store is awesome. The managers make it easy to allow time off when an employee needs it. You make life long friends, there is a lot of opportunities with in the company for advancement.
review_cons: Treat other employees or associates better compared on their ranking. If a model is a cast off they receive special privileges. Basically it is a company based on looks. If you aren't good looking you won't be able to work there.
review_advice_mgmt: Just continue to do what you do. Make sure everyone is treated fairly and that you continue to build a level of personalism as well as professionalism

review_pros: Fun place to work, with a happy go lucky atmosphere. You will get to meet many new people because they are most always hiring and recruiting. Good place to work if you are new in town and need to meet some new people.
review_cons: Low pay for part time models and impact and generally will not raise your pay unless you become a manager. Loud music the obvious, and sometimes odd hours around holidays.
review_advice_mgmt: Be prepared to deal with people especially part time employees , seems the managers who were not good with people did not last long with the company.

review_pros: The discount is nice, the hours are extremely flexible, and you'll probably work with friends/peers.
review_cons: The managers are too young to have a sense of skills and what it takes to run the store. Although the store looks organized, within employers it is unorganized and there is virtually no training. You basically learn as you go, which personally I don't like.
review_advice_mgmt: The managers are not managing or training properly.

review_title: Really fun, easy, chill place to work!
review_pros:
- employee Triple A's where you get 50% off two tops, one bottom, and one flip flop every time there is a new floor set.
- you'll meet the coolest, most chill people here!
- schedule is really flexible. Everything is done electronically. You can schedule yourself available from this time to this time & have no problem at all.
- you don't have to have a lot of clothes or spend a lot of money on abercrombie clothes to work here
- managers are pretty cool/chill. they acknowledge when you do well. and they're only a little older than you, so they're like your friends.
- people dig that you work at a&f. it boosts your ego and confidence.
- the tasks you have to do are really chill and easy.. no hard work or stress is needed.
review_cons:
- other than the triple A's, all the other things are 30% off, and they're still expensive even after the 30% off.
- customers get better discounts than employees! which is ridiculous. We're the ones that have to wear your clothes, not them..
- your store manager makes the schedule, and if you're not his/her favorite, he/she will barely schedule you. schedules usually suck too. most people only get 1-2 shifts a week.
- call-ins are terrible. you have to call in an hour ahead of your call-in shift to see if they need you to work or not. you can never make permanent plans in case they might need you..
- you only get paid minimum wage.
- i used to get headaches and acne when I first started working there because of the constant cologne sprays (they have a cologne spraying machine) and extremely loud music.


**Overall, it's a chill job if you're in high school/ college student that still lives with your parents and don't need to pay any bills. **
review_advice_mgmt: Models and PTIs should get paid more than minimum wage, especially if they've been in the company for a long time. Managers should get paid more for running back and forth all day. And they only get paid half time for working over 40 hours. Is that even legal? A bachelor's degree shouldn't be a requirement to get the MIT position. A lot of other retail stores only require a high school diploma and they actually pay more too..

review_pros:
working with great, talented people.
Great benefits, and very competitive pay rate.
being involved with the product the whole way through the design process
review_cons:
way too many designers all fighting for the lime light. 
There are too many restrictions on what is "brand right" that its leads to the same product being produced year after year.
review_advice_mgmt: there need to be more of a structure with reviews and feedback. Having a review once a year is not enough to help people excel and grow in the company

review_pros: Well-known and respected brand, extremely professional, interesting work
review_cons: It is hard to rise up because management usually looks outside of the company for top positions
review_advice_mgmt: Promote more from within rather than always hiring from the outside

review_pros: Absolute best job for college students that dont need a big paycheck.
review_cons: Besides being a lead stock (only one position pet store) or a manager (need a bachelors) there is ablosultly no room for improvement. All part-timers get minimum wage and even if a manager wanted to reward you i highly doubt the district manager would approve. Every songle thing has to be approved by district manager and they are really really strict on money and hours even though the store makes a fortune. I wish i got sales compensation cause i have upselled so many times. But the managers at our store are very good with keeping employees happy. Overall it is a very fun pplace to work and easy to get hours cause so many people give away shifts.
review_advice_mgmt: Offer raises, more discounts on AAA's cause it takes three days just to pay off a pair of jeans and shirt to work in not including the rainbow flip flops i had to cut the tag off and anf belt and tshirts. Iand dont hire 150 employees who dont know how to do anything. Just hire a few and treat them well with better pay and more hours. Overall it would save money cause we could get stuff done quicker and better.

review_pros: youthful environment, great social life ambient working place. the opportunity to meet a lot of people. good discount on many of the clothes.
review_cons: not a very great pay, too many people working there and therefore you can not get many shifts, the hours are not that great.
review_advice_mgmt: you should hire a smaller amount of people so that the people who are already there can get more shifts.

review_pros: Flexible hours good job if in school
review_cons:
No hair color
Nail color
No makeup 
Min wage pay 
Don't really care about the employee

review_pros: Good place for small part-time job and sometimes working your way into a manager position.
review_cons: Poor pay (minimum wage) & poor ways of raises given out.

review_title: It was fun but at times very demanding.
review_pros: The discount, fun environment, free uniforms and the fact that you made friends easiy which made time fly by pretty fast
review_cons: Sometimes you would deal with annoying co workers. The playlist would drive you nuts after a while, you hear the same songs for like two months.
review_advice_mgmt: I think you guys are doing a good job but sometimes ya give preferences to those who go t work to fool around

review_title: Fun place to work not very serious.
review_pros: Fun management and coworkers, very easy work.
review_cons: Perfume in the air 24/7 + loud music = severe headaches.
review_advice_mgmt: More hours for models and impact members.

review_pros: You get to work with genuinely cool people and empathetic managers.  It's not meant to be a really intense job so the managers understand that you have other commitments (i.e. school, clubs); scheduling is very lax and it's generally easy to get shift covered when something comes up because of the large employee base.  You also get 30% clothes and gift cards all the time and 50% two tops, a pair of jeans/shorts/a skirt, and a pair of flip flops each time the floorset changes (these are called AAAs. You will learn to love them).
review_cons: When you are a part time worker for Abercrombie, you will make $7.25 an hour without a chance of a raise.
review_advice_mgmt: I genuinely appreciate the movement toward a more diverse employee base and the fact that my managers make sure to instill in all of my coworkers the importance of helping the customer.  Everyone in the store realizes that customer satisfaction is imperative, and I really haven't any idea why the brand has still got a bad rap.

review_pros:
Fun environment
Constant interactions with people
Good atmosphere
Always doing something different
Never too slow
Unique interesting customer base
Popular brand
review_cons:
The low pay
The fact that it is retail makes it a pain during holidays
Many employees 
Having to keep up with the clothing trends.
review_advice_mgmt: Perhaps get to know all of the employees better.  Make all the employees work during closing.  Have more interaction with customers.

review_pros: Great place to network with other college professionals.
review_cons: Low compensation, Scattered hours, Horrible customers, Retail environment.

review_pros: flexible hours, dress pretty, easy going, and relax environment to work in. i would recommend people to give the company a shot.
review_cons: minimun wage. the stores are often too crowded during the busy seasons, and we don't go on proper breaks as planned.
review_advice_mgmt: treat people with respect, and do not think you are better than the rest of the co-workers. other than this, it's all good

review_title: A&F/Hollister is a company modeled around low pay and low retention rates fo all employess.
review_pros: If you have a good store manager, stress is low.
review_cons: The "models", part-timers, gripe about having more hours, and, being 17-20 are essentially kids, looking for every opportunity to not follow directions. Micromanagement and constant check-ins are needed. If you are a clsoing manager, your entire life is define by how well the store looks the next day. Your store manager gets on you @ss if things aren't perfect for opening the next day, you stayed too long to clean up, etc. Additionally, hours can suck 1:30pm to 10:30pm 3-4 days a week plus one mandatory weekend worked (similar hours) means no life. What can you do in entirety before 1:30pm beside breakfast and lunch, or do after 10:30pm when you need to go to sleep for the next day? Managers come and go quickly, noticing the pay does not do justice to the bachelor degree required to be a manger. Therefore, often "promotion" comes from others leaving.
review_advice_mgmt:
Don't let you managers play favorites with associates. It creates a bad atmosphere when 1 "model" gets 20 hours a week and others get 4 in 2 weeks. The ones with a high number of hours are more complacent - don't want to work because their cups hath overflown, plus they feel a time crunch with school (High School or College). You also kill the self-esteem of your employees meaning they will never be future customers, and dissuade others from being customers.
By favoring one model over another (especially when people are new hires) you make it blatanly obvious that the company values LOOKS in its part-timers over anything, or that the NON-FRAT policy isn't in place because AM's and SM's have friends that are part-timers.

review_title: I should have left after a year.
review_pros: Store has a really laid back atmosphere and you can quickly learn everything you need to know about the job in a month or two.
review_cons: If you're a hard worker, you'll be expected to continuously give 110% while the people around you who do nothing but suck up to the store manager get yearly fifty cent raises. In order to move into management, you need a four-year degree but after I received mine and asked about a manager-in-training interview, I was no longer scheduled and never heard anything back.
review_advice_mgmt: There needs to be stronger accountability for results other than just meeting sales numbers. Managers simply hire any pretty face and District Managers hire on how well they like you which usually ends up with that manager recruit leaving in half a year.

review_title: Promotions Based on Looks and Favoritism vs Talent
review_pros: Good healthcare plan and benefits, good coworkers
review_cons:
The company is completely obsessed with how "great looking" you are, and Senior management promotes heavily  (99%) based on looks.  Prettiest girls always got promoted to SM the fastest.  DM often threw temper tantrums.  There were unrealistic expectations for store experience -- upper management demands perfectly board folded, size stickered stacks of clothes and yet we never have enough budget hours to accomplish everything.  You will at times feel like a janitor, as we have to direct the usually teenage models to clean the store before open (1 model can't possibly clean a huge store in the 1 hour before open so the manager usually has to do half of it).

We lost over 200 units a week due to theft (we were a Target store) and yet company refused to give us LP agent to help.  The handicap fitting room didn't even have a lock on it!  People would sneak back there and pop sensors off the clothes and there was nothing we could do about it except give them "great customer service."  What a joke!   You would think they would at least lock up the fragrances but they are out everywhere in a dimly lit environment, ripe for the taking. Yet you will get yelled at for out of control shrink. 

The people can be great, especially other managers, but the models and impacters are oftentimes spoiled high school/college kids who routinely forget to print their schedules and don't show up.  Many of them try to do as little as possible, so it is a constant battle to make them do anything.  Turnover is extremely high, managers quit all the time and so do part-timers.  This is endlessly frustrating because by the time you are able to finally train someone they leave.  And who can blame them -- the beautiful people we are supposed to employ usually can find jobs that pay more than 7.50 an hour.  Managers are underpaid relative to other retail companies.  Also, expect to be inundated with never ending gossip about who is hooking up with who, and endless rumours in general.

Work life balance can be difficult, especially if you are visual manager (and then expect to work 6-4am during floorsets and updates).  I average about 9 hours a day (with 1 hour unpaid break that is mandatory).   Expect to work all holidays and nights (night shift is from 2pm-11pm).  Getting a full weekend off is rare.  This job burns most people out fairly quickly.  The one plus is Abercrombie is a good name on your resume and will open the door to many other retail jobs that pay more.  My co-workers have left for Guess, Louis Vuitton, Henri Bendel, Armani etc.
review_advice_mgmt: District Managers need to be more accountable for their promotion decisions.  Stop promoting girls just because they are hot and flirt with you.  Give us more budget hours to get done what we need to.

review_title: A fun place to work at if you are not lazy and do not mind completing tedious tasks.
review_pros: Great advancement opportunities (I have heard). The work environment allows to really just be yourself and do your job the way you think will get the job done most efficiently.
review_cons: If you do not like the abercrombie and fitch style you will be very unhappy there. You need to accept and take in the culture.
review_advice_mgmt: I believe that Abercrombie and Fitch does a great job in letting their employees know what is expected out of them and why it is so.

review_pros: Dress code- jeans, flip flops, and sweatshirts.  My co-workers and I became good friends and even though now we all went our separate ways we still keep in contact.  Fairly laid back atmosphere.
review_cons: Extremely long hours with extremely poor pay.  My Assistant Manager (who was paid hourly, rather than salaried like I was) got paid more than I did and worked less hours.  Required to recruit all employees (management and associates) off the sales floor, in the mall, and offsite- even though there was a whole recruiting department.
review_advice_mgmt: Increase salaries of the store managers.  Don't have such strict hiring standards (all managers are required to have a 4 year degree).  Have better training materials for MITs.

review_pros: Everyone is really laid back...generally pretty attractive.  Discounts at the stores. Overall it is a pretty good employer.  I enjoyed it.
review_cons: High-school type drama often goes on in the stores.  Management sometimes is involved in the clique-ish type behavior as well.
review_advice_mgmt: I would say the associates should push the recruiting.  Managers can sometimes come off as awkward.  Keep loyal to the brand's intent.

review_title: most of the best years of my life, learned to run a business with a lot of responsibility at a young age, experience!
review_pros:
great people all working towards a common goal
fun environment, fast paced
great experience, growth, opportunity, benefits
review_cons:
long hours
unrealistic expectations at times
review_advice_mgmt: ask for more feedback from the field, restructure some departments to provide more avenues domestically for more store side/HO related positions. reevaluate expectation with measurable objectives to be more consistent company wide and the resources should adapt with the expectation, as well as compensation. create a relocation department with a better system to assist through entire process, possibly regional..

review_pros:
Coworkers were fantastic
Discount was great
Great music although a little loud sometimes
Fun environment to work in, very laid back
review_cons:
Expect minimum wage for compensation
Upper management didn't even know you existed (nor did they care)
Retail customers are the worst

review_pros: Friendly laid back work environment.
review_cons: Overworked underpaid and little recognition for hard work and over time.

review_title: I've stayed with the job for the benefits
review_pros: The atmosphere is super fun and everyone is very outgoing and energetic. The company also offers great benefits and 401k.
review_cons: Promotions are given not based on merit, but on who they like the most. Their biggest focus is on hiring beautiful people.
review_advice_mgmt: Brown-nosing, being energetic and loud, and recruiting is how you get noticed.

review_title: Bad hours, bad pay, good benefits
review_pros: Young, energetic atmosphere. Good health benefits and vacation time.
review_cons: terrible hours, no social life due to working nights/weekends. terrible pay. company is rapidly closing stores in the U.S. so no real upward mobility unless you're willing to go overseas.
review_advice_mgmt: pay more.

review_pros: the cool people and the discount is pretty much the only thing worth working there for
review_cons: the hours and the fact that upper management doesnt care about employees at all
review_advice_mgmt: try and care about employees more because employees who are valued work better and contribute the company more

review_pros:
As long as you're pretty you'll have no problem getting the job.....(shrugs shoulders...whatevsss brah)

A majority of the clientele is eye candy.

Abercrombie & Fitch has a drug test policy. But they literally drug test zero percent of their employees.

The music is so loud it makes it easier to ignore the customers.
review_cons:
8.5 decibels. 8 hours a day. 40 hours a week. The hell that is my life. (Most jobs that dish out that much noise on a daily basis hand out ear plugs)

Horrible hours. With an ever rotating carousel of scheduling changes, which are never the same from week to week, expect to have zero life. 

When they hire you, they dodge as many questions about salary as possible. When I point blank asked about the meager wages (22,000 a year after taxes). I was told that my hiring was merely a training position, and that in 7 weeks or however long their cult course M.I.T. Program training takes, I would receive a promotion. And promotion I did receive. Upon my completion of the training, they went into the staff listings on the company computer network, and clicked the little tab by my name. They changed "Position Listing" from M.I.T. to People Manager. With zero percent wage increase as I was led to believe. The quintessential "Gold Star" finger to the "we literally only hire 23 years olds fresh out of college with their degrees, who literally don't know any better than to take these "you're beautiful", "you're better than everyone else" uppper management strokes their egos with, all the while A&F is just diddling them around. Complaining about high management turnover to their underpaid employees, whilst simultaneously saving millions of dollars a year on HIGH MANAGEMENT TURNOVER.... For some reason the whole Catholic Priest tragedy keeps coming to mind for an analogy.....weird.
review_advice_mgmt: Considering the fact that Mike Jeffries dumped all his A&F stock on December 23rd, right before the earnings report crash in January...... I'm fairly certain that they don't give a (insert expletive).

review_title: The models and impact workers are great, however, management does not make an effort in being friends.
review_pros: I really enjoyed working with my co workers. They were very friendly and kind. They are great easy going people.
review_cons: At times I felt that I was under appreciated. I think they need to understand that everyone else has other jobs.
review_advice_mgmt: Become friends with the employees.

review_pros:
Aber has on of the best M.I.T. training in the business.  It is an excellent program that allows you time to lear how to run the business.
There is something ALWAYS going on, something to do, something to fix, someone to train, etc
Always looking to advance your position. I got my own store after being a M.I.T for 3 months, and 4 months as an Assistant Store Manager.
review_cons: You are required to recruit young, attractive, aspirational, and meaningful candidates for possible employment.  It can be extremely difficult to find good looking, and aspirational people with a college degree that want to work with a small salary.
review_advice_mgmt: I don't have advice for them.  I was once in their shoes.  Anything I say, I am sure they already know.  I would say, don't let work take over your lives.  Make sure you make time for you.

review_title: It was a nice entry level place to work and learn basic management skills IF you can handle the music...
review_pros: Relaxed environment with a very easy to follow training program. Once employed you are taken under the "wing" of the store manager who week-by-week helps you learn the different concepts that the company wants you to "master" in order to be named an official Assistant Manager
review_cons: The biggest downside for me was the workplace environment. You work/manage almost all high-school and college age kids who can be quite immature and cause you to have to deal with lots of immaturity. Also, the atmosphere of the retail store can be extremely annoying as their is mandatory non-stop music blaring on repeat.
review_advice_mgmt: I would recommend that the management seriously looks into the mandatory music that is played 24/7 within the store and the sound level it is played.

review_title: Abercrombie lures you in with the promise of promotions from within etc.. but they are not jobs you want.
review_pros:
Good benefits
Casual atmosphere
Promote from within
Very easy job
Other retailers value the training they give you during your MIT program
review_cons:
Long hours, never get out when you are supposed to
Incompetent employees
DM who tried to pit managers against each other
review_advice_mgmt: Your managers are not children they don't need their hands held and 800 checklists every day.  The MIT program is long drawn out if you have had previous experience in retail.

review_title: It was fun and allowed creative sales experiences.
review_pros: If you are interested in fashion and like the brand. Also some perks, such as discounted clothes and other merchandises. Good.
review_cons: They don't hire international students as a full-time employee, so I couldn't elongate my expriences there. But it was fun. Good.
review_advice_mgmt: Please sponsor international students. And A&F needs more improvement on the styles because, the style of the clothes remains same. Cool.

review_pros:
Lack of professional attire
access to sale items
a good experience working with a semi high end / popular brand
diverse group
review_cons:
Lack of communication with managers
lack of employee support for part time workers
the belittling of some employees and lack of encouraging the employees to pursue higher education (from management) especially when it is there only chance of getting promotion
review_advice_mgmt: There are actually employees that work at the company to enjoy working there so please treat everyone with respect and it will given back.

review_pros: Fun environment.  Opportunities to learn & grow with company.  Low stress.
review_cons: The hours are late during floorsets.
review_advice_mgmt: So far I am having a great experience!

review_title: Its a good place to work
review_pros:
Good Music, Good Clothing
Freedom
Flexibility
Team work
review_cons:
no feedack
no motivation by manager
review_advice_mgmt: It will really helpful to get a feedback on jobs done

review_pros: Good Discount.Promoted quickly.Work with young adults. You will probably be the smartest person in your store.
review_cons:
Management is pathetic.  They think they are somebody because they are DM's or Rm's for this company when in reality they wouldnt make it far in the real world.  
The hiring policies are ridiculous.  You should be running a business instead you are running around college campus's trying to "recruit" employees you dont need.
review_advice_mgmt:
Take care of your employees. Listen to them.
There is a reason why you are a joke to the rest of the retail industry.

review_pros: It is the funnest job I've ever had, it is very flexible with hours, great place to work at if you're going to school full time.
review_cons: It pays min. wage and you have no way of getting paid more than the rest of the in-store models.

review_title: More stressful then it needs to be.
review_pros:
1. The associates
2. Decent benefits
3. Simple job
review_cons:
1. Upper management can be hard to work with at times.
2. Manager schedules are never constant (never the same schedule/shift times on a weekly basis).
3. Difficult customers with a whole range of personalities.
4. Dealing with Thieves on a daily-weekly basis.
5. Very low pay for amount of work done.
6. Highturnover rates with lower level managers..
review_advice_mgmt: Give more pay raises! Its crazy how much work people put in and how much they sacrafice for a company that makes so much money (not to mention how much its Ceo gets paid), and yet all they receive in the end is 'great job's or 'thanks'. People have been working there for years however still make less then 35k as a store manager! A little appreciation in the form of fair pay raises would make the job a lot better Imo. The job heirachy is all screwed up too. Most District managers are egotistical and seem to always be looking down on the managers and associates.

review_pros: You can be running a multimillion dollar a year business within 6 months and only see your boss 1 of every 7 work days.
review_cons: Having to pay minimum wage to part-time employees who have to spend 100$ on their work clothes every two months. Employee discount not any better than what customers pay.
review_advice_mgmt: More flexibility with what we pay our part-timers and how they are treated. We spend countless hours recruiting great candidates from Universities only to lose them they break of the cult mentality we've created.

review_title: okay place to work, but re-folding perfect clothes is too repetitive
review_pros: it's a great place to meet great people.
review_cons: Sometimes management expects too much from you for what you are paid for. You ALWAYS have to be busy doing something even if no one is there and EVERYTHING is perfect.
review_advice_mgmt: allow front door models to move away from the station for ONE second if they NEED TO! we can't just ignore customers because we have to say "HEY, HOWS IT GOING" to EVERYONE

review_pros:
GREAT learning experience. Oh man, I learned everyway not to run a business, as well as some great visual merchandising strategies. 

Prior to being promoted to lead stock, I was part time impact. With that position, there was a lot of flexibility with scheduling. The company also allows relocation with gaurenteed position at new stores which has come in handy with my several city changes. 

Once becoming full-time: the benefits ARE AMAZING! I only now wish I would have taken full advantage of them as I've yet to find as good of a package for such a low rate. 

Granted I was not a manager, I was granted the management discount which was awesome!

While the egos of many part timers can be overwhelming, it has a fun culture. It also help build a strong confidence in both myself and everything I stand for. While some took this confidence boost to their head, I feel it helped give me that competitive edge.

Despite it being hectic, as most retail is, it can be rather laid back.

I also enjoyed the music and the dress code.
review_cons:
Oh boy, where to start?

I was once very dedicated to this company and wanted to advance as far as I could. I valued Mike Jefferies and idolized his ideal in running a business... Then I woke up and saw Abercrombie for what it was worth. Talk about slap to the face.

Abercrombie focuses more on looks than properly running a business. While they have that classic American beauty image to uphold, the quality of employees suffer as they will select an interviee with far less to contribute to a store that looks good vs. someone who has more than the world to offer that looks above average. Many part time employees, esp "Models", take the job as a joke and fail to equally contribute, even though they are getting paid to do a job. Oh the rants you hear on a daily basis by these kids. Yes it pays you min. wage, but find a job in the mall that doesn't. Yes, it gives you poor hours, but again, good luck elsewhere. Those on a full time level have to BUST their tales on a daily basis to make up for the slack that reoccurs every day, every week, every year. I luckily was a non-exempt employee therefore I LOVE OVERTIME PAY :).  Management turnover is also very high, which leaves for a chaotic work environment. Of the three years I worked for the company, I had at least 25 different managers, which does include management at all levels not just Store Manager. 
District managers, and this is all three that I have dealt with, do not value anyone other than the store manager. They have little respect for anyone, which humors me as they were once working in that position some years ago. I could go on forever..
review_advice_mgmt: Value all of your employees. It takes an entire TEAM to create success. Employee turn-over is high, there is a reason and that can be addressed. Also, don't keep useless managers as they drive away those with true potential. I have seen store after store fail for similar reasons. Look deeper into employee motivation as the company as a whole needs to improve the moral of a majority of their employees. In wanting to be selective in hiring, select a pretty face with brains- it isn't as hard as it sounds. Sadly, all this advice is not unknown.. it's ignored.

review_title: An opportunity for long time success.
review_pros:
Great Health Benefits.
The People.
Unlimited opportunities.
review_cons:
Work attire. 
Inconsistent schedules.
No weekends off unless requested.
review_advice_mgmt: The company gives specific direction for each task given. - This is greatly appreciated! Home Office and higher management consistently gives negative and positive feedback. This allows stores to have a happy balance with their management teams. Thanks!

review_title: Bad pay and overly high expectations.
review_pros: Decent pay, can hire great associates under you. You are the boss and learn a lot through manager in training program.
review_cons: Barely allowed to take vacation, bosses are rude and expect too much. Company does not care about it's associates. Expected to do evrrything yourself, I was barely allowed to take lunch breaks, called in on my days off, just a horrible ad stressful wok environment.

review_pros: Casual dress and fun people to work with
review_cons: Upper management can be unreasonable and unfair
review_advice_mgmt: Treat all employees equally.  Tell them directly when there is a problem.

review_title: Long hours but lots of experience
review_pros: you get paid well to manage high volume areas, so you gain a lot of experience.
review_cons: You work long hours and your direct manager likely has no to little experience managing people.

review_title: A cult that sucks the fun out of you
review_pros: Very flexible in hours, time off and understanding of school and other jobs. Great good looking people. Good place to make new friends and potential romances.
review_cons: Horrible pay. Conforming dress code. Catty and depressed Management staff. Slow promotion process.

review_title: Great place to socialize and make minimum wages.
review_pros: Fun, energetic environment with great music made the long hours somewhat more enjoyable. Some managers were very personable and made the job seem less like work.
review_cons: Managers who pick and choose favorites. If you aren't well liked you can forget about getting scheduled a reasonable number of hours each week.
review_advice_mgmt: Perhaps you should make more efforts to treat every employee fairly, regardless of how close you are to them personally.

review_title: enjoyable for a min wage job
review_pros: The music keeps you moving at work even though it is very repetitive in a shift and other fellow employees are fun to work with.
review_cons: Music is repetitive, not able to wear comfortable shoes to work, the perfume in the store is too strong and follows you everywhere
review_advice_mgmt: if you are stressed out or having an emotional day do not take it out on your employees

review_title: If you're looking for a lot of hours, not the place for you
review_pros:
Managers and coworkers can be really great, and you get to meet a lot of people
Scheduling is very flexible, and it's really easy to transfer to other locations
review_cons:
Store can get catty, depending on your managers and their tolerance/participation in store gossip
If you're looking for a very reliable and profitable part-time job, this is probably not for you
Music gets repetitive after a while
review_advice_mgmt: The stores generally have a really high employee turnover, so it would be great if you could offer pay raises to employees who have been working with the company longer and have more experience.

review_title: It's a terrible company that is willing to hire anyone because of their turnover rate.
review_pros: I like the fact that we get two days off but other than that everything else is horrible.  I just need to keep this job because it's the only place hirring at the moment and I need to pay my bills.
review_cons: Everything.  The Pay is horrible and the demands are very unrealistic.
review_advice_mgmt: They need to pay their employees much more.

review_title: good job if you just need money in the short term
review_pros: flexible hours and cool associates to work with
review_cons: most employees average about 4 to 8 hours a week. pay is $8 an hour with no possibility of promotion or raise. Managers are typically pretty gossipy and remind me of Mean Girls

review_pros: Laid back atmosphere. Significant discount. Good job for high school or college kids. Easy place to meet and make friends.
review_cons: The pay is simply minimum wage. To advance you must have completed a college degree. It may take a while to become a manager and have your own store.
review_advice_mgmt: Managers are required to have a college degree, so they are a bit older than most employees and have much more experience.

review_pros: Friendly staff, decent discount, overall a good environment for a part-time job if you don't need to make much money.
review_cons: The pay is barely over minimum wage.  Store management positions require a college degree.  The pay isn't much more than a full-time underling, just more responsibility.
review_advice_mgmt: Give employees an incentive to move within the company.  Encourage more ways of store management to make it into the corporate side of the company.

review_pros: It's an okay first job to have especially since retail experience and working with people is necessary for future jobs.
review_cons: Disrespectful employers who were lazy and always want you to do their job for them. Don't expect any recognition for your work but expect recognition for your mistakes.
review_advice_mgmt: Don't try to get on the good side of the leaders. Just do your job and move on from there.

review_title: A&F is a fun company to work for!
review_pros: Abercrombie is great because you have many different promotion opportunities. You also meet many great people that become your best friends.
review_cons: The pay isn't the best.
review_advice_mgmt: Increase pay for those who deserve it most!

review_pros:
Great energy.
Fun with friends.
High School job.
MUST be 17 years old to work.
review_cons:
Longer you work here, the more responsibility is put on you with the same pay (minimum wage). 
Folding clothes.

review_title: it is a good place to get management experience.
review_pros: the people you work with make the experience better.
review_cons: the pay and district manager is terrible
review_advice_mgmt: give considerate feedback

review_pros:
flexible schedule, competent and kind store managers

good place to learn how a corporate retail store is run, yet in a smaller store setting.
review_cons:
very few hours, horrible pay, and you don't get a good discount (20%, if i remember correctly).  

dress code can be annoying- can only wear certain colors during certain times of the year, hair/nails done a certain way, no makeup, etc.

they dont seem to care about selling, which i found odd.  not much, if any, direction on how to sell.  if it wasnt for my previous retail experience, i would have had no idea what i was doing when i was selling to customers.  however, they didnt seem to care if you sold or not anyway.
review_advice_mgmt:
Worked at abercrombie kids in Spring 2009.  I worked here when I was in high school.  This job is NOT the kind of job you can rely on for hours- i only got about 8 hours per week, and there were many kids who worked in the store.  This made it difficult to get alot of hours.  Also, the pay was horrible- minimum wage with taxes taken out.  

Although I learned how a corporate business is run (i previously worked at a family-owned clothing store), my job basically consisted of standing in the front.  I would always be placed in the front, where I would fold and refold, and greet customers.  I basically got paid to text for a few hours a week.  This is not the job that you get to earn good money and have set hours/schedule; however, it is good for a high schooler who needs to get a job so that your parents will stop nagging you to find one.  It is a good place to learn what the corporate retail environment is like (minus comission).

review_pros: The best thing about Abercrombie is their hours.
review_cons: The worst thing about abercrombie are the customers
review_advice_mgmt: I think that management should offer better discounts to employees, offer more hours per week to current employees, and I have no idea what else to say.

review_title: In the beginning it was fun and enjoyable, and then...
review_pros:
It's good for high school students who don't have any expenses and just need a little bit of money to have fun. 
The fragrance can smell good.
The managers are helpful, training is given.
review_cons:
Not enough hours.
You start off at -$150 because of the "uniform" and it takes about 2 weeks to earn it back.
The labor is stressful if you are by nature a hard worker. If you're lazy then it's fine. 
Not really recognized for your hard work unless you have a good manger. But corporate never looks at the manager's reviews on the associates unless they think they're stealing.
Oh, there's a lot of shop lifters. So if they don't express enough to you, be ready you'll get a lot of notifications about how to stop shoplifters.
review_advice_mgmt: The managers are good at their job, very helpful and fun to be friends with outside of the workplace (no longer co-workers).

review_title: A shallow place where only attractive people are hired
review_pros:
-Meet some great people
-Nice 30% discount on full priced items
-Flexible schedules
-Great managers who are close in age with the rest
review_cons:
-Its really hard to get hours, you normally work about two 4 hour shifts per week
-The pay is minimum wage so its not that great
-The district manager is the one who wants the store and the associates to be in perfect order and you have to look flawless when around her or she'll criticize you.
review_advice_mgmt: I think you are doing a great job at my store with what you have to work with and my only advise would have to be to give out more hours to the hard workers and less to the people to just waste space.

review_title: A fun, fast paced work environment with great people and abysmal compensation.
review_pros: The opportunity to work with a large team selected primarily on their attractiveness, social skills, and positive attitude.
review_cons: One of the absolute lowest compensation package offered by any major clothing retailer. Salary increase possible after 1 year of employment (not counting 3 month MIT program), with increase offered in 0%, 3%, or 5% increase depending on job performance (Needs Improvement, Doing Well, Outstanding).
review_advice_mgmt: I've been told that the average turnover of managers at this company is around 6 months. I've been with the company for 1 year and 8 months, and have seen 15+ managers quit/terminated. Closer connection with higher management, a more competitive salary, and better attention to positive and negative performance of managers would improve manager retention.

review_title: Management promotions based solely on recruiting good looking associates
review_pros: Decent pay and benefits package, reasonable with time off requests, opportunity to meet and work with fun people, good retail management experience
review_cons: Once in a management position, your promotions are based on how many new associates you personally add to your store's "tracker", or list of best looking employees. Far too many operationally incompetent Store Managers promoted just because they've recruited very attractive associates. No focus on selling, more of a "product will sell itself" mentality. Hours go to the best looking, not hardest working part time associates.
review_advice_mgmt: Recognize and reward best part-time associates with raises. Set better criteria by which to judge who should be running your stores. Focus on customer service.

review_title: If you can work hard, put in the overtime and get over some of the policies this is a good retail management career.
review_pros: Working with great, fun, young people. Fairly good pay when compared to other retail management jobs, good career opportunities for those committed and willing to go above and beyond expectations.
review_cons: There are few opportunities to be creative as almost everything is standardised. Policies go to far to prevent socialising with colleagues (many promotions involve relocation, so re-starting a social life is hard). Working unsociable hours, occasionally with little sleep between shifts.
review_advice_mgmt: Do more to reward and retain talent as many good managers become demotivated and leave. Performance based bonuses/incentives/small gestures of appreciation would help to motivate staff and increase productivity.

review_pros: Great benefits, fast pace. Fast track to promotion if you're willing to go above and beyond. Even better chances of promotion if you're willing to relocate. They are always interviewing employees for home office and are very generous and take care of employees when travel is neccessary.
review_cons: They have some wierd policy to get around paying employees over time pay. Anything over 41 hours a week you get half time pay....thats right only half of your hourly wage. Usually you are not there anything over 40-41 but during busy high volume weeks or big vists you'll go over hours and its not worth it to be making less than minimum wage at that point.
review_advice_mgmt: Over time pay please! We work hard and its nice to be recognized for it! The people that are staying longer hours are the people that want to be there.

review_pros: Laid back, above average looking co-workers
review_cons: Long hours, terrible pay, promotion based on looks not quality of work
review_advice_mgmt: Ugly people judging others looks, get real.

review_pros:
-teaches you how to use a register 
-gives experience
-is something to talk about after you quit
- is something to talk about in another interview about horrible past employers
review_cons:
-Low wages
-The fact that you must wear specfic clothing (there clothing), when the pay if horrible
-The fact that you have to call in to check your hours, because the manager won't tell you
-Have to check and see if they need you to work that day
-Let you know ONE HOUR in advance if you are supposed to work that day
-No job training
review_advice_mgmt: They need to get their stuff together, at least in the store I worked at. No one knew when they were supposed to work and were told only one hour in advance

review_title: Great opportunities are given to all from a company that only promotes management from within.
review_pros:
Work with a lot of fun people.
Lots of growth at the store level.
International opportunities.
High energy work environment.
review_cons:
Upper management opportunities are limited unless you're willing to move.
Pay isn't the greatest. 
A lot of travel is required at times.
Long hours and blackout periods during the holidays.
review_advice_mgmt:
Allow mid/upper management to live in the area in which they work.
Offer a more competitive salary comprable to competitors.

review_pros: Get to work with cool managers, pretty much do what you want
review_cons: Annoying/rude customers at times, the smell of the cologne gives you a headache

review_pros:
Manage teams upwords of 100 employees.  
Time management skills, customer service, specific deadlines, great coworker community,  nice atmosphere, opportunities for advancement both domestically and internationally.
review_cons: not a 9-5 job, managing younger employees whose goals are often specified outside of the company, possible long days, retail atmosphere so weekends off are not always given.
review_advice_mgmt: Crackdown harder on slacking management members, offer greater incentives for positive work performance, greater opportunities for advancement/ raises, higher raises.

review_title: Great place to begin and build a career in management.
review_pros: Flexible schedule, increasing pay for positive performance, opportunity for relocation and promotion, ability to manage independently and train new employees.
review_cons: Holiday season provides you with little downtime, high turnover rates reduce rate of promotion for others.
review_advice_mgmt: New managers are sometimes lost in stores without positive store managers and this increases the turnover in stores.

review_pros: The store had a discount and had fun co-workers
review_cons: Pressure to look just like the rest of the co-workers, sent home for wrong dress
review_advice_mgmt: Don't hire so much and focus on the team you do have

review_pros: Abercrombie and Fitch supports the individual but also incorporates as a team. The job is not overly demanding but the rate of pay for all associates is relatively low compared to other companies.
review_cons: The CEO Mike Jeffries did not make the right decisions when the economy dropped and refused to lower prices initially and by the time he did, the company was already too far behind in popularity.
review_advice_mgmt: You can move up quickly and seemingly easily but once you get to a management position, it is a lot of responsibility but rewarding.

review_title: Loved the employees in my store; Dissatisfied with Upper Management
review_pros: despite the stigma that exists, most everyone I ever worked with in my store was a great person to work with and you can really develop some good friendships, although that comes at the cost of your nights/weekends/holidays etc
review_cons: Hours; Holidays; A long line of management levels; A lack of flexibility with unique store situations; policies that do not reward loyalty for customers or employees; Some management districts have high turnover, and others have almost zero, making it difficult to move up if your settled into a district without turnover; Advancement is based on Recruiting, not store success
review_advice_mgmt: upper management exists to pass along memos and police policies with a disconnect understanding day-to-day difficulties and how policies effect customers. Caring more about its own perception of how it treats customers, than how customers perceive the store.

review_title: Working for A&F was tiring, depressing, and difficult.
review_pros: I did get to occasionally meet customers who I really could help, and every once in awhile I'd receive a compliment on how good my tables looked from my managers.
review_cons: I was suffocating because of the perfume that I had to spray on the clothes, couldn't hear because of the music, and was constantly trying to keep people from stealing. I was never really trained, and was expected to learn things on my own.
review_advice_mgmt: Give more training, be less strict about dress code. I should not have been almost fired for wearing a headband and having my nails done (2 days before I went to prom)

review_pros: Fast promotion rate if you work hard and communicate well. Promote from within. International and Home Office opp avail. Company pays for most relocation expenses.
review_cons: Very long work weeks & not compensated well. Promotions ultimately result in relocating continuously. High stress because of high standards, but results are not met with positive reinforcement/ praise.

review_pros: Its a very easy job! The people you work with are usually bubbly and outgoing. When you first get hired you get 50% off your first outfit if I remember correctly.
review_cons: There isn't a opportunity for promotion, the pay is minimum wage, and there isn't a consistent schedule meaning the managers will schedule you when they want.
review_advice_mgmt: Try not to only hire attractive people, us normal looking individuals can give excellent customer service as well, also change how scheduling is done

review_title: My experience was great and it gave me great retail experience.
review_pros: loved working with customers. The retail environment is great, and very relaxed. The employee discounts were great.
review_cons: It seemed like they really stressed wearing their clothes and managers would sometimes get upset if you weren't
review_advice_mgmt: Since employees are given "rooms" to maintain, they were not allowed to leave that room. I would suggest allowing employees to help customers as much as possible when needed.

review_title: I've had a great experience working at Abercrombie & Fitch
review_pros: Great management and hard working employees
review_cons: Hours aren't distributed that well at a kids store
review_advice_mgmt: I have no advice to offer to my managers. They are amazing at running a store and have excellent customer and employee relations.

review_title: Good place to work if you're just looking to work a few hours a week
review_pros: Always hiring and looking for people. Depending on the store, can be a great and fun environment to work. Work around your own schedule. Great for students still taking classes. Usually very flexible with needing days and time off.
review_cons: If you do not fit management's idea of the "image", you'll get a stock room position if you're lucky. At interviews management usually has their mind made up about who they're hiring, even before you open your mouth. The pay is right around minimum wage and the hours are very limited. Company looks to only have people working between 8-12 hours/week. Very lucky if you can get 20 hours/week. They do not want customers to always see the same employees while shopping. Even though you may work hard, people that work half as much may have the same, if not more hours.
review_advice_mgmt: Look to hire those that are proud to represent the brand and actually do the work that is required of them, even if they do not "fit the image" that you are looking for. Customers do not always give into the image, instead they want to be acknowledged and helped when needed. It is better to have hard workers, than pretty people that do not want to do the work.

review_pros:
opportunities to work all over the world
associate discount
great medical benefits
company promotes from within (no senior management outside hires)
lots of options the more you move up
working with attractive people
review_cons:
holiday hours (you're too exhausted to enjoy time with your family)
pay/compensation
pressure to constantly bring MORE results (never good enough)
relocation package/compensation is not great
going to work internationally requires a two year contract

review_title: It was resume experience, that is all.
review_pros: Fun people (except management). It was a job that paid me so I couldn't complain much.
review_cons: Grumpy management. They don't give you many hours to work if you don't fit the "Abercrombie" look. After 2.5 years of working there I received no wage raise.
review_advice_mgmt: Stop thinking that your product are god's blessing to the world. Listen to your store associates about merchandise because we are the frontlines of the store!

review_title: My job experience with A&F has been a fun, but exhausting ride.
review_pros: Pros about working at Abercrombie & Fitch is that it provides a fun environment where you get to meet new people.
review_cons: Cons about working at Abercrombie & Fitch is that the work load is at a minimal, most of the time; in result, most associates will not get the hours desired.
review_advice_mgmt: Some advice to management is to give more feedback, check up more often, and give a daily outlook on what needs to be done that day.

review_pros: Its fun but not that much of a learning experience.
review_cons: The scheduling sucks, if you are looking for many hours don't work at Abercrombie. Also, being on-call is a pain.

review_title: Do not make this your only job
review_pros: the best reasons to work at anf is the name it looks really good on resumes, because its a high quality store. Its flexible if you are in college or have other thing going on.
review_cons: Its an image based company so if you dont look american and pretty in their eyes your ugly and that might reflect how many hours you get. The management are mostly stuck up especially the higher up people like DM's, and they really dont have any ethics for employees, they force you to but their clothes and wear them, they force you to work without breaks sometimes. They dont have a break room for employees and they discourage you to eat in the stockroom, talk to your associates while working, or look at your cell briefly. They are very anal when it comes to presentations and folding clothes. If you are a model be prepared to stand up front for 5 hours at one time, or be on register running around getting fitting rooms, folding clothes, and doing go backs. Overall i worked for this company for 3 years and i never had a opportunity for advancement since you have to have a bachelors degree to be a manager. I only got a 50 cent raise which in the retail world is terrible. I wouldnt recommend working her since you only get 10-15 hours a week sometimes and since your pay is very low.
review_advice_mgmt: care more about your employees

review_pros:
-Develop strong management skills if personally driven
-Relationships you build 
-International opportunities
review_cons:
-Unstable schedule, limited time off
-Stressful work environment
-Must be willing to relocate for promotions
review_advice_mgmt: stronger communication through chain of command, flexibility with mandatory schedule

review_title: You can give your life to A&F, and do a great job, and still be fired
review_pros: The only reason to work at A&F is to have the name on your resume. Oh, and no one works on Saturday except the stores and the boss.
review_cons: If you're not sucking up to one of the 3 evp's, you probably won't make it for very many years. And if you get on the wrong side of any one of them, check your watch.
review_advice_mgmt: Best advice I can think of is: promote or hire some competent people to run human resources, allocation, distribution, marketing, oh, and the company while you're at it.

review_pros: It's a great start for graduate student
review_cons: Too young too naive to work in the place.

review_title: Interesting and challenging with limited support from management
review_pros: Young energetic atmosphere, High energy, Open floor plan with little to no "doors".  Good recognition for resume.
review_cons: "cliques" in management, Biased opinion of employees based on personal wardrobe, low tolerance for individual ways of thinking
review_advice_mgmt: Be open to industry knowledge, and not so much in how prospective employees fit "the brand mold".

review_title: It was terrible our dm was so rude and treated us very poorly
review_pros: the discount was ok if you were a manager and  retail hours are not to bad. the training would have been good if there was a store manager or dm that cared
review_cons: they were rude, they would yell at you when you would work 60 plus hours a week for them.  you would fix something that was wrong and go above and beyond and would never get any recognition
review_advice_mgmt: Honestly take pride in your store and associates/managers.  Let them know you do care about how hard they work and how much time and effort they put into your stores.

review_title: Not a great company to work for
review_pros: work with great people and can be fun
review_cons: do not care about employees
review_advice_mgmt: care more about your employees

review_pros: Compensated very well mgt positions
review_cons: Lots of politics. Senior Leadership lacks input from middle mgt who knows the details.

review_pros:
Laid back
"Jeans & Flip-Flops" attire, very casual
Casual work environment
Good work/life balance
Employees often socialize outside work
review_cons:
Pay is low
Can't move up in the company until college is fully completed
Sometimes management gets uptight

review_pros:
Great benefits (medical, dental, the full coverage)
Great discount (if you wear clothes outside of work)
review_cons:
Incompetence at all levels of this job
irregular shifts 
not a secure job (they let you know that)
not appreciated
Never get raises!! (even associates, only way to get a raise is to get promoted)
review_advice_mgmt: appreciate the workers!! who actually are making the connection to customers, without employees you have no one to delegate orders to.

review_pros: You get discounts on the clothes if that is the style that you are looking for. The discount is pretty good.
review_cons: There is too much down time and not enough time working. Way too much standing around and not doing anything.
review_advice_mgmt: I would make sure that your employees are always working and doing something instead of talking to each other or on their phones.

review_pros: Overall, the pros include lots of hot coworkers, fun atmosphere, flexible hours, young coworkers, not hard work at all, easy interview.
review_cons: The people working with you might not be the sharpest tools in the shed, but if you look at it as a part time job, its not bad.

review_title: Not the best but not the worst job someone can have
review_pros:
- EXTREMELY Flexible - since A&F hire so many people (my store in particular) they are tight on hours so they won't think twice if you change your availiablity 
- Down to Earth Managers - for the most part all of my managers are easy to work with since they're about your age they understand you have school and stuff 
-Impact Members are usually down to Earth- I find mostly the Impact Team is very easy to talk to because we're all fairly nice to talk to, even a lot of the models are, there are maybe 4 or 5 models that need an attitude adjustment (they think they're above everyone else especially impacters since they're "models" - news flash, model is just abercrombies way of sugarcoating the position of sales associate
-Discount works at multiple stores - Hollister, abercrombie kids, Gilly Hicks
review_cons:
-Very little hours given - so many employees are hired (its not the managers fault they're pressured by senior management and corporate to hire in bulk) it is deff hard to schedule enough hours to satisfy everyone - however hours are given on an work ethic basis and my store they actually do recognize who is doing the work 
-Bad pay -minimum wage (only hope to fix that is that you have to be working for a year + to get a raise and even then the raise isnt that much) technically your eligible after 6 months but that doesnt happen 
-High turnover - 2 managers have already left since i've been there (only been there for like 3 months) - employees quit every few weeks or so 
- Unrealistic expectations at times - one manager at my store expects work that would take a person that is completely focused 1 hour to do in 15 min -  can't leave shift until certain task are completely done as well - which means you're usually there till 1 hour or so after shift - (it isnt all that bad since shifts are typically 5 hours at most so you're staying 6 hours)
review_advice_mgmt:
-Less empahsis on hiring so many employees simply because of looks. Too much of the work is being placed on competent employees for lazy employees that are being hired and cant be bothered working past 4 hours 
-Senior Management needs to be more down to earth - some senior management try to appear friendly but give off an intimidating vibe as if they're being forced to do something

review_pros: Good first job. That's about it.
review_cons:
Not enough hours
No community
No communication between management and employees
Not a grown up job
Over hiring
Tokenism
review_advice_mgmt:
Less hiring
More "diversity"

review_pros: Flexible Hours that are very good for college students
review_cons: Very little hours and some of the workers aren't that nice

review_title: Fun experience of the retail world!
review_pros: Great first job, very easy job
review_cons: minimum wage and loud music

review_pros:
Very flexible hours that work with your school schedule.
Friendly environment.
Decent discount.
-50% when you have to purchase new "uniform clothing"
-30% all other times
review_cons: None really, just kind of boring

review_pros: You're guaranteed an interview when you apply.
review_cons:
You need a degree to move up anywhere company except for full time stock or model?
Minimum wage- really?
No hours
Hires too many people
Models get more hours than impacters when impacters do more work
Job can be overwhelming.
review_advice_mgmt: Tell the people above you to get their crap together and form a better company.

review_title: So far at A&F I could say I wish I got more Hours
review_pros: Very flexible schedule, good discounts
review_cons: Minimum wage, not guaranteed hours

review_pros:
Discount on clothing
Work around young people
review_cons:
Cheap pay $7.15 for Part-Timers
Skinny people only
The 'managers' who are in their late 20's are the cashiers not the part-timers!
review_advice_mgmt:
Raise pay
Felt a lil' bit of racism (the hispanics/blacks were in put in the stockroom)

review_pros: not much is expected of you, basically unlimited lunch
review_cons: lower pay, some managers go on power trips every now and then
review_advice_mgmt: you waste a lot of money at the home office stores

review_pros: Girls here are really beautiful and really easy to talk to. The managers will like you if you don't have an ego and are quick to learn.

review_pros:

review_cons:
Discount does not stack with current sales so customers get the same discount as you.
Stuck at minimum wage salary for as long as you work there.
review_advice_mgmt: Try to be more organized. I realize corporate gives protocols to follow but even those can be  inconvenient for both the customer and the employees who work under you.

review_pros:
- If you look good and are outgoing it is really easy to get hired.
- A feel good job because many of the people who walk in are intimidated by you.
- You get to be around attractive and interesting people.
- Make your own schedule really, they don't mind if you can't make it in one day or another.
review_cons:
- Minimum wage
- Have to wear clothes consistent with "The Look Policy", in other words something that is current season. End up blowing a large portion of salary on clothing. A&F says they don't require you to wear their clothes. That's a lie.
- If you are in the front area you have to stay there and say stupid taglines within 15 seconds of a customer walking in/out. You also end up folding and refolding already perfect piles of clothing endlessly.
- Same annoying soundtrack repeats the whole season.
- The smell clings to you.
- No training. When a customer asks for help you have no idea; I just give them some random bs.
- Get tired of fake smiling all the time.
review_advice_mgmt: Maybe somebody above you requires you to be super anal about dress code and folding clothing. I don't know. All I do know is that it's really annoying to be called out for super small nitpicky stuff. Please be more understanding. Obviously employees can be replaced easily at Abercrombie but I would like some respect.

review_pros: Fun, young, casual, corporate office environment.
review_cons: Disorganized, inconsistent message and job structure.
review_advice_mgmt: Value your employees.

review_pros: opportunity to gain sales experience and learn about corporate policies
review_cons: Minimal pay, very few hours per week

review_title: Abercrombie and Fitch was a great company to work for and I met a lot of great people.
review_pros: Great energy and great people. The company is very detail oriented. Very fast paced environment and never a dull moment. Great opportunity to meet upper management as they came through the stores often.
review_cons: Long hours, sometimes 50 hour weeks. Work on most all holidays and weekends. Some of the values of the company are less than desirable. The work/ life balance was not very satisfying because I would always be called on my days off to solve issues, take conference calls from home, and there was a lot of out of work research to be done for recruiting events and job fairs.
review_advice_mgmt: Sometimes when upper management came through the store, they would act like they owned the place and intimidate managers instead of getting to know them and be friendly like they tell us we needed to be.

review_pros: Abercrombie does give a good, easy segway into a management position, as their hiring standards for Managers in Training are not very strict- you do no require management experience, just a Bachelor's Degree. So for someone fresh out of college it is a good starting point for a full time job with benefits, and they do start you at a decent salary given the economy (or they did two years ago when I was employed, things may have changed since).
review_cons:
Abercrombie treats their managers horribly, when they are so essential to the success of the stores! There are three types of Assistant Manager you can become when you "graduate" the training program (which they do not hold strictly to- MIT's can easily cheat and are often given the answers or don't even end up doing the actual training activities because they are needed as extra register "ringers" because they do not count as the same type of hours alotted for the day): Impact Manager, Peoples Manager or Visual Manager. Admittedly, the first two are not so bad (with only one or two closing shifts each, and always a weekend day off), but if you are the lucky one to be made Visual Manager, you have officially signed your life away to the company. As VM, you are basically a second overnight manager- you have only one or two opening shifts and rarely get a weekend day off. It is extremely rare that any of the other managers, who always have the same schedule, will switch with you so that you can get a weekend day off and live a normal life. You work either overnight from 5pm-2am or in a non-overnight store, from 6am-2pm, often without getting a lunch break because there is no one to cover you. You are often in the store alone at scary and dangerous times. You cannot leave a floorset or update until every single detail is met and everything is finished- which often takes up to 12 hours to complete. I managed a team of overnighters who spoke minimal English, and was once there from 5pm until 10am the next morning- and only paid half-rate for overtime hours. You are not allowed to take off time to compensate the extra hours worked- you just keep working and still only get paid half of your normal rate for any hours exceeding the 40 per week expected of you. You also are constantly denied requests to use your alotted vacation time. Or even to take time off due to an injury endured in the workplace. 

Abercrombie's hiring standards and claims of diversity are also completely false- they instruct managers to dissuade "undesirable" applicants from applying in the store kiosk, because the only numbers they base their hiring percentages on are the ones from applicants in the kiosk (versus online or interview walk-ins). They tell applicants that are not "Cast-Of" to apply for the impact position versus the model position, where you have to meet a certain look and standard (beautiful, thin, etc.) They recruit to fill gaps in diversity not to be a genuinely diverse company, but to meet their quotas so they don't get in trouble.  

Overall Abercrombie is a completely unethical company that treats its managers and employees like slaves.
review_advice_mgmt: My advice to Management is to treat your Managers better- they are running your stores! Make the schedules more fair, and pay time and a half for overtime hours like a normal company should- not half time pay. A college graduate should not be making the same as a 17 year old after a certain number of hours are met. Grant your managers the vacation days they request and deserve! Create a way for the Visual Manager responsibilities to be shared, and be fair in your hiring! Also, I was personally mislead and told constantly "You're our best Assistant Manager, you will be promoted so quickly you're a rising star" etc. and they kept delaying my promotion because I didn't want to be Visual Manager anymore because of the extreme work hours- be fair! Don't take advantage of hard workers!

Every brand I have worked at within the company have managers working overtime each week on a regular basis. Management pay should be increased.
