review_cons: unexpected call-in shift, unorganized task agenda, hard to please difficult customers. sometimes the schedule being too flexible can cause you to work more 40 hours one week versus only 10 hours for another week.
review_advice_mgmt: More PR to change the stereotype of the brand

review_pros: Fun atmosphere, the people that I worked with were all around the same age and had a lot in common. We had fun working together.
review_cons: No recognition for work well done, no possibility of raise. There were quotas to fill in regards to the amount of people we had hired in each ethnic group, and qualified applicants were turned down because they were not the right skin color.

review_pros: it was a relatively fun, social job where i got to work with peers. Managers are your age so its interesting.
review_cons:
Hard to get good hours.
You also have to buy their clothes and they are strict about jewelery, make up, etc.

review_title: Decent part-time job. Paid min wage.
review_pros: Worked with all my friends.
review_cons: Minimum wage and everyone that worked for the company is OBSESSED with the brand.
review_advice_mgmt: n

review_pros: Very good place to work for as they believe in finding the right talent internally and offer good training and development programs
review_cons: Overnight managers and stock  at Hollister have very limited or no career progression opportunities.
review_advice_mgmt: Management should consider to offer same training to overnight emloyess as well.

review_pros: easy, 0 hour contract , 200% salary on sat sunday
review_cons: boring, not good for your career

review_title: It was a good time with A&F
review_pros: Good salary even if you are working as a part timer and even good over time, would reco. if looking for part time job................
review_cons: They dont provide any visa for international employees irrespective of how long or how good they perform....

review_pros: Flexible hours, not very demanding. Most managers are quite relaxed, as are the workers.
review_cons: Pay is not very  much. Raises are based on favoritism.

review_pros:
Great atmosphere to work in
Meet many great people
Learn organization and multitasking skills
Great benefits 
Flexible hours
review_cons:
First couple months aren't the greatest but it gets better
Very micro managed 
No room to try new ideas
Spring time is very slow, resulting in less hours which means fewer shifts
review_advice_mgmt: It would be great if you are employed with Abercrombie for a certain amount of years that having a four year degree for becoming a MIT be waved to allow people who have worked there a long time to move up. It would stop the revolving door of MIT's that come through.

review_pros:
employee discount 
ok employess
ok management
review_cons: to busy, horrible pay, horrible working conditions, they force to buy new uniforms(triple A's) every three months
review_advice_mgmt: raise pay and stop demanding so much.

review_title: great company to get promoted within
review_pros: good discounts, promote within, good benefits, friendly coworkers, fun management, good pay once in managerial position
review_cons: rude customers, short shirts, lots of secret shops, loud music, too much Fierce throughout the store
review_advice_mgmt: less Fierce, quieter music (hard to hear the customers at the cash wrap)

review_pros: Great atmosphere, great location and greater people to work with. it was my first job and happy that was. I can't thank them enough for giving me the experience, first couple days were rough, getting the hang of things. the managers were very friendly and easy going but still kept things running in an efficient manner.
review_cons: the always "on-call" schedule bothered me a little, even though i was seasonal, they kept me, but the schedule never really changed.
review_advice_mgmt: better training with new employees, train them a day or two before putting employees to work

review_pros: decent benefits, fun environment, good co-workers, job laid out with checklists.
review_cons: Used to have freedom in what you wore as long as it was the brand now stuck to a very limited selection, never have 2 days consecutive off so burn out is bound to happen, used to have a lot larger staff to make it easier.

review_title: Very unorganized management and only worked one day for 4 hours.
review_pros: The benefits of the associate card so you can buy their clothes and get 40% off
review_cons: Not enough hours for all the employees
review_advice_mgmt: Be more strict.

review_title: Exhausting, a lot of personal sacrifices, no appreciation
review_pros: The people are what make the company
review_cons: Controlling, must follow company standards to a T, no creativity allowed, long hours with no appreciation, no positive feedback, upper management only ever let's you know what you are doing wrong, terrible CEO, no benefits for beating sales goals.
review_advice_mgmt: Appreciate the people who work and continually sacrifice their personal life for you.  Learn to say thank you and actually mean it.

review_pros: One of the best things about working here is the energy and enthusiasm which Abercrombie & Fitch offers as an employer. Also they are extremely flexible about hours, ideal college job
review_cons: One of the negatives about working here can be the inconsistency in terms of hours which employees are allocated weekly, far from consistent

review_pros: Great fun, youthful atmosphere, working with same age people who usually share same interests. Met a lot of friends through Hollister. Part time flexible hours.
review_cons: Limited amount of hours available, so you probably end up looking for a 2nd job. Minimum wage, which I wouldn't mind, but the shifts are so short that you sometimes end up paying more getting to work. Very superstitious organizational culture.

review_title: High turnover, poor training, hires based on looks.
review_pros: Easy job, good for high schoolers looking to waste some time.
review_cons: Low pay for low labor, looks for physical perfection in their stores, you must wear navy, white, or gray.  Must wear jeans, must wear flipflops.  Managers aren't the brightest bunch. and there is high turnover.
review_advice_mgmt: Value you your employees more.  Hire better people and pay them better to reduce training costs.

review_title: Compensation too low, Must buy outfits every couple months
review_pros: Discount on clothing, Young and relaxed employees, easy tasks
review_cons: Required to buy seasonal outfits, limited hours, minimum wage, company values

review_title: Great Job for Highschool or College!
review_pros: I LOVED my co-workers. Honestly we were like a family. Your A&F experience will depend on your co-workers. If you hate your co-workers the job will suck, but if you love them than the job will be so much fun. The work was easy, cashwrap was fun. The fact fact that the managers are usually in their early 20s makes it easier to talk to/relate to them, the 50% discount has now increased so you get more items half off, everyone's around the same age so tons of new friends/people to hang out with, VERY easy flexibility.
review_cons: The pay. Honestly if it was more than minimum wage (even .25 more) the job would be so much better. Some people say the Triple A's are annoying, but honestly there are ways to get around it so you're not just giving your paycheck right back to the company. Basically the money is the worst, everything else is so laid-back and fun.

review_title: I value the work experience and the friends I made more than the company itself.
review_pros: I met some awesome associates and managers throughout the five years I was there.
review_cons: The company has gotten more uptight over the years. The employee handbook says they won't require you to buy the clothes, as long as you have something similar to the current look and display no competitor logos. However, I've heard our DM say if associates don't buy the new look (which changes 3-5 times per year), they are not to be scheduled. There is a minimum number of new recruits they want each month, which is fine except it takes hours away from experienced associate and often, those old associates end up training new kids because the managers are busy trying to get their own tasks done. Most associates get three (on average) 4- or 5-hour shifts a week so there is a high turnover rate. It's a difficult company to move up in unless you start off as a manager. You need at least a bachelor's to enter the MIT program. So even if you are a dedicated worker who has put in numerous years (in my store there were at least four of us who were past the 5 year mark) and had no write-ups or customer complaints, you are basically stuck in the entry position. You may get to move up to lead stock, but only if your store feels like setting aside the hours for that position. The company focuses heavily on diversity and non-discrimination but it's not hard to find a list of the lawsuits A&F has been involved in. I will admit though that that issue is more because of the shady values of some individual managers so not every store has that problem. Honestly, this company is best suited for a summer or seasonal job and that's it.

review_pros: Good social and flexible environment to work in.
review_cons: Often monotonous and boring work.

review_title: Easy Job, Minimum Wage, FIERCE smell
review_pros: The people are amazing, it's a fun environment and an easy job.
review_cons: The ridiculous amount of cologne sprayed inside the store; bad management; dim lighting and disgusting amount of dust that gets accumulated (seriously, just look up at the light next time you're in an AnF store)

review_pros: Depending on the store you're in, you can get lots of hours and overtime. Working with really good looking people - cons is that they are not smart.
review_cons: No proper training provided. Gives you a binder where you can see your progress which is mostly based on how your relationship is with the store manager. Do not trust anyone you work with because they all talk poop about each other. If you want to grow as a professional/individual, take this as a temporary job because you will not mature and grow in this setting.
review_advice_mgmt: Know that this is a business, not your house.

review_title: LOW PAY but all you do is fold clothes
review_pros:
Can be lazy
dont have to really interact rather than to protect your room from distruction
can be on phone sometimes
young coworkers
review_cons:
LOW PAY
can receive little hours

review_title: Watch out if you are thinking of being a Manager..
review_pros: Upbeat atmosphere. A lot of laid back days. Fun employees. Okay discount.
review_cons:
Pay is HORRIBLE for the slaves the company makes you to be. You must have a degree to be a manager or Asst. manager. Whereas other clothing stores don't require such and pay much better. Pay is laughable. You always work overtime and the company's expectations are LITERALLY IMPOSSIBLE to reach within the number of employees/hours you are given.

No appreciation from District Manager. You have to recruit, daily, to fill employee quota since there is high turnover, and you have to use your own car/gas when you go out recruiting.

I worked here for only a year and miss the employees, but the company made it too hard to work.
review_advice_mgmt: Invest in your management/hourly employees. Lower your expectations and make them reachable. Give hourly employee incentives to work harder.

review_pros: I got hired pretty much on the spot
review_cons: exceedingly strict dress code & rules, nasty management, had to go in to get schedule, sometimes worked closing shift then opening shift back to back

review_title: Abercrombie & Fitch is a fun place to work if you like who you're working with.
review_pros: Employee interaction, customer interaction, friendly & fun environment to work in. The culture is very young and you'll be working with people your age.
review_cons: You are required to buy "50s" which are new clothing releases that the store is trying to push to customers. These end up taking quite a chunk out of your paycheck. There can be limited hours available, as they like to hire many people. There are seriously STRICT rules you must abide by to be a "model," including limited makeup, limited color nail polish, etc. regarding your appearance.

review_pros: Working with young cool people. For the most part the work is easy and you do not need to have common sense to do anything
review_cons: No creativity allowed, closed minded, Need to have "the look" to be worth anything to the company. Pay is minimum wage and there is no chance to move up without a degree.
review_advice_mgmt: Have an open mind, see value in people for reasons other than looks...this probably has something to do with why nobody wants anything to do with this company anymore.

review_pros: Young management and staff so potential to have a great time at work.  Casual dress, and semi-relaxed environment (really what you make of it).  The job itself, once you get the routine down, is very easy since the company tells you exactly what to do every day through memos and a daily "program".
review_cons: High turnover, low pay (1/2 pay for over 40 hours), no appreciation from management- a management that sometimes has only been promoted to management because they've been with the company for so long.  The expectations are very high for "customer service" standard and "visual presentation" standard but the pay is worse than most retail management positions.  You're also expected to complete tasks with models who only work 4-8 hours a week because the company prefers to have "fresh faces" for customers.  With these people who hardly every practice doing anything relevant to the tasks you're supposed to get floor sets and updates done very quickly.  It can be very frustrating.
review_advice_mgmt: Promote based on quality of work and not just based on who gets the best looking recruits.  Focus on customer service and differentiating the brand instead of creating an elite environment and basically making a clique out of the store.  Pay better and give people more of an incentive to stay- if you only promote from within, you have to keep good candidates who actually want to stay long term.

review_title: Management Experience Looks Good On Your Resume, Company Name Does Not
review_pros: Pros: Easy Advancement Opportunities, A Variety of Opportunities Following Assistant Manager Role, Informative MIT Program and Management Training, CDP Reviews, Good Benefits
review_cons: Cons: Unflexible Schedule, Unrealistic Presentation & Recruiting Standards, Very Little Room for Growth in Salary, Terrible Ethics
review_advice_mgmt: I would suggest less evidence of favoritism in upper management seeing that this company promotes based on "who you know" rather than "what you do."  Also, monthly management improvement meetings or training sessions for ALL levels of management including regional, district, store, and assistant managers would be helpful.

review_title: It was great for socializing, Not for an actual job.
review_pros: Great to meet people that are in the area if youre new to town or just wanna make more friends.
review_cons: You really have to work your ass off to get hours was the biggest one. After working there for 6 months i finally started getting more then 15hrs a week.
review_advice_mgmt: Should open up full time positions.

review_title: Unnecessary rules, Very boring atmosphere, no incentive to work there
review_pros: couldnt find any pros. Even the discount was not enough for an employee
review_cons: Too organized, no freedom, no incentives to help promote product. As a sales associate, there is no real sales.
review_advice_mgmt: Need more diversity, need to branch out more to get customers, need to incentivize sales

review_pros: The brand name at best.  Its considered high-end retail.
review_cons:
Everything....
the pay is horrible, absolute worst in any retail (high-end and low-end) management I could find.
overworked...expect to work a minimum of 50 hours but with only paid for 40 hours.
horrible recruiting and hiring routine, its all based on looks, so you're left with less than capable staff which means you have to pick up all the slack...
promotions are popularity contest...
review_advice_mgmt: Good luck if you're still in it...I heard The Gap is hiring and they pay double...

review_pros: Easiest job in the world
review_cons: A level of boring comparable to watching paint dry, then wear off.

review_title: Great people, challenging environment, learned a lot
review_pros:
-awesome/fun staff
-great benefits
-challenging 
-learn how to manage a store
review_cons:
-inconsistent schedule (hard for work life balance)
-unrealistic expectations w/ company standards/recruiting
-loud
-pay
-physically demanding (long hours on feet, heavy shelves/shipment/supplies)
review_advice_mgmt: Invest in your employees!

review_pros: I only really liked my co workers.
review_cons: They do NOT train their employees. It was my first job and they kinda just put me in the store and learn along the way. They would ask if they could put me in register and just because I said I never was on register before they looked for someone else. I mean really, if an employee doesn't know how to do something then teach him/her. I only had one manager I didn't like very much because she always gave me an attitude for no reason. It was minimum wage.
review_advice_mgmt: Train your employees better. Let the managers do manager tasks.

review_title: Too many employees, hardly any hours
review_pros: Easy work, good discount on clothes, easy to change schedules because there are so many people that need hours.
review_cons: Expected to look/dress/act a certain way, customers are usually rude, hardly get any hours because there are over a hundred employees, everyone is shallow and for the most part does not act like they want to be at work.
review_advice_mgmt: Change up the question that models have to ask when people walk in. It gets annoying really quickly.

review_pros: discounts, attractive workers, good job for a high school student
review_cons: too loud of music, customers can't hear what I am saying

review_title: Great company to start your career at.
review_pros: The job offers good benefits and compensation.  The Home Office campus is great.  After training, given lots of responsibility right away.
review_cons: Mobility is based on availability only, at least in department I was in.  Not too much bad to say about the company, enjoyed it there.

review_title: Unprofessional work environment but good managerial experience
review_pros: At first it was a very fun job, lively music, many things to learn about the aspects of managing a store. Managers had to be quite autonomous, creating weekly schedules, training teams, hiring/recruitment, keeping track of sales goals, having weekly meetings, making daily deposits at the bank, etc.
review_cons: The job title "model" is used as a means to only hire beautiful people, even if they work horribly. I had several people under me who did not work and often worked a lot of overtime to have the store cleaned up as a result. Upper management was very discriminatory and promotions were not given on merit. There was a lot of dishonesty, internally, theft and high turnover. Salaries were really low and we were forced to work 50 hour weeks (60 hours around Christmas time) - paid HALF pay for additional hours and not given time off during holidays.

review_title: Good starting place, but DO NOT GET STUCK HERE.
review_pros: The people you meet are phenomenal!
review_cons: The pay, management, higher management, customers
review_advice_mgmt: Take some interest in your employees, listen to what they have to say

review_pros: Fun people to be around if you, develop friendships and great way to start right out of college
review_cons: work life balance sucks, never good enough mentality and politics.  Stressful and draining in the end.
review_advice_mgmt: more support

review_pros:
Easy
Nice Managers
Attractive co-workers
Great job for high school kids
Sometimes they try to hire lots of employees - meaning less bours for everyone else
review_cons:
It can be very boring sometimes.
The managers are usually pretty good but when they're bad, they're really bad. 
The pay is basically minimum wage.
review_advice_mgmt: The regional management needs to go easier on the store managers.

review_title: Fun, humbling, informative, and overall great experience.
review_pros: Flexible hours for students, you meet great people, and is a easy job to accommodation to.
review_cons: Fast paced and sometimes stressful.
review_advice_mgmt: Have more respect for floor models.

review_title: Lots of hard work and long hours, surrounded by a beautiful setting and beautiful people.
review_pros:
Awesome campus
Amazing cafeteria
People are typically young, outgoing and have interesting backstories
You get to wear A&F, Hollister and Gilly Hicks to work everyday.  This means shorts when it's warm!
Lots of campus events and after hours get-togethers
review_cons:
Long, hard hours (depending on your position, average is probably 53-ish hours a week)
High expectations of quality, sometimes impossibly high
If you don't fit the A&F mold, it is likely that you will feel like an outcast

Truthfully, the HR department here is scary.  There really is no typical HR team that you would find at any other company of this magnitude (which is ridiculous, by the way), but instead, we have a a large recruiting team and they are looked at as HR.  Recruiting for this company is frightening as it is - just read the other reviews - but the fact that this is the team that sets the standards for the company says a lot about expectations.  If you are not impossibly outgoing, full of energy, ready to schmooze and party with your superiors, (and let's face it, being skinny seems to be a requirement), then you're going to have a hard time here.  That is the truth of the matter.

review_pros: Great opportunities for improvement. Casual work attire, not to be confused with environment which is far from casual!
review_cons: Work/life balance is non-existant, turnover is very high.

review_title: Good but unable to promote for "look" reasons
review_pros:
Good atmosphere
young people
fun while working
review_cons:
hard work is not always recognize
your position depends on how good you look
look policy
review_advice_mgmt: Efficient people, working hard for the complany should get promoted if they like to no matter what they look like

review_pros: Not a stressful job, flexible hours
review_cons: Required to purchase new, company brand clothes to wear to work every couple months

review_title: Enviornment and people make work enjoyable but everyone is underpaid
review_pros:
You can get promoted fast in this company; especially if you are willing to move and relocate. 
Opportunites all over the globe. 
The job is really hands on- not stuck at a desk. 
Keeps you youthful being around a bunch of kids in high school and college- promotes a fun/laid back work enviornment.
review_cons:
On your feet all day. 
Everyone is underpaid- especially for all the requirements they are looking for in an associate (both management & associates). 
Hours and work schedule (have to work at least one weekend day). 
Don't have major holidays off.

review_title: Hours few and far in between, low pay.
review_pros: Get certain clothes half off, get to wear a cute outfit to work, and have a fun work environment
review_cons: Few hours to be had, they have "call in" shifts where they'll schedule you a shift and if you receive a phone call you have to go in, if not you don't. Those are relatively inconvenient because if you don't get a call you waste 4 hours waiting on a call. Time consuming work that has to be done before you leave with low pay. For example, I was once scheduled to leave at 10 (the mall closed at 9) and I didn't actually end up leaving until 1 because of the stuff they wanted me to do before I left.

review_title: Floor model easiest, best job ever for any 16 y/o
review_pros: I worked there until my first year of college as a floor model, the pay wasn't that good, but it was fun, easy, and scheduling worked around my life
review_cons: Bad pay, you'll make minimum wage the majority of the time you work there, even when you get promoted your pay only goes up a few cents, and you have to buy a bunch of different clothes from there each season, you get 30% off and most high school kids are spending their money on clothes anyway, but if you're over 18 and have real responsibilities, this isn't a job you want.

review_pros: There are some good days and then there are those horrible days. Sometimes its very laid back. Some of the people you work with can make your job worth it. The hours are very flexible and you can easily get someone to cover your shift.
review_cons: The managers have preferences and suck at distributing hours. Models complain so much and they stick this weird idea in their heads that they actually think the are "models". There is no real authority, i have no idea how this company is still running. Everything is supper expensive and we have to pay for our own uniforms every 3 months
review_advice_mgmt: Keep your stuff together. Why don't you worry about the people running your company and let older people in to work instead of these moronic high school idots who have caca for brains. That is all...

review_pros: easy work , easy money , friendly environment
review_cons: boring . the wage is not good enough , you will not learn any new thing

review_pros: Excellent discounts, and fun atmosphere
review_cons: Pay could be a hang up for some. Work loads maybe piled on.
review_advice_mgmt: communicate

review_pros:
First and foremost, fellow employees made the job enjoyable.
Being part of a "club". There's a special niche feeling about working there.
review_cons:
Although appealing at first, the music and the smell become overbearing. 
Duties on the floor are way too structured. You're assigned to one room and can't leave it.
Worst of all, the tag lines as people enter and leave are mandatory and exhausting. You feel like a robot.
review_advice_mgmt: Any greeting will do. It doesn't have to be "Hey, what's going on?!" word for word.

review_pros:

-fun enviorment
review_cons:

-not enough to do on slow days

review_pros: Fun environment and laid back
review_cons: Pay and they don't let you have breaks
review_advice_mgmt: Stop being lazy

review_pros: Coworkers are great, some managers are good, flexible scheduling
review_cons: Having to pay for new clothes every 2 months, store layout is awful, folding must be absolutely perfect
review_advice_mgmt: Ditch the ridiculous "look policy", choose practicality over the "style" of the store

review_title: Great place to work part time
review_pros:
Flexible Scheduling
Likable Staff
Great Discounts
Good Dresscode
Fun Management
Cool Customers
review_cons:
Affirmative Action
Low Wages
Uglier Hires since the Law Suit
review_advice_mgmt: Ever since the lawsuit I've noticed they've been hiring uglier people just to not be discriminatory which in my opinion drags down the status of the brand. When I first started working there the lawsuit hadn't happened and we were busier than ever and the entire staff was very attractive, but since than we've gone down in sales and people who aren't into the brand as a whole shouldn't work their in my opinion and all the "newer" employees have trouble meeting dresscode because they don't even own abercrombie, which in my opinion makes you unfit to work their if you can't even afford or like the brand.

review_title: Not what they claim to be.
review_pros: Benefits, salary ,  beautiful work place ,Most people are nice.
review_cons: Very incompetent management . HR does not care about people's issues.

review_pros:
- good benefits - medical, dental, vision, 401k
- friendly co-workers and supervisors/managers (in the main)
- soft attendance policy IMO.  You have to work hard to get fired for poor attendance.
- discount at AF, Hollister, Gilly Hicks, and kids stores
- recently went to a four day workweek (10 hr. shifts), which gives you a three day weekend 
- on campus gym
- I've seen complaints about the home office HR, but the HR team that handles the distribution centers is great, very helpful and responsive in my experience
review_cons:
- They've started farming out a lot of work to a temp agency, which keeps their costs down and our wages low
- high supervisor turnover rate. My supervisors have lasted, on average, less than a year before they quit or are rotated out.  They rotate supervisors constantly, and many don't last very long because of the hours.  This is bad when it comes to getting your annual reviews and raises.  It also means you often know more about your department than your supervisor.
- Senior management.  They tried to consolidate everything into one DC, encountered all kinds of problems, and the hourly employees paid for it.  The difficulties meant we lost our summer (2012), working six days a week for nine straight weeks.  The point man on the consolidation "left" the company, and they decided to keep both distribution centers.
- During the Christmas season and summer you will be working a lot of OT weekends.  So if you like spending time with friends and family during the holidays or those summer weekend nights, forget about it
- low low low pay.  The starting wage when I was hired many years ago was $9.30/hr.  It's still $9.30/hr.  Warehouses all over central Ohio have raised their base pay, but not AF.
- mind numbingly repetitive job no matter what department you're in
- dirty and very noisy work environment.  Lots of atmospheric particulate matter - you blow your nose at the end of an 11 hour shift and the discharge is black
- The jobs I've had have been physically demanding, and after so many years you are worn out.
- I work only in the distribution centers, but from what I've seen of the corporate home office (HO), they hire relatively young and good looking people, work them until they burn out and leave, then replace them with someone else relatively young and good looking, then repeat.  They have a high turnover rate.  The CEO has said he likes to hire employees close to the age of their target customer, and the grueling hours the HO employees work seem to be part of the strategy to keep a young work force.  Either that or a young HO work force is an unintended consequence of the hours they are expected to work.  The HO people that I've encountered have all been very nice.
review_advice_mgmt: less supervisor rotation, across the board rate raise is long overdue especially considering the fluid production standards

review_title: Not the best place to work at
review_pros: You actually meet some decent people. If you are a shopper and actually like ANF's clothes, you can see and hear about the upcoming sales and clearances.
review_cons: All the managers have been poorly trained and have no idea how to run the store properly. The music is way too loud for no reason. The backroom's music is so random and only one CD is allowed to be played. The managers don't do any work, even when it's clear that there is a low supply of workers.
review_advice_mgmt: Train your employees better, and be reasonable with certain regulations.

review_pros: Really easy work and fun crowd to work with
review_cons: The company is really superficial
review_advice_mgmt: Start to act like real human beings and rating your workers on their looks instead of quality

review_title: Just a job to get extra money

review_cons: Managers at times had to be strict on us
review_advice_mgmt: Give better hours to employees

review_pros:
easy job
super flexible when it comes to scheduling
the managers and other part timers are awesome (well most of them at least)
employee discount is decent, 30% off regular priced items for part timers, managers and other full time employees get 40%
your discount also works at Hollister (but is only 20%), and Gilly Hicks (there aren't any stores near me so idk what the discount is).

review_title: shallow company. no room for progression
review_pros: literally the easiest job on the planet, essentially you need the skill set of a monkey!!! as a cast o' you are pretty much given free reign on your schedule and they dont care if you dont show up because they cant fire you :), great if you want a job that you can decide when to work and when not to, good way to build experience on your resume .. not that you will actually gain anything of value. Impact system is great.
review_cons: minimum wage, no commission, DM's are horrible... like making staff cry horrible, prepare to live a life of no make up, ripped jeans and flip flops (which make your feet hurt), very biased models treated very differently to impact (especially cast o')

review_pros:

review_cons:

- If you aren't "cool" or good looking enough, you'll hit a glass ceiling.  Lots of favoritism in this as well.
- For the most part, company views employees as expendable.  A new crop of recent graduates looking for jobs are out there for them and the don't really value your time with them.
review_advice_mgmt:

- Honesty with people.  If someone isn't going to get that next level job they want, just tell them.  Some will be fine with the job they are in or can look at another route up in the company.  
- Move people where they want to be moved instead of wherever you need a quick fix.

review_pros: Very flexible work schedule and great team environment.
review_cons: None I wish to share.

review_title: Pretty much what you see at the store.
review_pros: Surrounded by people your age. Not grueling hard work.
review_cons: They hire a lot of people and give really bad hours. You can't wear nail polish or makeup or jewelry. And your toes have to be colored pink red or french tip.
review_advice_mgmt: need more hours.

review_pros: The work in itself is extremely easy, and it can be a very fun work environment - you're always surrounded by young, attractive, charismatic people.
review_cons:
The company is shameless in the way it manipulates and uses its employees. There is a constant pressure to recruit more, better looking employees (when at my store we were grossly overstaffed and had more than twice the employees we were supposed to) and to fire employees who didn't get 'approved.' (Or, more commonly, to make life hell for them until they voluntarily left.) In my district there was a competition to see if we could recruit enough to completely turn over our staff every 4 months. This is a) nearly impossible and b) no way to actually run a business.

As for professional development, it is what you make of it. If you make a conscious, individual effort to learn logistics and management, then it's possible that you will. However, the company doesn't actually evaluate their managers based on running the store, but on how many 'approved' models they recruit. Because of this, your store manager (and probably district manager) will be hopelessly inept and you will spend a lot of time cleaning up after them or enduring their awful scheduling and management mistakes. (They were promoted for their recruiting skills, NOT their management abilities.) I was literally told, word for word, after my 6 month interview; "You're doing great on all the stuff we talked about here, but.. honestly, none of it matters. Just get more approvals."

Because of this single-minded focus on recruiting, customer service is extraordinarily bad. The company doesn't care about the customer experience, so no customer complaints are followed up on and you as a manager have no power to fix difficult situations. So your 'customer service' experience will be completely limited to just hearing irate mothers scream at you about your horrible policies and store atmosphere every day and being able to do nothing whatsoever for them.

These kinds of decisions explain why the company is doing so poorly financially, and they show absolutely no sign of being willing to change. And finally, when I turned in my notice that I would be leaving the company, I was fired two days into that notice. After consulting other former managers, this is apparently the norm for A&F; a sort of "you can't leave us, we're leaving you" response. That last event in a very long line of unprofessional conduct confirmed that I had made the right decision.

review_pros: laid back, flexible hours, easy job assignments
review_cons: boring, costly uniforms, dark and loud environment
review_advice_mgmt: more conscious of employees

review_pros: - Coming from mom-and-pop/small business retail experiences only, this job helped me get a good feel of what corporate retail is like.
review_cons:
- Very low pay (I believe it was min. wage when I was there?) with very few hours (only about one to two 4-hour shifts a week)
- Strict dress code: you had to wear all of their clothes only, and they had to be the "seasonal" color (ex: navy blue and white in winter, yellow and green in spring/summer,etc), only "natural" looking hair in "natural" hair styles, only clear or pink nail polish ... All of that can be really hard to keep track of and follow when most of the people who work there are 17-18 year old kids.

review_title: Grateful for the opportunities yet getting burned out
review_pros: Quick promotion opportunities, Promotes from within, vast National and International opportunities, relaxed environment, young people, well know brand that's easy to sell, solid training program
review_cons: Pay is generally below the median average for most retail management positions in other companies, very structured and very little room to implement own ideas
review_advice_mgmt: Lighten up. Demand better pay for your hard working managers. Yours expectations are high, and yes attainable, but sometimes it takes huge sacrifice and those who outshine in tough situations should be rewarded and recognized more often.

review_pros: Fun work environment. Great learning experience.
review_cons: High management turnover. Holiday work schedule.

review_title: Used to love my job, now it is stressful and unenjoyable
review_pros: Good benefits. Good pay. Get to meet new people through the work. If you like the clothing, you would like the AAA's. Discounts at full price stores sometimes even up to 50% off.
review_cons: Not flexible with hours like they say they are. They only are if you are a part-time employee. There is no trust in the managers because they will take what you say to them and tell the whole entire staff when they are supposed to be "professional." They do not have a certain job description to follow so expect to do everything. If you do no finish your tasks for the night, you will be in trouble. Your job includes marketing, cleaning, shipment, training, filling, go-backs, back stocking, and cash wrap all in a 6 hour shift. They do not give you the proper amount of hours to finish your task so you are constantly stressed over a job not a career. Also you need to buy new AAA's (work clothes) every three months. They are very strict about the look policy. Every three months I was spending up to $200 on work clothes.
review_advice_mgmt: Need to be more flexible to other ideas. Also need to respect your employees more. Need to listen to other inputs of employees (even if they are on a lower level of management) Also micro managing everything is aggravating. Professional behavior needs to be worked on. Too much drama is caused because of catty behavior and gossiping about others. Outlets should have set guidelines instead of just what one "thinks" is right.

review_pros: Extensive management training program that covers a wide variety of topics including HR, loss prevention, store experience, recruiting, people development, customer service, etc. You are put into situations that will drain the life out of you with goals that are impossible to achieve but are great learning experiences to develop management skills.
review_cons: A&F is obsessive about certain aspects of "store experience" to the point where sales and customer service are sacrificed for, as an example, perfectly folded stacks of 25+ shirts. Upper management seem incapable of staffing their stores with managers (probably because the pay is ridiculously low for a job that requires a 4-year degree) but don't allow extra hours of labor to compensate. Opinions on how to run the business more effectively have no place here besides small, insignificant ideas here and there. Work turns into a daily battle of trying to keep presentations folded while cheap, inconsiderate customers tear through stacks of 25+ shirts. There is little room for advancement and promotions are extremely competitive.
review_advice_mgmt: Upper management must be more open to walking into a store as they are run on a day to day basis and accept that there are issues with the way business is run at the store level. Be realistic about the state of the company at that level and maybe we wouldn't be forced to cut hours drastically across the board to compensate for ridiculous over expenditures in labor wages to prepare for visits.

review_pros:
- You get to know the American structure of a company
- Possibility to go abroad
- Correct payment
review_cons:
- Really picky on details
- There is no possibility to work there with a self-employed business or make invoices as one
review_advice_mgmt: Loads of models are self-employed, let them make invoices for tax-management

review_pros:
- Company Discounts
- Great music
- Great starting job
review_cons:
- Lack of consistent time (time/hours varies)
- At least one "on call" shift
- Poor scheduling on store management (depending on manager and location)

review_title: Nice place to work for a high school-er.
review_pros: All the workers become friends and you get 40% off certain items as an employee.
review_cons: Cheesy greeting for floor models. Scheduled on days you are unable to.

review_pros: This company has a great program for people just starting out and trying to get in the field. I started out as an MIT. Once I completed the program I was immediately an assistant manager. Less than a year later I got my own store and less than a year from that I am now running the top store in my state. There is not much room to grow after that.
review_cons: After you are the store manager of one of the top Abercrombie's in the state you pretty much have to wait forever to get a promotion. There are 2 different routs you can go. Either district manager or home office.  For Dustrict manager you generally would have to be in that same top performing store for at least 5 years. For home office they won't recommend you unless you store is perfect. (Never happens) All in all it is a good short time company, not a lifetime career. Ex. They have only had 1 person retire from the company.

review_pros: -if they like you and you have a long-term interest in the company, they'll do what they have to in order to move you up
review_cons: -they don't care about your life outside of the company and will do what they can to rid you of your outside distractions (i.e. school)
review_advice_mgmt: treat the little people better!

review_title: Worst company I have ever worked for..
review_pros:
- Responsibility - they will give you lots of it
 - High pay
review_cons:
- Highly political work atmosphere 
 - Entire company is inefficient
 - Top management treats employees very poorly
 - Low morale - everyone on my team is counting down the days until their contract is over so they can quit. 
 - Absolutely NO work/life balance

review_title: Great job while in school, not a place to build a career.
review_pros: Fun atmosphere and fun people.
review_cons: Poor pay, poor advancement opportunities, policies that work against the costumer creating issues between employees and customers.
review_advice_mgmt: Invest in you employees, focus on your customers.

review_pros:
- You leave work smelling good
-Discount
review_cons:
-Little to no hours if you don't fit in with them, they're all asian and if you're not then they won't talk to you
-They cut shifts the day of
-They never ever treat you with respect
-They spend more time looking in the mirror than working
review_advice_mgmt: Get over yourselves and actually do your job

review_pros: Almost all of your colleagues are under 30, which doesn't make you feel old right after college. It's located on beautiful grounds in Ohio (the occasional deer is visible from your window at work). You have tremendous exposure to all aspects of merchandising from the very beginning and you present directly to the CEO after only a few months. The base salary is what an average family makes in Ohio and if you're good, it can grow quickly. And after about 2 years, you will have the ability to travel to the factories that make your garments, most are located in South and East Asia. The food in the cafe is pretty good and there are exercise facilities directly on the premises (though I never used them).
review_cons:
In their brochure they tell you it's a "diva-free" zone, which to anyone with a brain should mean "there are a ton of divas here." Why else would they make such a statement. 

As a merchant, you are at the center of everything and responsible for everything. Which means, you will always be the first person to blame when something goes wrong in the very long and complicated supply chain. You are responsible for every part of design, costing, planning, production, transportation, and sales. It's truly too much work for any one person and there used to be more jobs (usually two people for one brand) before they cut jobs in the recession.  

Your manager will decide your life at Abercrombie. I was unfortunate to get truly one of the worst (and there are a lot of bad ones). There is no training on how to manage there, it's just the person personal style. Some people are awesome and some are terrible. This person will decide himself or herself if you are good or not. Also, shakeups happen all the time. People get moved too often and it disrupts teamwork. 

The worst thing is that even in the rare case you succeed (they hire so many people not because they are growing, but because so many new people quit after their contracts are up--and some pay out their contracts to quit beforehand, even in a recession) you likely won't last for long. As the CEO is whimsical and he treats people like the clothes themselves, what's hot today is tomorrow's trash. So the higher you go up the chain, the more likely you are to be lose your job. My terrible manager prayed NOT to be promoted, because he feared the extra responsibility and losing the job stability of being on the bottom. 

Overall, it's a good place to get some experience right out of college, but only a very small percentage make it a career. It's meant to beat people up until they quit, so they can hire new "Fresh and young" faces,which keeps the brand closer to the target age. If you are over 30 at A&F, most likely, you are not in merchandising. It's impossible to be a merchant and have a family, as you work about 11 hours on average a day, can it be more, and ten is the minimum they ask every day (8am-6pm) is the best you'll get.
review_advice_mgmt: Management knows what the problems are, but they keep things this way because the whole place is designed to weed out people to keep the place full of "fresh eyes" for the clothes. So it's not worth giving advice to management.

review_pros:
It becomes more bearable once you get to know your co-workers.
Flexible schedules!
review_cons: So many rules! It is ironic that they are big on diversity but force us all to dress and look the same.
review_advice_mgmt: Train your managers better. Most of the new managers seem to know nothing.

review_pros: hires management with no previous experience, good opportunity to get your feet wet, good benefits, young and attractive coworkers
review_cons: salary not competitive, long hours, work holidays, very structured setting, loud music nonstop on the sales floor and fragrance not for everyone, must recruit/hire new employees and new managers based on looks

review_title: Decent part time job - no long term career
review_pros: help you work around day to day duties and responsibilities
review_cons: no real career opportunities, pay is terrible

review_title: Very monotonous but a lot of fun people
review_pros:
Fun people 
Good atmosphere 
Flexible hours
review_cons:
Could be boring folding clothes over and over 
Frustrating customers at times

review_pros: It's a good place to start, maybe in high school as a first job. The managers are usually nice and understanding. They call you the day before you're scheduled to let you know the time you work the next day or leave you a voicemail message. Not a great job, but It's not hard work at all.
review_cons: They pay minimum wage and unless you're employed full time it's hard to get a raise with this company and you'll have to be there for a long time before that's even a possibility. Doesn't pay well.
review_advice_mgmt: Managers deal with a lot and they do very good at their job. They're usually young and don't last over a year before deciding to go back to college instead.

review_pros: Good looking employees, flexible hours (when they give it to you), and laid back staff.  Fun environment.
review_cons: Pay is terrible, doing nothing for hours, terrible hours, no raises.  Overall not really a place that I'd like to work at again.
review_advice_mgmt: Speak to corporate about raising hourly wage

review_title: Summer Internship at Abercrombie and Fitch
review_pros: Great experience for one's resume during summer internship.  Got a lot of great exposure to what working at the company would be like
review_cons: Sometimes supervisors don't have enough managerial experience.

review_title: Great as a part timer. Not so sure about full time yet.
review_pros: Flexible hours and fun coworkers as a part time associate.
review_cons: Very stressful at times due to situations beyond your control.
review_advice_mgmt: Try not to abandon new people. Makes it very difficult for them to want to be there when they aren't being trained.

review_pros:
- The work is really easy and you can socialize while doing it.
- Easygoing atmosphere.
review_cons:
-  You only get a shift, (or two if you're lucky) every week.
- You have to buy Abercrombie & Fitch's latest clothes in order to work there. Even with the 40% of discount it's really expensive.
Even though I only bought a pair of pants, the required flip-flops, and two shirts that I rotated, by the end of a Summer working at Abercrombie and Fitch I just about broke even. The store changes it's required look every season to ensure that the store associates have to buy more clothes on a regular basis. Store Managers have hiring quotas for a reason: if they make each employee buy several items to be "in dress code" and then only give them a shift a week, the store will make money off of their employees. I'm not sure if all Abercrombie stores are run this way, but all of my friends who have worked at the local Abercrombie have had the exact same experience. Don't work here!
- Oh, and I have been routinely required to work 45 minutes to an hour off of the clock, after my shift is over, in order to finish a folding project. That's just plain illegal!

review_title: Pretty laid back and fun if you like to fold clothes.
review_pros: Fun people to be around. Get a discount on clothes.
review_cons: People constantly calling in. Pretty small check depending on how long you work.
review_advice_mgmt: Less fragrance sprayed in the stores.

review_pros: A&F offers a great salary, and a photogenic atmosphere. The holiday parties and quarterly promotions are one of a kind.
review_cons: Bad habits of irresponsible hiring- i.e. completely under qualified managers. Very strict on what you are allowed to wear to work-- you are "suggested" to wear the brand, but in reality you must wear the brand (or try to fit into the small sizes).

review_pros: employees, atmosphere, discount, overall great
review_cons: non that i can think of
review_advice_mgmt: open more stores

review_title: Learn as much about managing/leading people as possible, then run for the hills.
review_pros:
-I have been wanting to write a formal review of this company for years now. Anyone who is seriously considering working for them, this will be a factual account of what it is like. I worked part-time all over Oregon and CA for five years (high school-college), and went from MIT-AM-SM in 1.5 years. 

-If you are halfway intelligent, you will immediately realize it is not hard to run these stores. Everything you need is provided by a giant manual regarding policies (so no creativity allowed) for operations, and another huge binder for anything visually related.  If you are "great looking" i.e. very naturally beautiful or handsome (think fashion model type of look) you will move up faster than someone who is far more qualified to run a business than you. You will be tired from standing and walking all day wearing flip flops. Tip: Wear the style of shoe they allow and place insoles in them. It will absolutely save you, and make you better able to enjoy what you're doing.  You will be expected to "recruit" attractive people daily whether it be in the mall, or at a local college campus, and have interviews bi-weekly to interview people you already know youre hiring anyway.  You will have DM (weekly) and RM (bi-monthly or quarterly) visits that will not want to discuss business strategy, or cost saving methods, hours, people development, or basically anything business related.  As long as you have "cast of" quality employees (best looking) you can run way below sales plans and still be promoted and praised. 

-There will be a lot of difficult employees to work for.  Winey managers at times, winey sales staff, people not showing up for shifts (be smart, youre hiring high schoolers and college kids so expect this from time to time and be ready to set a clear expectation from the start), and stockroom kids (impact team) that steal, slack, and also do not show up.  This is where you can become an excellent leader of a future company. You will learn do deal with these things, manage them, execute terminations, one-on-ones, motivate troubled employees into hard workers, etc. Many are unable to do it. Focus on your strong managers development, know which other managers can't cut it (being able to recognize who doesn't really want to be there to develop their future skills, and are just using this as "full time job with benefits" is one thing to work on), let the high turnover kids (part-timers) float in and out in their natural Crombie cycles. 

-If you can be seen as a fair, friendly, cool, hip boss that can get their work done, have tough conversations, and still act like a gentleman..Your store will run itself and your staff will smile and have fun. People want to work for leaders like Ive just described.   

-You will probably resent the company after some time.  The miserable pay for the amount of hours and work you put in will anger you. Lack of recognition from superiors on excellent work you are proud of will upset you, when they only want to discuss recruiting beautiful faces. These are the times to manage your own stress, and learn about your own style, stresses, and how to overcome them. Holidays, thanksgiving, sales, black friday, etc will all beat you down. You will be micro managed. Learn how to manage this. 

-Oh yeah, they actually do have nice benefits insurance wise. I always thought they were trying to keep turnover low with this.

-In summary for Pros: if you're in high school or college, want to have fun, work with good looking people, and have a nice way to find parties, this is great for you! Otherwise, work somewhere else. If you are able to profile people and have no problem sorting out "normal" people from "amazing" without ever feeling mean or cruel, you will do great here!
review_cons:
-There honestly are too many cons about these guys to list. Some you cannot turn into a positive. The sadness you see on peoples faces when they ask for a job when your DM tells them "we're not hiring at the moment" then makes a snide remark about them as theyre walking away, still able to hear whats going on is heart breaking.  All DMs I worked with (at least 12 over my entire career with them) were like this.  

-Seeing all your best, hard-working, money making employees hours forced cut time and time again by your boss because "she is better looking and needs to work more" is impossible to comprehend in a profit center. That was what did it for me.  

-This company is a dying trend in the States. Stores are constantly closing here. Internationally yes, they are doing alright for the moment (think China). Unless you want to learn to speak another language quickly (which would set you up nicely for a much better paying job) you have little hope to be moved over seas anymore. 

-The CEO. Just read about him for yourself. You would be representing HIS ideals and practices. 

-The other reviews do a solid job describing personal growth in the company. Once an SM, be ready to wait.
review_advice_mgmt: H&M, American Apparel, etc are successful and stealing your market share for a reason. I'd look into changing your business model even a slight amount and getting away (at least here) from the "preppy" nonsense of the 90's and earlier 2000s. You were at one time a non sale brand. You changed that. Change something else to help you. I promise you, your core customer (international) will not care if you add in more modern styles.

review_title: If fast paste monotonous work, cliques, and slow employee empowerment is what you're into this is the place to work.
review_pros: I guess you can say that one pro would be the discount on clothing that all employees receive but it isn't worth spending you few peanuts you get from your paycheck.
review_cons: There are a lot of cons with this company. Its seemingly ran on a 13 year olds dream to continually have the coolest clothes in town and the same kind of business aspects you'd expect from a company ran by said 13 year olds.

review_title: It was a great first job
review_pros:
Fun people
Easy job
Very laid-back culture
review_cons:
Folding to standard. 
Very political
Depending on the manager and whether or not they like you you would get hours.

review_title: Fun Culture, great opportunity, high pressure
review_pros: If you work hard, you get promoted and the people there are amazing.  Compensation and benefits are on the high end and it's a perfect place for someone out of college.
review_cons: MJ is an inconsistent leader and lacks long term vision.  He will tear people to shreds in public when they don't agree with him.
review_advice_mgmt: Replace Mike with a competent CEO, listen more to the organization.

paid min wage

review_pros:
-Schedule flexibility: if you really needed a certain day off, you can easily switch your working days and off days with another manager just as long as he/she is willing to.
-Health benefits: I haven't signed up myself because I lost the opportunity to but my store manager told me the benefits are great.
review_cons: -The company seeks to hire associates who adhere to the look policy. Therefore, managers may work with associates who may fit the company's look but not necessarily have working experience. Working with associates who may be as young as high school students tend to have less responsibilities and those who aren't high school students. Thus, they may not even show up for their shifts.
review_advice_mgmt:
I understand the company seeks to hire associate who fit the company's brand and looks. However, this does not create the most effective and productive working experience since the basis of employment is not working experience or how well he/she can carry out a given task. 
As someone who has worked at the kids store, pumping up the volume seemed unnecessary. Most of the customers were parents and most had difficulty with the music.

review_title: smart marketing based on the use of youthful energy
review_pros: good experience for entry level management, good benefits.
review_cons: hard work, stressful, loud music and not non normalized hours.
review_advice_mgmt: this is not just a job, this is style. If you are like this lifestyle, you will have a good carrier in this company, if this is not your style, you will have a headache.

review_pros: Fun employees, Great discount, Movement of promotion is high, and training program is the best.
review_cons: long hours and strict rules
review_advice_mgmt:
Dear Upper Management,

Please promote the hard workers and not just the suckups.

Thanks.

review_title: a good place to work with people who have different backgrounds.
review_pros: Can get employ discount although not much. Work is challenging.
review_cons: need to finish a lot work in every shift.
review_advice_mgmt: The management can be finer.

review_pros: you meet some great people, you're managers are mostly around your age so you definitely  can connect with them easily. The job is very easy, you just walk around, greet people, and fold clothes.
review_cons: the look policy of the company is a little too demanding. also you don't have much room for growth and promotions. you're stuck in the same position.
review_advice_mgmt: You should really consider hiring undergraduates as managers, many are definitely qualified for the position. you guys require a four year college degree, for not a very hard job.

review_pros:
-Great People to work with
-Energetic, fun atmosphere
review_cons:
Loud (Too Noisy)
Dark
Hiring based on Looks
review_advice_mgmt: Hiring practices are not in the best interest of the person at heart.  The associates and managers that I know, for the most part, are great not because of their looks but because of who they are.  There are great people who care about others and often I see some great people not get hired because they didn't meet the standard look.  Overall I gained some valuable experience as A&F was the company that gave me the first shot at a professional and I met some great people who put the needs of others first before themselves and those are the people I enjoy to work with.  Sure there are pros and cons to the job and overall I thank A&F for giving me the chance to grow and learn about myself in ways that will only help me further in my career.

review_pros: Great discount and a chance to meet a lot of great looking people. Learn a lot in networking, recruiting, and visual excellence!
review_cons: Don't teach the numbers of retail, only care about your appearance, will fire you for anything they dont value their employees

review_title: fun until the start of your 4th week!

-discounts on clothing
-friendly kids working for you
review_cons:

-closing mondays at 1130pm, coming in at 8am for mandatory meeting and closing that same day -11
review_advice_mgmt:

-give incentives for recoveries made

review_pros:
Help build confidence and become a more outgoing person ingeneral.

review_title: fun to work but not enough hours available
review_pros: it's a fun atmosphere, you get to meet to new people, easy job

review_title: I worked for Abercrombie and Fitch for 7 years and loved it.
review_pros: People, training resources, environment, excitement, management is passionate about product and company goals, extremely high standards for people, and merchandise, visual presentations,
review_cons: Work/life balance, salary, must relocate to move up in the corporation, high stress
review_advice_mgmt: Be more competitive with salaries, offer more incentives

review_pros: The associates and other managers employed in my store were a saving grace of this job. In addition, the benefits were comprehensive.
review_cons:
The hours and pay suck--I worked weekends and nights as an impact assistant manager, so it was nearly impossible to have a personal life outside of work. The company also treats their employees poorly and has terrible values. I was frequently told to only hire attractive people for part-time and management positions. The company does not care if people are hard-working or reliable, just that they "fit the look". It's a revolving door of employees as the company pushes recruiting very hard, but then makes no effort to retain employees (during my 10 months there, I saw 6 managers quit). Furthermore, the company has obviously been hit hard with the recession (and with their declining popularity in general) as they gave stores barely any hours and are STRICT on each store hitting their required hours exactly. You will get your ass handed to you if you go over, even an hour. For instance, on busy Saturday afternoons, we would typically only have 3 associates working at a time and 2 managers. Since everything in the store must be "perfectly" folded, this made it difficult to close the store within the hours budgeted and according to company standards. Having so few associates at a time and ridiculous policies also made for angry and frustrated customers. 

You're not technically required to wear the company's clothing, but as a manager, I was pretty much forced to purchase and wear the company's clothing to work. It wouldn't have been a problem if I had received the clothes for free, but I only got a 40% discount, which sounds like a lot... But when you don't make that much, the clothes are expensive, and they have new looks every two months, it is a lot of money. 

The company has ridiculous policies and standards across the board, and it has dumbed down the manager's role so that a monkey could do it (a checklist for the day would print out every morning from corporate). Overall, it was a terrible experience for me.
review_advice_mgmt: Treat your employees like people. Retail jobs in general have bad pay and hours, but make it up to employees by giving them other perks and treating them well. It will pay off in the long run. Also, turn down the AWFUL music and stop spraying the store so much... you might actually start getting customers back.

review_pros:
good discount 30-50% off
good looking people
easy job
flexible schedule
review_cons:
little to no hours 
forced to buy their clothes
being on call
review_advice_mgmt: Reward those who have been loyal to the company

review_pros: you get 30% off clothing with the quarterly 50% so you can always wear the new styles, online management of hours/days off, flexible.
review_cons: managers aren't much more experienced than you, the work day goes by really slow, all you do is fold clothes and say "hey what's up" to whoever walks in, no room for growth, horrible pay, retail hours.
review_advice_mgmt: instead of making us re-apply to be a manager you should look to those who have worked hardest and longest.

review_pros: The discount provided on new clothing
review_cons: Everything about this job is awful
review_advice_mgmt: Shut this business down

review_pros: managers are good, and the environment is very easy going
review_cons: alot of folding involved can get frustrating
review_advice_mgmt: good job, a little shallow though

review_pros:
I had a wonderful experience here. I started at Abercrombie kids when I was 17 and when the store was shut down, moved over to Abercrombie. It was mindless work with a great atmosphere and amazing people to work with. I liked the fact that the managers weren't much older than I was as they were easy to get along with but still very efficient at their job.  I worked here for 5 years and after going off to college I loved having the ability to still work when I came home on breaks and 
summer.
review_cons: I honestly don't have any cons! I loved working on the floor, register and assisting in floor designs. My only con is any position in retail where you're constantly refolding clothes, but you should know what you're getting in to!
review_advice_mgmt: The Champaign store has closed, and its been 6 years since I've left, but I had a fantastic experience here!

review_pros: The part time associates are great. I love all of my kids. Travel opportunities are also a pro.
review_cons: Very unorganized even though there are "standards". No one is on the same page. Micro management happens daily. Work/Life balance is non existent.
review_advice_mgmt: Pay more attention to the needs of the hard working managers that you have. Care about your managers work/life balance.

review_title: Fun place to work, but not much longevity for the future
review_pros:
Fun environment with employees being teens- 20s maybe 30s age range.  
It's a great right out of high school... college years job!
I loved the management when I first started working... but we won't talk about the "untrained/ unprofessional" management in this section.
The jobs are segregated to people who work in the front, the people who work in the back stock and the overnighters.  Each job title involves certain tasks and typically only the employee with the job title fulfills that particular task.  Your job is clear and concise.
review_cons:
It's a minimum wage + chump change kind of job.  Don't expect to make a ton and don't expect to move up very fast.  
There also are a lot of employees and there aren't a lot of hours, which however is somewhat strange because if you ever call in sick it's almost nearly impossible to find a cover.  You receive a company directory with HUNDREDS of names and numbers, but unless you have a close pact with friends there aren't many "strangers" willing to go in for you if you need someone last minute.
It can get tiring standing on your feet all day talking to hundreds of customers (both good, bad, and ugly), loud music, strong scent, dark, and dusty.
review_advice_mgmt: After the CEO remark, it might be a good idea to hire the "not so beautiful/ not so cool people"... There definitely is a negative light on the company.  Current customers don't mind as they are the "beautiful/ cool", but parents, prospective customers, and the "not so beautiful/ not so cool" have been voicing they're opinion.

review_title: overall, it was a good experience
review_pros: it had a lively atmosphere, which I enjoyed
review_cons: sometimes, the work hours were quite long
review_advice_mgmt: overall they did a solid job, I would not change anything

review_title: I worked as a seasonal Christmas employee and it was a pretty typical retail environment.
review_pros: At Christmas time the store was very busy, so the time passed quickly.  Also, you were on your feet the whole time so it was like a cardio workout.
review_cons: You had to wear their clothes, which is fine, but the employee discount was very little.  I bought one pair of jeans and wore them every time I worked until I got my first paycheck and got some khakis and mixed and matched about three shirts to make different outfits.  Also, they like you to layer your clothes so you wear as many of their items as possible.  And, you can only wear approved shoes which were on a chart in the break room.
review_advice_mgmt: Don't openly tell people we only hire attractive people---I actually heard a manager tell someone that!  I was only there temporarily, but I could sense that the managers (who weren't by any means model material) thought very highly of themselves.

review_title: It was a job, and I've made some really awesome friends there, the end.
review_pros: None. If you're looking for a job then it's only an ok job until you find a better one.
review_cons: You have to buy the clothes, your discount sucks, the pay rate sucks, and the music is too loud.
review_advice_mgmt: Minimum wage isn't enough pay, especially if college students are your target employees. And the AAA and regular discount should be better.

review_pros: good career advancement opportunities available
review_cons: restrictive atmosphere, loud music, limited staff personalization

review_title: Abercrombie works hard to equip all its employees with the necessary tools to succeed.
review_pros: Abercrombie has become a very proactive company to become more inclusive.  Truly hires people who think is a good fit and best represents the company.  Having great leaders to help those that are new to the company and supports them as best as possible.
review_cons: The team of part time personnel is quite large in numbers and getting to know everyone on a personal level to create a more welcoming feel.

review_pros:
-Young coworkers with similar interests.
-Discount on the clothes.
-Fairly easy job.

-Giving certain shifts to the "best looking" people. Favoring them.

review_cons:

review_pros: Allows you to gain experience managing a store and implementing strict standards. Working with fellow managers is usually a positive experience. In a mall setting, mostly in what would be your more affluent shopping areas.
review_cons: Long hours, low pay, little to no job security. Impossible visual and people standards. Little help from upper management. Holidays are horrendous. Many broken promises from district managers, hard to get promoted.

review_pros: You can choose your own schedule
review_cons: no one seems to take the job very seriously
review_advice_mgmt: should be more strict

review_pros: flexible hours, work with fun young people, laid back, easy tasks, make new friends
review_cons: malls are typically open late, your life smells like the currently promoted scent
review_advice_mgmt: have consistent store managers to uphold the store because theres a million different store managers and new ones and gone ones every season

review_pros:
~Physically attractive co-workers
~you wear jeans to work
~management hand picks staff, potentially you could build a staff of friends
~good management training program
review_cons:
~supervisors are underqualified to manage and overpressured to produce
~supervisors give false promises of promotions
~you work at the mall
~you have to keep buying clothes that are only appropriate for the mall
~even though you may think you're doing really well, your supervisor and his/her supervisor are slashing through employees to promote their favorite regardless of "measurables"
~Career opportunies are available if you are willing to be walked all over for years
~promote great values/RMs and DMs systematically oppose publicized values
~closing stores domestically
review_advice_mgmt: To the RMs and DMs: Realized that you are creating the future by highering so many young people.  It is pathetic that you direct each other to lie on your employee reviews and reports. You go in and change your employees passwords. You are morally bankrupt and you take advantage of 17 and 18 year olds.

review_title: I love working here, however the pay is horrible and only two people a year get a raise
review_pros: easy going, laid back, hours are okay depending on season
review_cons: Not a lot of raises, poor pay, not a trusting company, dictating

review_pros: the discount was alright I guess.. but still ended up being pretty expensive
review_cons: Minimun wage, lots of shop lifting takes place, managers don't treat the employees very well,  awful smell in store, and horrible hours

review_title: It was an "OK" experience. Not the best job in the world but the pay was good and worth it.
review_pros:
Good Pay. $9 an Hr. 

They have a Facebook Page for Impact team members so if you don't get a good amount of hours, go on the page and people give their shifts away all the time. 

You get assigned different things to do, not just be on the sales floor. Stock etc. 

Flexible Hours.
review_cons:
Sometimes they barely give you shifts. At times I was scheduled for one shift per week.

Managers can be nasty sometimes, and give you attitude for no reason.

Costumers have no manners. They destroy your neat pile without consideration.

If you don't like folding clothes then tough luck, they stress on neatness and keeping the section your in with good care which at times is nearly impossible.
 
They treat the models better than the Impact Associates. Some models are cool but others don't even help you and act like they are all that.
review_advice_mgmt: Get over yourselves.

review_title: Beautiful campus... great food... smart co-workers. That's it for the positives
review_pros:
Campus is breath-taking. The food in the cafe is delish (as it should because you either get this food or pack as the office is not located near anything... and it takes a zillion years to walk to your car).

A&F hires smart people from all around the globe. Salaries are high.
review_cons: ZERO work-life balance for the salaried folk. Embarrassing "company culture". Getting slammed in the media constantly. CEO is far too in the weeds. Creativity is not accepted. Get a job here maybe 1-2 years max.
review_advice_mgmt: Start embracing a creative, open-minded culture.

review_pros: Easy work environment, my coworkers were really outgoing and friendly. Management was also pretty nice, and we always got out early on closing shifts. The store was really clean and they always paid attention to and followed my availability requests. We were allowed to use cellphones on the sales floor without getting into too much trouble too, so that was nice. I was never really up front much, which is a reward, i got to fold clothes or ring up customers so my shifts always went by fairly quickly. Basically if you work hard and get stuff done, you get the best jobs to do around the store.
review_cons: They hire a ton of new people EVERY WEEK, so hours are spread pretty thin. There is a very high employee turnover rate. The store is incredibly loud, trying to have a conversation on the sales floor is pointless. I didn't feel like I got enough training - people I know who've worked there for years still don't know how to do stuff. You only get minimum wage, and if you're lucky, a maximum of twenty hours a week. They have a strong reliance on call in shifts, which is incredibly annoying and a pain because they only use you 20% of the time, but when they do use you, it's always unexpected. Sometimes closing took longer than it should because people goof off and talk - if you're a hard worker, expect to be singled out. They expect you to wear their ridiculously priced clothes even when you only work 10 hours a week.
review_advice_mgmt: Have two people in each sales room - especially upfront. It gets incredibly boring standing by a table of shirts that you've already folded 400 times. Less emphasis on the "Abercrombie look" would be nice - I like wearing jewelry and eyeliner.

review_pros: Very flexible schedule, and fun & friendly co-workers.
review_cons: Not the best chance to work your way up in the company, the company still likes to choose looks over work ethics in some places. Pay is terrible for the amount of work you are expected to do.
review_advice_mgmt: Start promoting within stores and give pay raises to more than just 2 people a year.

review_pros: Flexible, part-time, nice friendly atmosphere, good pay
review_cons: Some unexpected long shifts, which can actually be avoided.

review_title: I had this job for a few months in college
review_pros: Employees get a 30% discount on all full-priced clothing. However, the clothing is expensive considering the pay is minimum wage. Most of the employees were nice, friendly and easy going. Management was strict but cool.
review_cons: The music was annoying and played on repeat for months at at time. The pay is minimum wage. And working in retail was not fun for me

review_pros: Great part time job, flexible hours, met great friends!
