review_cons: I worked here for 4 years, during college for 2 years, and 2 years as a manager. The DM's treat you like crap and the only way you advance is by being a horrible person. The best managers usually end up quitting because their abilities aren't recognized by the higher ups. Every single manager I know who quit was pretty depressed before it. I usually worked 10-12 hour shifts every day, and not because I wasn't completing my work on time.
review_advice_mgmt: Learn a little respect. Don't call the employees ugly. Don't forbid them to take breaks during 13 hour shifts.

review_title: A tough environment but a good stepping stone to something else
review_pros: Young company, fun coworkers, you can get promoted fast if you have the look (meaning attractive, wholesome) and you are intelligent and hardworking. I made a lot of friends working there.
review_cons: Compromising ethics, hiring people based on looks and the sheer volume of things that you need to juggle and perfect. Upper management is extremely tough and expects perfection from your employees to the standards in your store. Everything in the store has a certain place, from the number of inches a zipper should be pulled down on a jacket to the amount of inches from the wall a table should be.
review_advice_mgmt: Pay your managers what they are worth, not half pay for overtime and give bonuses to managers for meeting their sales goals. Having contests where a few stores out of hundreds get bonuses for arbitrary plans doesn't motivate us. Turnover would be a thing of the past if you valued your management and even associates better. It is s really hard to recruit amazing looking people to work at minimum wage.

review_pros: Great atmosphere. Ive met many great people while employed for this company.
review_cons: Not for anyone who is a household provider or looking for set hours. Minimum wage. Hours vary, but rarely exceeds 20 hours per week. Management change frequently.
review_advice_mgmt: Lower the soundtrack and take it easy on the spritz.

review_pros:
Fun people and co-workers
flexable schedule
review_cons: pay is only at minimum wage. job requires you to have a bachelors in anything just to move up in the company. I worked with people who have been with the company for 6+ years and never gotten a raise. You have to buy your own uniforms, nothing is given to you. the employee discount is only 30% and no discount for sale items. managers are snobish. They look down on impact members and and yell if you aren't moving fast enough. Models are treated better than impact members, but if you aren't dress properly they will stick you in the back of the store with impact members. I overheard Mike Jeffries question why one of my co-workers was greeting. kind of insinuating that she wasn't good looking enough. overnight employees are paid more than day time employees, despite that we deal with customers, run go backs and do size checks all at the same time. Managers give out low key raises, so my best advise is kiss ass and make friends with manager
review_advice_mgmt: listen to your employees, stop being shallow

review_pros: Fun environment, great office, good dress code, great corporate parties, good employee discount, gym at office, great cafeteria, don't have to deal with hussle of downtown
review_cons: Ego company, not friendly, work you to death, ridiculous policies, don't give realistic job descriptions, cutthroat environment, move up by sucking up and drinking the corporate kool-aide.

review_title: Made lots of friends with coworkers
review_pros: Fun company to work for, the people are all really nice and lots of fun to be around. I enjoyed working in the stockroom and when I was needed on the floor it was fun too. The managers were all pretty nice in my store, although this experience varies by store. Even our district manager would make conversation with us, which isn't always the case in retail.
review_cons: There are (almost) never raises! I worked for over 2 years there and never saw more than 8 dollars an hour (minimum wage in my state). Customers can get really rude, and always have to complain about the music or the lighting, etc.

review_pros:
its a job right?
Ive meet some nice co workers
review_cons:
the spray is sprayed a lot on the floor and the back of the bottle says do not inhale... i was a visual associate 
hours suck
pay is too low, i did things that was other people's jobs
mean managers
no breaks on 5 hour shifts
review_advice_mgmt: be nicer to employees

review_pros: schedule is very flexible. the people you work there are fun and easy going.
review_cons: they do not offer enough hours to associates

review_pros: Great coworkers. Great environment. Easy job.
review_cons: being on my legs all day killed me and they had so many people working there, they put me "on call" so they only called in when they needed me or i called them when i wanted to work (which was everyday - which was kind of annoying).
review_advice_mgmt:
dont just hire any attractive person that walks in the door and actually give hours to those of us who need it.
and dont just make clothes for "average" people. Plus-sized people are people too.

review_pros: Fun people to work with in High School
review_cons: Pay was not great for amount of hours put into the store

review_pros: Co-Workers were really nice and managers were really great too.
review_cons: Can only wear their clothes and very strict about makeup, hair, etc.

review_pros: there are great career opportunities
review_cons: the pay is very minimal
review_advice_mgmt: it's a great place to get your foot in the door

review_title: Not the best, but not the worst either. There's a lot of work to be done, and not enough compensation.
review_pros:
Friendly environment
Semi-Flexible hours
Coworkers often become lifelong friends
review_cons:
Minimum wage pay
Not enough hours
Managers don't do much
review_advice_mgmt: Try to put less thought into the look of your employees and more into the well-being and actual skills of them. Higher pay would be great too, especially for those who do their job and don't just stand around during their shift.

review_pros: I loved the energy and the fact that it was led by youth for the youth
review_cons: It can be a bit unorganized at times. Also, uniforms should be given to employees...
review_advice_mgmt: organization in processing is key!

review_title: Should only be an option if you can't find a job after graduating.
review_pros: You will never get bored; there is always a ton of employees working, most of which are interesting and fun. Benefits are great - you get medical, dental, and vision. You have the opportunity to rise in the ranks quickly if you put the company first and have the right look. It's a great a stepping stone to other, more meaningful, jobs.
review_cons: Awful hours; i.e. closing until 11 and opening the following morning. Terrible, often times embarrassing policies. You are always under the gun, be it from the SM/DM/RM - if you are perfect you don't hear anything, but if you make the smallest of mistakes you will certainly hear about it. There is little no opportunity to show your individuality - everything is predetermined or automated by home office.
review_advice_mgmt: If you expect your management to be positive, talented, and well-educated (all managers must have a four-year degree), reflect that in their salary.

review_title: Great place to get your sales experience.
review_pros: Well trained managers, they made us feel comfortable working there. Great management skill as well. They showed me how to greet and solve general problems, telling us steps by steps.
review_cons: Loud music blasting constantly, smell of the in store spray can be hard on your nose after a week or so.

review_title: If you want a paycheck and great benefits then A&F is the place to be.
review_pros: The people you work with, the benefits are pretty awesome, and the clear direction from upper management.
review_cons: You essentially recruit your own replacement x whatever your boss sets as your goal, you're hiring primarily based on looks that fit the company image, you're expected to get "approvals" and MIT recruits every month- if you don't they use that as an excuse as to why you aren't being promoted, raises are subjective based on your relationship with your direct supervisor, and you work countless hours for "supplemental pay" (half your salary rate, which typically is under federal minimum wage after 40 hours worked per week).
review_advice_mgmt: Don't make false promises to managers who want to do good for the company and then paint a grey image for them to fall into. Also, your career shouldn't be defined by how many approvals and MIT recruits you've gotten, but more so by how well you can manage and lead your store to greatness.

review_title: When they are continually hiring for your position, that should set off red flags...
review_pros: Constant paycheck. Good health insurance. Great sick pay but can't use. OK vacation but can't use. Good discount if you like the clothes. Promised quick promotions only if you can get the other managers to not quit their jobs.
review_cons:
Work every weekend. Your days off are never consecutive so its hard to ever leave town. Management is stretched so thin that taking time off is impossible even when you are sick. You must recruit new managers and get them to stay in order to get promoted. If you cant do this you will be stuck at your position indefinitely. In the interview I was promised bonuses and working over 40 hours would be even pay. Worked a year and bonuses turned into donations to charity in your store's name when you meet goals (haha). My over 40 hours pay was actually $6.40. Yes, less than minimum wage.

Must work through breaks at times. Your district manager or home office is always adding additional tasks for you to do (they think we do nothing all day). As a visual manager, your job performance rests on the shoulders of a high schoolers who do not need/want to work. You listen to crappy songs on repeat all day. Your DM pressures to you to make associates buy clothes even though they don't have to. Constantly judging people on their looks it will make you sick. Your DM has complete unsupervised control of your store so your job really depends on them. By far the most stressful job. Take this job if you have no other choice.
review_advice_mgmt: Drop the attitude "If you don't like it, Ill hire someone else". Work on employee retention rather than bringing in new people in every month. Rotating weekends off would not be impossible. Do not lie in the interview to get people to work! Reward people for good/hard work with tangible rewards rather than just a pat on the back.

review_title: Great job to start with if just finished college.
review_pros: Abercrombie and Fitch will train you regardless of your experience.  Promotions can happen fast if you started at the right time (i.e. low on assistant and store managers).  Flexible schedules and insurance for domestic partners is another perk.
review_cons: Working retail hours is never fun.  The company has weird policies that customers do not understand or care about and will argue with about them.  Management always expects a perfectly folded store which is impossible with people shopping in the store.  They also only want people with a certain look to work at the store that you must recruit which recruiting will improve your chances of a promotion.  (A promotion is just for the job title, there is no actual promotion in your pay until you become a store manager.)

review_title: A&F was not an enjoyable employment experience
review_pros: The management program provides basic exposure to a wide variety of corporate subjects. The basic level managers get practice interviewing, organizing, and managing a large employee base.
review_cons: A lot of tedious work for management. A lot of reporting and mindless activities with no explanation. Employees aren't incentive to perform good work and there is no mentorship or much room for merit based promotion or movement.
review_advice_mgmt: The guidelines for managers don't promote a career at A&F. Those practices for new managers should be reviewed

review_title: Good environment socially, pay wise sucks!
review_pros: You get to meet great people! Co-Workers and some managers are great to talk too and work with.
review_cons: So much work as an impacter with VERY little pay! You're slaving just to see $100 checks. There are barely hours, the pay sucks! You have to buy their uniform every season which takes away from the money you salves for.
review_advice_mgmt: Give better uniform discounts! Give better pay!!!!

review_title: Some what a decent part-time job
review_pros: Cool environment for young individuals (18-22yr old) to meet new friends.
review_cons: Culture is very strict, due to the image that it try's to maintain.

review_title: Pay and management is terrible, staff (at my store at least) was pretty cool
review_pros: The other models who I worked with and the PTI were great. They definitely were good friends, a lot of fun, and a lot of the "cliques" we made here lasted outside of Abercrombie.
review_cons: Other than my coworkers, this job was absolutely TERRIBLE. Pay was atrocious: we got $7.25 an hour, and only four people got a $0.25 raise a year. The raise was/is not based on how many years you've been with Abercrombie or how loyal you are, not even on how many hours you dedicate to the store per week- its based on how CLOSE you are with management. In addition, Abercrombie likes to overview the term "Store Model" when hiring associates. Some people get so excited over being called a "Model" that they accept the $7.25 pay, when we are forced to do more work than $7.25 can compensate. Management will also go out of their way to make your life a living hell if they don't like you, and NO ONE lasts at Aber. There are some people who are loyal die-hards to the company and stay (despite the fact that they get no recognition), but other than those few, Abercrombie is a revolving door when it comes to new models, PTIs, and store management. No one stays. Whoever looks good and accepts $7.25 is good enough to work there, and if they expect more than to be overworked and given substandard treatment than they are shown the door and 3 other "good looking" people are hired in their place.
review_advice_mgmt: APPRECIATE your loyal employees!!! SO many of my friends have been with the company for 5+ years, hoping to achieve higher positions, and had their hopes ruined by "new" management (...and I say "new" because the entire management staff seems to change every 6 months". Instead of making Abercrombie & Fitch a store of new faces, try to keep the same hard working employees on your staff and treat them well... they're worth it! Also, only allotting 4 people per year a raise is unfair. Considering the amount of people Abercrombie & Fitch hires per year, it is unfair to only choose four to give raises to. This policy just ASKS for favoritism. Other than that, the only way to KEEP loyal employees is to give them yearly raises, even if its just a little, or based on work ethic. If associates feel like they are not being recognized or appreciated they wont stay... but don't you want them too? A lot of them are worth it.

review_pros: Great environment, good co-workers, discounts on clothing, meet a lot of new people, good music to work to, gained a lot of experience
review_cons: Not enough hours, some days were very redundant and slow, inconsistent scheduling, had to stay longer for stocks, minimum wage

review_pros: Fun people to work with, clean environment, you smell great leaving work, discount on clothes, get to listen to upbeat songs while at work
review_cons: the overwhelming perfume can give you a headache, some customers are difficult to deal with
review_advice_mgmt: Keep up the good work

review_title: Pros: flexibility for student, friendly environment Cons: weak management, lack of motivation
review_pros: flexibility, friendly environment with an open atmoshpere
review_cons: management skills are weak, the system lacks qualities that encourage motivation from employees
review_advice_mgmt: Restructure the system so that there are more staff with business skills, rather than just good looks

review_title: Merchant at A&F, they work you hard and expect social life to revolve around the company.
review_pros: You will work with fun, young people. Many social opportunities.  Good salary and opportunity for growth in the company.  The corporate culture is very relaxed and the attire is casual.
review_cons: Work and Life balance is nearly inexistent. The company expects that its employees will revolve their entire social life around A&F and its employees.  Partying is not at all uncommon here. This is not a "Professional" atmosphere.

review_title: Can be either really fun or extremely boring....depending on who is working that day.
review_pros: Young friendly staff, clothes discounts, lifelong friends, flexible schedules, fun atmosphere, opportunities to work in different stores if you move, if you get a degree you can be promoted to store manager.
review_cons: Low pay and gets really boring if your friends are not working. Also you are expected to keep buying the newest clothes that are released. They are particular about your nail color, hair style, etc...

review_title: My experience taught me that I do not want to work retail for the rest of my life.
review_pros: Easy job, very relaxed, flexible schedule, can get time off whenever you want.
review_cons: Boring if the store is slow, many of the people don't do anything, no raises ever, loud music, barely any hours, the managers are not good at managing, no employee appreciation.
review_advice_mgmt: Looks don't always mean everything, sometimes there needs to be some brains.  You should appreciate your employees and give them raises.

review_title: Great for entry level managers who wants to learn how to run a business
review_pros: Work with fun people who are all very driven, learn some great people management skills and operations functions, opportunity for growth early in career is high
review_cons: Work/life balance is low, very high expectations with little resources that are still being scaled back. Manager turnover is very high,
review_advice_mgmt: Hiring externally will help with retention and turnover

review_pros: Really good merchandising and selling method, good atmosphere with the other team member
review_cons: Very hard job, too much perfume and music
review_advice_mgmt: To train more the new impact member, because you have to learn all by yourself which is not always easy

review_pros: Solid discount of merchandise, very cute coworkers

review_title: Do not apply for this job!
review_pros: Good discounts on their clothing
review_cons: Fake people and dumb rules

review_pros:
Great health insurance and lots of training
Was able to transfer to a new city and the company helped with relocation costs
review_cons:
Sometimes only had a few hours to sleep between shifts
Worked 6 days a week on salary
Not much potential to eventually make much money, even with regular promotions
Shallow hiring practices
Too much turnover in management
review_advice_mgmt: Be willing to pay your managers more and hold onto them rather than continuing to hire new ones

review_pros: its a fun place to work, you get to know your staff
review_cons: not to much room for growth. Very unethical when promoting to store managers. and the turn over for managers is awful and can become very stressful when you have to work with 2 managers in a store. you do not get pay enough for the amount of work you do and raises with associates and management are not satisfying
review_advice_mgmt: to really look for better ways to help with district managers not depending on only store managers for feedback, but to also make your assistants feel more appreciated and stop a lot of drama from upper management like dm"s n store managers consulting about there assistants in negative ways. overall  upper management needs to be more professional.

review_title: Great place to spend your first two years out of college
review_pros:
- Great exposure to cross functional teams
- Good opportunity to work at a large cap company and have real responsibility very young
- Opportunities for management very early in career
- Fun, creative, aspirational corporate culture
review_cons:
- Very little training given to managers so you're likely to have at least one really bad manager while you're there
- Hours not so great, usually 12 hour days
- Responsibility and promotions usually given to who the higher up's like the most, or feel is the best fit for the company (i.e. wears all current A&F clothing, is tall, slim, and blond, and never plans to leave Ohio) rather than who is most qualified. Beware of this!
review_advice_mgmt: See above.

review_pros: Tons to learn with a very reputable company. When you do well, you get recognition and promotions are directly tied to performance.
review_cons: Long hours. Starting salaries are better elsewhere.
review_advice_mgmt: Work hard and live the brand

review_title: HR doesn't care about retainment and career advancement isn't based on quantitative accomplishments.
review_pros: Challenging with constant opportunities for personal growth, extremely casual atmosphere, lots of responsibility.
review_cons: Doesn't care about longterm happiness or growth of employees.  Apathetic HR representative Bill Piper. Growth of career isn't remotely based on actual quantitative accomplishment but based on friendships with upper management.
review_advice_mgmt: Upper management and HR should be way more involved and knowledgeable about the actual  "leadership" and "management" of their team leaders and managers. Their is no accountability  for team leaders or managers.

review_title: A lot of work, not enough pay
review_pros: The employees were great. The discount was ok for managers. It was 40% regular priced items .
review_cons: I was a visual assistance manager and the hours were crazy, a lot of work and that pay was ok. The management schedule was not flexible.
review_advice_mgmt: Flexible hours for managers

review_title: It was a fun environment, with fun people but definitely had some negative aspects.
review_pros:
-flexible part time hours
-great first job or through college 
-discounts on clothing 
- fun people 
- long time friends 
- easy work
review_cons:
- intimidating if you're skinny but by no means a size 0/00. 
- REALLY loud music which you get used to but still can't be good for your hearing
- really smelly
- meticulous folding 
- super strict look policy (dress code) 
- can be boring depending on your location and if you're the greeter stuck up front for 5 hours
review_advice_mgmt:
I loved all of the managers. It does take some time to feel like they like you, but if you prove you're reliable, they'll come around. 
As for the district managers... Unless you're pursuing modeling (and are the A&F ideally sized model)  its best to lay low with them. They can kill your self esteem in an instant, if they even acknowledge you to begin.

review_title: What I expected, with a few twists
review_pros: People seem to like that I worked there - they find it funny
review_cons: You smell terrible, the songs take over your mind and its so dark in the stores

review_title: management, who is your age, will treat you like a disposable servant."
review_pros: coworkers are amazing. if you don't get caught, you might be able to make your day more enjoyable through interactions with coworkers.
review_cons: they play favorites like crazy. one manager loves you, you get 30 hours that week. if they switch the scheduling manager, you suddenly have only 10. they hold grudges, are rude, and will probably yell at you if you're caught laughing.
review_advice_mgmt: it is your JOB to hire 18 year old frat boys and ditzes. you chose this job, so don't get frustrated with them when they're being themselves. you can't place someone in one spot for 8 hours, with nothing to do and expect them to be well-behaved good looking robots. at least not for the 10 bucks an hour you pay, which you tend to 'accidentally' shorten when paychecks come around.

review_pros: Not a very strenuous job. Other floor models are actually pretty nice. Basically you get paid to stand around and look hot as well as greet people.
review_cons: Poor hours. Management can be really uptight. Almost no chance to move up in the company. Very conceited. Poor hours and pay.
review_advice_mgmt: Learn how to properly manage a company for Christ's sake.

review_pros:
Discounts on clothing
Fun work environment
Good music (if you like it)

Toward the end of my employment with A&F (around 2009), we were forced to use employee discounts on certain clothes in certain colors. It was really like you were working to be compensated in clothing.
Many if not most of my coworkers were lazy, and just wanted to stand around looking pretty.
review_advice_mgmt:
Relax on the color schemes for employee clothing.
Stress customer service skills and training for employees.

review_title: chill for a high school student

review_title: It is a flexible place to work for teenagers and young adults."

review_cons: Abercrombie and Fitch is not an easy place to move ahead if you do not have desired "look". Although it is a flexible place to work for teenagers and young adults it is not a well paying job.
review_advice_mgmt: People should be hired based on their work skills, intellect etc. Employees should be more welcoming to customers.

review_title: Petty immature managers, Job for students who don't mind getting exploited
review_pros: -No pros working here at all.
review_cons:
-Min' wage
-coercive policy and management 
-Managers; whom are often 21-25  years of age act like high school students. They engage and start petty drama. Total lack of professionalism 
-No growth possibilities, many managers also end up quitting after head offices fail to keep promotion promises
-Managers use profanity to intimidate associates who don't know their rights 
-Managers, especially the females are too emotional and penalize you by reducing you weekly hours or making you do the less favorable tasks when you voice your concerns
- The managers are incompetent and blame the associates for their lack of proper management procedures  
- The Eaton centre store is filled with ignorant managers who influence their associates into discriminating against certain races and make rude comments about them
- I can go on but to sum it, MANAGEMENT is HORRIBLE stay clear! 


TRASH company.
review_advice_mgmt:
-GROW UP! Though this might not be the career path you foresaw and will probably not be advancing higher than managerial position with this company, you need to learn to manage your emotions. Your personal life issues should not spillover into your work.

-You are not doing anything special. You work a deskilled job which any high school student can do with training.

review_pros: Good looking people, flexible hours, great college job. The stores have something for everyone: accounting whizes can work the store numbers, brand enthusiasts can focus on presentation. The flagships are especially good at providing room for specialization.
review_cons: Low pay, store policies stifle creativity and flexibility for management. The store suffers from high manager turnover due to low pay and job satisfaction.
review_advice_mgmt: Pay your managers more and allow them to respond to local changes and problems with unique solutions. Also, speed up the supply chain.

review_title: Working at A&F can be a very miserable and demeaning experience depending on who you work with.

Good Benefits Package

Overworked and undercompensated

Hypocritical company culture
No lower management development

Treat your associates like human beings, not animals or better yet, slaves.
Reward a job well done.
Work on developing your associates and lower-level management.

review_pros: The people are fun and nice to work with.
review_cons: Very hard to get a raise, bad pay.
review_advice_mgmt: Stop being so judgmental on who you hire

review_title: Easy and flexible job great for high school/college age young adults.
review_pros: Extremely flexible schedules, not many job demands, fairly easy if you're good with interacting with customers.
review_cons: Minimum wage with few raises no matter how long you work for them.
review_advice_mgmt: Have a system to give raises after a certain amount of time.

review_pros: My schedule was very flexible. I was able to pick up or give out my hours very easily.
review_cons: It was very boring and they would rather you organize than talk with customers.

review_pros: Good management, great teamwork You get to meet a lot of new people around your age who have similar interests as you
review_cons: Not that i know of

review_pros: There were some genuinely cool people who worked there and discount on clothing is always nice (I am a sucker for their denim).
review_cons: When I think on my time at A&F I think of the loud music in the store that could eventually cause damage to my eardrums, the strong scent that has actually made my nose bleed, a one-dimensional job, and uptight store managers who always assumed I was up to no good. This was my first experience with crazy micro-managers and I realized that even though I'm a hard worker who normally respects authority, micro-managers make me want to rebel and do the opposite of whatever they tell me to.
review_advice_mgmt: Hire more employees who speak Japanese (since this was the Ala Moana Shopping Center location), give your employees more responsibility, trust your employees, and remember these employees may be young adults but they are humans not machines.

review_title: Pass on trying to be a 'model' here. Its the most boring job in the history of the universe.

The co-workers are pretty chill and friendly though.

mind numbingly boring, music too loud, cologne too saturated around the place. 
customers often want legitimate help finding things, but you receive no training of that sort, nor are you trained to fold properly, which will be expected of you at times.

review_title: do it for the people not the money
review_pros: great discounts, coworkers are friendly and fun.  a&f is an international company so I meet people from all over the world. love the store music and people think I'm rich when i say i work here...which so not true. i don't mind folding clothes so its fun for me. plenty of opportunity to move up in the company
review_cons: low pay and not enough hours.

review_cons:
Minimum Wage

review_pros: Get to meet some cool co-workers that are just trying to get by doing this as a part time job like you are.
review_cons: * Management was unorganized, the whole time I was there at A&F, they never got their computer fixed so I can put my own hours in the system, I would then write down my hours and they would schedule me completely different days or lose it.  I told A&F ahead of time I wouldn't be able to work Christmas Eve, the day after Christmas, NYE and New Years Day and they schedule me then after I gave them plenty of notice and after I was told they would honor my request.
review_advice_mgmt: Be a bit more organized

review_title: Not a brand that I would like to be associated with, but its a very strong brand image.
review_pros:
It is a very professional working environment.

review_pros: Friendly managers who take care of employees

review_pros: awesome high intensity environment. Great work experience!

review_pros: Loud music, great clothes, flexible schedule.

review_pros:

good starting benefits
sales associates are friendly

review_title: Very good experience, but not a career path.
review_pros:
- Every store I've worked in has a tight bond between associates
- Great atmosphere and a pretty good moral inside stores
- A satisfaction in being able to run a store on your own as a manager
- Wearing great clothes in style every day, very relaxed
review_cons:
- Constant unrealistic goals of hiring "pretty" people, that's the ONLY way they judge "performance"
- Corporate is a myth.  Can never talk to anyone from there and only communication you get from them is via Printer every morning
- Constant battle over budgeting hours based on sales, daily
- After store manager level, advancement is very hard
- Low salaries lead to constant turnover
review_advice_mgmt: Increase the salaries to some of the competitor's standards, you will increase your employee retention rate.  Have people answer phones in your corporate headquarters.  Stop having people go out recruiting, this does nothing for the company.  Most (if not all) of the "referrals" are snagged by managers when people already show up to inquire about a job.  Personally, I can tell you that everyone I've seen get an MIT role applied on their own.

review_pros: relaxed work enviornment, casual dress code, cool associates
review_cons: under paid, under staffed, under appreciated
review_advice_mgmt: Value your employees.

review_pros: I enjoyed the discount on the clothing
review_cons: it is dark, has loud music, and many intense smells

review_pros: Laid back work environment, really nice people, great flexibility, good hours if you're a good worker, great way to break yourself into retail
review_cons: Store managers can be a little power hungry and get catty with assistant managers, customers tend to have a bad attitude towards employees (models in particular), and hours have to be spread across a lot of models. As a model (floor sales associate), you don't get a lot of hours unless the managers like you. As an impact (stockroom), you get a lot more hours, but it's also more work, more pressure, less fun, and same pay.

review_title: It sucks but really easy work.
review_pros: You can be on your phone. Theres ultimately no punishment for anything (Late, rudeness). Paid breaks. Make your own hours if friends with management. Meet great people. Surrounded by good looking people.
review_cons: Always have to stay late. Tedious folding. rude customers. Superficial b***hes all over. Dont hire ugly people and dont put larger people on the sales floor. Discrimination.
review_advice_mgmt: Get the stick out of your a**.

review_pros: Retail Experience, opportunites to advance
review_cons: Minimum wage, crazy around holidays

review_title: Mixed Feeling about a Failing Retailer
review_pros:
I have worked for the Abercrombie & Fitch Company for four years now, both as a part time associate and at the management level.

-The stores are fun to work at, lively and have a good vibe about them.
-It is a clean and easy job.
-Management is not expected to fold clothing and we have freedom to do what we wish in the stores.
- Abercrombie stores are everywhere, thus transferring locations is very easy.
-Associate discount can be up to 40% for full time employees.
-Great medical benefits!
-The stores are very tight knit and everyone is friends with everyone.
review_cons:
-A&F has a tendency to harbor shady management on all levels of the company. The turnover rate for management is absolutely incredible, and 90% of the turnover is due to firing of management (internal theft, dishonesty, sexual harassment, discount abuse). You name it, I've heard it. 
-A&F is not competitive with wages and salaries. ALL part timers are making minimum wage and management is making among the lowest retail management salaries in the industry.
-The company is failing incredibly profit wise. Both Ruehl and Gilly Hicks (A&F owned brands) have folded in a three year time period. I do not see A&F being around 10 years from now with the same facade, type of clothing or company goals.
-The time frame for promotions from store management level to district level or home office level vary greatly. I've seen equally qualified store managers get promoted to a higher level in a 2 year time period, while it's taken others up to 6 years. Favoritism and physical appearance are the only factors in promotions within A&F.


Overall, A&F has been good to me, with some major drawbacks. I am overall very pessimistic about the future of this company.

review_title: Hot people in a sinking ship
review_pros: Lots of attractive young people working a college like environment. Nice base salary, but the hours make you question if it's actually worth it.
review_cons: Waste so much paper, ink, and time on designs that aren't creative. Not creative, because the upper management is too scared of the CEO

review_pros: Flexible, It's some kind of job
review_cons: Shitty Hours, Call ins galore, poor treatment

review_title: Seasonal employee for Winter 2012. I got almost no hours and actually lost money.
review_pros: The actual work is very easy. Regardless of your position, you'll spend time doing mindless task that quickly pass the time.
review_cons: Management gave me less than ten hours during the 1.5 months I worked there. On one of my two three shifts they called me in just to send me home an hour later. I lost money because they made buy a specific work outfit from the store (to be fair they gave me like 50% off). Management clearly favors better looking employees.
review_advice_mgmt: Corporate needs to start an intuitive to make all employees feel equal. There is a serious issue with some employees being bullied for being less attractive than some of the "floor models." An asian girl who had normally amount of weight (seriously, I'm not being nice, she was normal looking girl) was called fat by management behind her back.

review_title: Lack of corporate communication with store management
review_pros:
-Relaxed work attire
-Get to work with people close in age
review_cons: -Awful hours, never set schedule
review_advice_mgmt: Communication is lacking between management in stores and home office employees.  Stores could run smoother if home office employees would engage w/ store management to make more realistic solutions to problems.  Update/Floorset procedures would benefit from Brand Senses employees actually observing the process that they help create instead of just at mock stores.

review_pros: Flexible hours when you get shifts.
review_cons: Managers constantly change and associates come and go on a weekly basis. Upper management doesn't care about their employees and have a "I can easily replace you" attitude. Minumum wage with no raises. Getting breaks can be hard sometimes (there was a class action lawsuit recently (which A&F lost). Even though they claim they are an EOE, managers have said they hire based on looks and the company has a look policy binder that states the ideal physical look an employee should have. Basically if you're fat, ugly, and/or old, you won't get the job. Also, managers play favorites so if they don't like you, you won't get shifts. And lots of drama between employees (go figure since it'soarly high schoo/college students).
review_advice_mgmt: Honestly whatever I saw won't work since the company doesn't care what I have to say. But if they do, offer raises to hard working long-term employees and allow better upward mobility within the company. If you treat your employees right, they will make the company better.

review_title: Hide your morals and have some fun
review_pros: Its honestly a fun job! Great people (most of the time) and a good out of college experience
review_cons: If you have any sort of moral being, be prepared to ignore it for all the cool pretty people.

review_title: Fast paced, high stress....not worth it.
review_pros: Beautiful campus. Energetic atmosphere. Opportunities to contribute immediately.
review_cons: Too much to do. Too little time. Even if you work miracles to get the job done with excellent results...it is never enough. You are told to go faster and do it better and cheaper next time.

review_pros: The pay is not bad and there is definite room to grow so long as you fit their "look" and are very outgoing. I personally loved the working environment and the people I met.
review_cons: Get on your DM's good side. Little praise for all the jobs well done and plenty of talking behind everyone's back. The company really values the attractiveness of its part-time employees over everything else and managers have to make sure to recruit, recruit, recruit!
review_advice_mgmt: Read any business article and you will see that a lot needs to change to improve sales in the United States.

review_title: Ok company to work for part time
review_pros: Easy job to maintain while going to school or working full time somewhere else and you meet great people.  Also, you receive a 30-50% discount which is awesome.
review_cons: Raises of around $0.20 (at max) are given once per year if considered and obtaining a full time position is hardly given.  Must have a degree to be in management, but pay is low.

review_title: Grossly discriminate, it's sad how a store like this survives. It says a lot about Americans.
review_pros: There are non. blacks on the back of the bus, and in the stock room, always.
review_cons: Hmm, supremely superficial, if you're not light bright, you're not right. If you aren't silver spoon fed, why are you in this store? You know that's what they talk about in those pep talks. "Our clothes, for our lifestyle, for people like us." White people, white trash. Abercrombie and Fitch used to be a hunting and sporting apparel store, should've stayed that way. Those dead guys must be suffocating in their coffins from the stench of their brands cologne
review_advice_mgmt: It's all a disgusting facade. To make people think they'll look prettier in your clothes. You know you don't like anyone that wears a size 3 and above.

review_title: Great first job out of college, no opportunities for moving up the corporate ladder
review_pros:
Get to wear comfortable clothes
Work with great looking people
Everyone starts from the bottom and has to work their way up in the company
review_cons:
Cult like company, either jump on with their views, or run for the hills
Low pay
Work long hours
Super high turn over rate
review_advice_mgmt:
Pay your management more to help reduce the high turn over rate, pay is very low for retail industry which demands a college degree
Work on rotating schedules to give management teams off weekends
Try to better develop your management teams to move up within the company

review_pros: Flexible with schedules and nothing else
review_cons: Minimum wage, late hours into the morning, required to wear clothing, and power stricken managers.  My.anfcorp.com is dysfunctional almost every day.
review_advice_mgmt:
Be more practical. No person can perform in a work area on their feet for six hours wearing flip flops.  There should be at least one free uniform given to the associates after working at Abercrombie for a certain amount of months.  If LP is such an issue, remove the plants and create more sight lines and lower the volume of the music to hear any criminal activity occurring where there are no associates.  Making the store "perfect" after every closing is unrealistic and too demanding for the amount of money I am given every two weeks.  And after four months, I have had enough of Abercrombie and am leaving after "cool" friday.  And one last thing, having managers swipe their card to do a return is inconvenient for customers and the models, plus, having to get walked out by a manager is ridiculous.  There are hundreds of customers, twenty of us; check their bags, not ours.

Side note: no one "cool and popular" are wearing these clothes because they are HIDEOUS. Neon colors for men and glitter on sparkles for women is just ugly. If it weren't for resellers, there would be no customers in the store.  At this rate, I see Abercrombie failing in the next coming decade.

review_title: Not a place to grow old with
review_pros:
Lasting friendships with co-workers and associates
Benefit package
Flexible schedule
One of the only places that hire you in as a freshly graduate without any prior experience. The training program help build you from scratch.
review_cons:
I don't even know where to begin...The low morality and the corporate culture just make me sick in my stomach. You will constantly have to get out and "recruit" people, despite the fact that the store is overstaffed, thus causing constant turnover. DM tell you straight to the face: "Weep out the 'bad' employees." Bad here means "not very good looking".You will never get settle with good and experienced employees whom you can rely on. You will have to train someone new every week. The hiring practice is shallow as the company stress too much on how good looking a prospective employee is rather than how he/she would contribute to the success of the store.

High school drama between adults and favoritism present among lower and upper management. Home office provide you little to no support when you were trying to call them. Human Resource and Payroll departments never answer your phone call and always prompt you straight to voice mail no matter the fact that you have an emergency that need to be resolved in minute. Sometimes I wonder if the people working in that department actually get paid to do anything? DMs get brainwashed by the Home Office and forget their days as a Store Manager. 

Pay is among the lowest retailers while our CEO was named the most overpaid executive. And yet the standard and expectation are ridiculously high. Half pay for any overtime which is extremely discouraging. The turnover rate is soaring high that manpower become a significant concern and yet they couldn't even admit the main cause for the problem. And then they blame it on the lower managers for "not being able to train and retain people" so that they can use it as an excuse to make us constantly recruit for college grad. How could I recruit any beautiful good looking smart and intelligent college grad with nothing good to offer for them? Discount? Tried that, but I'm sorry your employee discount suck. No discount on clearance and you only get 40% off full-price merchandise. Promotion and advancement base on relationships rather than performances. 

Basically, working there make me feel suffocated and depressed as I see myself being molded into a beauty judging machine.
review_advice_mgmt: Mike, how about you cut 1 million in your annual compensation and give everyone a raise since you are sitting up there making wrong "choice of words" but we become the front line that take the bullets for you. And sell that unnecessary jet of yours to actually hire a few people to answer the phone for Home Office?

review_title: Stressed out managers make even more stressed out employees.

Also the pays TERRIBLE, even for a first job. . . AND you HAVE to wear their clothes which you pay for! EVERY SEASON, with very little options to choose from! Just go work at Forever21.
review_advice_mgmt: Chill. Also, stop discriminating against big chicks. You think big chicks can't fold clothes? You think your clothes are too good for big chicks?? Ellen degeneres try'd to advise you get your moral priorities straight and still nothings changed. BIG CHICKS NEED SHORT SHORTS AND PULLOVERS TOO

review_title: MIT program great for recent grads
review_pros: Great experience and fun atmosphere. As a manager you're working with mostly young college aged employees.

review_advice_mgmt: relax on the look policy

review_title: Great place straight out of college; expect to work a random schedule and a lot of weekends
review_pros: Great coworkers who are also young and active. Great training program to integrate you easily. Get a lot of responsibility -- managing stores with minimum of 80 part-time associates, developing schedules, organizing shipment/stockroom. If you work hard, have a positive and outgoing attitude, then you can get promoted very quickly and they only promote at store level from within. Also have awesome opportunities to travel abroad. Amazing medical and vacation benefits that begin almost immediately, but the pay is not quite as competitive as other competing small retailers.
review_cons: Schedules are rarely predictable and you will often work weekends especially during your first 6-8 months. Long hours on your feet, dark lighting especially in Hollister stores. The company is very detail oriented which is great, but also leaves very little room for any creativity or individual recognition. Very stringent store expectations, difficult to always follow and upper management can be very unforgiving.
review_advice_mgmt: Don't hold your managers to extreme goals that feel overwhelming or unobtainable. Be realistic and be positive. Give praise and support. Be honest -- don't lead managers to believe they will get promoted if you've already decided they have no opportunities for movement anymore.

review_title: Great place to start your first retail job
review_pros: Relaxed atmosphere, young people and fun place to work in without worrying about anything.No experience needed.
review_cons: Low wage, no opportunities to progress within the company, employees change at all times as well as managers.

review_pros: All young people with similar interests, can be a fun job depending on the people,  great benefits (medical vision dental), do require managers to have a bachelors degree
review_cons: Hours suck and pay is one of the lowest in retail, recruiting is annoying, have to rely on high school/college kids who are making minimum wage, get hired based on your looks

review_pros: Good benefits, Employees are awesome

review_title: Abercrombie does not care about there employees as much as you would think.

review_cons:
Terrible pay - bottom of the barrel but yet they require you to have a Bachelors degree. They give no employee discounts except once a season for the exact outfit they want you to wear.
Unethical - Hiring totally based on looks. If you see someone attractive you can offer them a job right then and there. But if they're not up to "company standard" you cannot hire them. It's awful. 
Work/Life Balance - They don't care about what's going on outside of work. Retail hours are hard enough but they'll have one manager closing every night and then the other opening. It's completely unfair and vacation is non-existent.
review_advice_mgmt: You're screwed and now your sales are reflecting it.

review_cons: Physical appearance is important. Period. Don't come thinking this is some "equal opportunity" workplace. This is an image driven brand. If you think it's shallow, don't apply.
review_advice_mgmt: Push advancement opportunities. Talk about them. More structure to the higher-archy.

review_title: DO NOT WORK FOR THIS COMPANY
review_pros: Easy to get a job here. For the part-time associates, they are very flexible with your work hours. That's about it.
review_cons:
Pay is horrendous compared to other retailers.

Upper Management does not have your best interests in mind.

My new District Manager did not like me because I voiced my concerns to her and defended my associates and managers. She wrote me up for insubordination for two separate incidences, both of which I had witnesses for, all who stated that I was in no way insubordinate. I filed an appeal to the disciplinary actions to HR. HR never contacted the witnesses I supplied, instead the investigation consisted of HR contacting the Regional Manager (who made a total of 2 trips to my store over my 1 year period as SM at this location), and decided between themselves to uphold the actions. I had attempted to contact my RM to discuss my concerns with him via phone and email, never did he once return my call or respond to my emails. I was essentially blacklisted from the company once my new DM decided she did not like me. 

In addition to the insubordination write-up I was given, my DM also wrote me up for poor performance. Never was it stated what areas I was lacking in. My store was in fact bringing in a higher revenue that the previous year and was selling a higher volume of units as well. When I compared my store metrics (based on our secret shop scores, interal audits, DM audits, etc.) to the other stores in my same district, my store was far from having the worst scores, yet I was the only one being put on this probationary period. 

Simply stated,this is not a company you want to work for. The immoral practices of the upper management and HR to the crap that comes out of the CEO's mouth, there are just too many reasons why not to waste time with this company.

Good riddance.
review_advice_mgmt: Need to listen to people that are actually on the front lines each and every day, as without them, you would not be receiving a pay check.

review_title: Awful company for which to work.
review_pros: Most associates are young and tend to be fun and energetic. Fair health benefits. One just needs to be attractive to be hired. Literally.
review_cons: Compensation is a joke (overtime is half the hourly rate) and not even remotely competitive within the retail industry. The company exhibits serious ethical business practices that must be fulfilled in order to advance. For example, the company "values" diversity and inclusion as long as you are not overweight and aesthetically appealing, and one's ability to be promoted is contingent on recruiting attractive 17 year-olds instead of performance. Management has no problem maligning assistants, throwing individuals under the bus for personal gain. Most associates are young; while many are fun and energetic, this job feels a lot like babysitting. Due to the company's values that foster an environment where physical appeal is one's greatest attribute (not work ethic surprisingly), many associates exhibit a sense of entitlement, which unfortunately translates into poor customer service. Frankly, management just isn't very intellectually astute.
review_advice_mgmt: AnF is a sinking ship; get off while you still can.

review_title: Pretty mundane.  My brain slowly turned to mush over time.  No one in management wants to be where they are.
review_pros: Depending on management it has the potential to be very flexible, with over 100 employees at most stores.  Always meeting new people at work.
review_cons: The repetitive nature of retail.  Folding, folding, folding, folding.  Also, sometimes it could be a challenge to get enough hours with so many employees in the pot.  Always meeting new people at work does not mean those people are quality individuals.  Many are materialistic snobs who have been trained to value external things more than other characteristics.  Those kinds of people will eventually make it to corporate.
review_advice_mgmt: Care deeply about your employees, make the best of every day, be professional, keep looking, you can do better.

review_advice_mgmt: Respect your lower level managers a bit more.  A few positive words can go a long way.

review_title: Bad place to work NOT RECOMMEND
review_pros:
Sales
Discounts
Maybe pretty people 
Don't know
and don't know
review_cons:
Many things to say about this section. But most of all, this company treats their staff very badly. I was hired as an MIT, then got promoted to Visual Assistant Manager. Entire experience there was horrible. I come home everyday feeling bad about myself ( because they make you think you're never good enough) or feeling bad that your manager just sucks. Overwhelmed feelings affected people that i love by sharing with them my day at work. 


Micro Management

Bad pay

Long hours. Especially holidays. Store managers get paid salary- work 10-12 hrs/day on average. They get days off in exchange for overtime. Assistant Manager gets paid hourly. They get paid half of their hourly salary working overtime. Although you will never ever work less than mins 42 hours/week. You will accumulate days off but requesting time off is never easy. They never want you to leave work.

Work-life- not balance ( shift 6am-6pm sometimes longer if your upper manager wanted to surprise you with a visit, 8pm-4am--- very irregular schedule)

Management team, upper management will not have your back unless you're store manager or higher. ( mostly because they cant afford to fire someone that sticks around for that long)

Stressful day

Upper Management visits store often- one problem- never give good compliments to all the hard work. but instead critique you more until your self esteem is as low as possible - Biggest reason for HIGH employee turnover rate ( Part or full time)

Hypocrite

Many things more. 

If you don't know how to rub people the right way or even fake it, you will never get anywhere in this company. Unless you are very pretty
review_advice_mgmt: NO use to have any advice. This is the company culture and how things work in the company.

review_advice_mgmt: BE MORE DIVERSE IN YOUR HIRING

review_pros:
All comes down to what store you're in. I was hired in a great store with amazing people who are still close friends now that I left. Awesome soundtrack; the cologne is hardly noticeable after working there and is something I still wear now. Manager In Training (MIT) program is awesome because you can move as fast/slow as you want; with the right amount of managers, your hours are decent and generally get to leave when your shift ends. Paid recruiting in the mall or going to campus was always fun. Company hires based on looks (it's a modeling retail store- complain all you want, but that's what they stand for). One interview with a District Manager (DM). 

I loved the company and the people. I would definitely return to the company if under new management.
review_cons: District Manager (DM) and Regional Manager (RM) for my area were terrible. Specifically, when the RM transferred to our region, all 7 Store Managers (SMs) quit within the first six months of her transfer. High turnover rate with management which makes for faster promotion (in some cases) and hinders you in others. DM asked me to manage a store after telling me it was an hour away; store was actually 2 1/2 hours away and company erased all history of having travelled there and refused to reimburse me. District Loss Prevention Manager (DLPM) became a jerk after being promoted. He threatened to fire me after I contacted a lawyer when he erased video information of a customer assaulting another Assistant Manager (AM). Required to work overtime after Manager In Training (MIT) is over especially in holiday season. This should be expected because it's like that in any store in retail.
review_advice_mgmt: Have RESPECT for employees. We're humans not animals. Stop bashing the public and making store associates/managers have to deal with the mess.

review_pros: pretty laid back, its easy to do, get to wear nice clothes, get to be around similar aged people
review_cons: very immature, as in most retail the customers can be rude, managed by college students, doesn't pay well
review_advice_mgmt: spend more time thinking about customer service rather than clothes price

review_pros: good people are working there
review_cons: the pay there is bad

review_advice_mgmt: More incentives, commission wouldn't hurt

review_pros:

review_cons:
the music is loud on the sales floor
training for new employees is not always the best
its a very strict work environment

review_pros:
you will get to work with some cool people
you will be compensated well
review_cons:
you will work with a lot of people with no experience, employees with experience are not recognized or rewarded, actually majority of the time the main people getting promoted are the people without experience, when they are done with you and they want a fresh face, they will figure out a way to get rid of you
don't expect a bonus, the company will never bonus the way they did in the past
review_advice_mgmt:
don't hire so many people that are full of themselves,, the company is known for hiring "diva's" and people are have self entitlement issues.. but there needs to be a balance,, not so many of them.. 
hire some people with experience and keep them
let the designers design things that people want
don't have so many merchants and don't give them so much power, there are too many they sit around and are bored much of the time
there is not a good balance between design and merchant world, designers need strength
Merchant seem to be trained to be against the world, they are off on their own, they don't work with their cross functional teams.
Baby merchants come in and they are nice, by the time they get a few promotions, they change to little tyrants.. seen it many times.. get rid of these tyrants.. they cause trouble
the company is structured wrong, changes and reorgs happen too easily by people that don't know what everyone is doing
many of these changes lack common sense and are not thought out strategically.
Reports and scorecards don't make sense, it is a manipulation of information to management
Everyone is trying to cover their ass and make it look like they are making contributions to the company.
The best manipulator looks the best and wins.
I could go on.. it may be too late to change.. but I think the internal workings of the company need to be improved before the product will every have a chance of improving

review_title: Before you apply, you should be warned.
review_pros: They have a very regimented corporate structure that allows new managers to learn at a very fast pace and cultivate a strong standard, but you will learn the majority of those things on your own. They promote from within so if you work hard you can get promoted fast, but with little pay raise.
review_cons: The turnover rate is absurdly high, most managers will quit by their fourth month. The competence of management varies excessively and the majority of them will bad mouth an bash each other behind their backs (i.e. a very hostile work environment). The CEO is a stubborn idiot who is resistant to change and seems to rather see his company crash and burn than to alter his idea of what the brand should be.
review_advice_mgmt: The superficiality of the recruiting process doesn't allow stores to have enough management staff which forces managers to be consistently overworked, which is why so many quit. The culture that is forced upon its employees is outdated and not relatable to the current market and seems to turn more people off to the brand than bringing people into the store.
